BREAKING: Jack Dorsey, the chief executive officer of Twitter, announced on Wednesday afternoon that his company will no longer allow political ads on its platform.‚Å†
‚Å†
The decision comes amid the heavy criticism Facebook has received in the last several weeks over its decision to allow politicians to run misleading and outright false ads on its platform.‚Å†
‚Å†
Dorsey appeared to take a subtle shot at Facebook‚Äôs position in a tweet thread he wrote announcing the news: "For instance, it‚Äòs not credible for us to say: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre working hard to stop people from gaming our systems to spread misleading info, buuut if someone pays us to target and force people to see their political ad‚Ä¶well...they can say whatever they want! üòâ‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Dorsey‚Äôs announcement called for further regulation of the online political advertising industry, as he argued it was ‚Äúworth stepping back‚Äù to reconsider whether ‚Äútoday‚Äôs democratic infrastructure‚Äù is ‚Äúprepared to handle‚Äù the kinds of advertising his company has helped make possible.‚Å†
(üì∏: Imago/ZUMA)

Trump keeps eyeing Syria's oil‚Äîbut there's not much there.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
As he announced the death of ISIS founder Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi Sunday morning, Trump reiterated his desire to keep some US troops in Syria to secure control of its oil. ‚ÄúThe oil is so valuable,‚Äù he said. ISIS had profited from Syria‚Äôs oil, he noted, and now the Kurds could benefit from it. And, he said, ‚ÄúWe should be able to take some also.‚Äù‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Trump then repeated his assertion that the United States should have seized Iraq‚Äôs oil when it invaded that country in 2003. ‚ÄúI said keep the oil. If they are going into Iraq, keep the oil. They never did.‚Äù That echoed Trump‚Äôs long-standing belief that US military intervention in the Middle East should treat oil as a spoil of war, as summed up in this 2012 tweet: "We should have gotten more of the oil in Syria, and we should have gotten more of the oil in Iraq. Dumb leaders."‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Even before Trump‚Äôs latest statements, US forces had helped Kurdish-led forces retake and hold onto oil and gas fields in eastern Syria. Yet while Syria‚Äôs fossil fuels may be strategically important, they aren‚Äôt the economic windfall Trump seems to think they are.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Syria‚Äôs oil industry has crashed since the civil war started in 2011. Last year, the country produced around 28,000 barrels a day‚Äîone-fifteenth of its 2010 production and a measly 0.03 percent of the world‚Äôs total output.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Trump's now suggested that he'd crack a deal with Big Oil companies like Exxon to ramp up Syria's production. The thing is, even if Syria were to resume oil production at pre-war levels and Trump were somehow able to expropriate it all (a logistically and legally dicey proposition, to say the least)‚Äîit would only cover about a week of the United States‚Äô oil consumption.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä

A group of scientist advisers fired by the Trump administration is warning that national limits on fine particles of air pollution aren‚Äôt strong enough to protect people.‚Å†
‚Å†
The expert panel of epidemiologists and toxicologists was disbanded by the Environmental Protection Agency but decided to continue its work anyway.‚Å†
‚Å†
The members are issuing their warnings as US regulators are reconsidering a standard for particulate matter‚Äîthe inhalable pollution that is 30 times smaller than the width of a human hair. The pollution can include any of hundreds of chemicals and come from power plants, cars, construction sites, and fires. It's linked with breathing and heart illnesses and early deaths.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúBased on full consideration of the overall body of scientific evidence, we unequivocally find that the current standards for fine particulate matter do not protect public health and must be revised,‚Äù said Chris Frey, a scientist from North Carolina State University who chaired the group. ‚ÄúThere is no way for EPA to spin this otherwise.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Frey and the other researchers worry the Trump administration may try to ease pollution restrictions, despite the clarity of the new science. Trump agencies are rolling back environmental and health protections across the board.‚Å†
‚Å†
With a new study from Carnegie Mellon University finding that an increase in fine particle pollution between 2016 and 2018 was associated with 9,700 additional premature deaths, it's more important than ever to regulate air pollution. Click the link in our bio to read more.‚Å†
(üì∏: John Short/Zuma)

As President Donald Trump announced the death of ISIS founder Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, it was impossible to avoid comparisons to President Barack Obama‚Äôs May 2011 announcement that Navy SEALs had killed al-Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä

Vice President Mike Pence still won't say what he knew about Trump's Ukraine deal‚Äîdodging questions and insisting Trump ‚Äúdid nothing wrong.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
On Sunday morning, Pence refused to answer whether he knew about Trump‚Äôs efforts to withhold military aid to Ukraine unless President Volodymyr Zelensky authorized an investigation into former Vice President Joe Biden and his son Hunter, a quid pro quo that has been corroborated by several top diplomats in their testimonies in the House impeachment inquiry.‚Å†
‚Å†
During his appearance on "Face the Nation," CBS News‚Äô Margaret Brennan pressed Pence four times on whether he had ‚Äúknowledge of the deal that these US officials have described under oath.‚Äù The vice president avoided directly answering the question, instead pointing to his own interactions with Zelensky, in which Pence said he ‚Äúfocused entirely on President Zelensky‚Äôs agenda to bring about reforms to end corruption in Ukraine and to bring together the European community to provide greater support for Ukraine.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúI can only tell you what I know,‚Äù Pence said. ‚ÄúAnd what I know is that the transcript of the president‚Äôs call with President Zelensky shows that there was no quid pro quo. He did nothing wrong.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
When asked asked a third time, Pence said ‚Äúthere was no pressure. It was entirely focused on issues.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
It was an encore of a similar exchange the vice president had during a press event in Iowa earlier this month. There, NBC News reporter Vaughn Hillyard asked Pence whether he had direct knowledge that the president had held up military aid to Ukraine in exchange for investigating the Bidens. Pence also ducked answering questions on that occasion.‚Å†

The House of Representatives will vote this week on continuing the impeachment investigation and opening proceedings to the public, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced Monday.‚Å†
‚Å†
In a letter addressed ‚ÄúDear Democratic Colleague,‚Äù Pelosi reiterated that the Constitution does not require the House to hold a vote before beginning an impeachment investigation‚Äîand noted that a federal court recently agreed with that fact. ‚ÄúJust last week, a federal court confirmed that the House is not required to hold a vote and that imposing such a requirement would be ‚Äòan impermissible intrusion on the House‚Äôs constitutional authority,'‚Äù she wrote. ‚ÄúThe Trump Administration has made up this argument‚Äîapparently out of whole cloth‚Äîin order to justify its unprecedented cover-up, withhold key documents from multiple federal agencies, prevent critical witnesses from cooperating, and defy duly authorized subpoenas.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúThis week, we will bring a resolution to the Floor that affirms the ongoing, existing investigation that is currently being conducted by our committees as part of this impeachment inquiry, including all requests for documents, subpoenas for records and testimony, and any other investigative steps previously taken or to be taken as part of this investigation.‚Äù the letter continues. ‚ÄúWe are taking this step to eliminate any doubt as to whether the Trump Administration may withhold documents, prevent witness testimony, disregard duly authorized subpoenas, or continue obstructing the House of Representatives.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúNobody is above the law,‚Äù Pelosi concludes.‚Å†
‚Å†
Click the link in our bio to read the full letter.‚Å†

The abortion bans just keep coming, but even anti-abortion groups doubt they'll work.‚Å†
‚Å†
On October 1, a federal judge blocked a Georgia law banning abortion after six weeks of pregnancy. On the very same day, a nearly identical bill was introduced in the Florida state legislature.‚Å†
‚Å†
For every legal setback to the recent efforts by Republican state lawmakers to impose effective blanket bans on abortion, there‚Äôs been another push to pass new ones. But with the courts in seeming unanimous agreement on the unconstitutionality of these measures, even anti-abortion groups are doubting the wisdom of the slew of bans.‚Å†
‚Å†
South Carolina legislators are also considering a bill that would ban abortions after a fetal heartbeat can be detected and make providing an abortion after that point a criminal offense. Nine states have passed bans on abortion pre-viability: Georgia, Ohio, Kentucky, Louisiana, Alabama, Mississippi, Missouri, Utah, and Arkansas.‚Å†
‚Å†
The confirmation of Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh in October of 2018 spurred many state legislatures to pass abortion bans in the hopes of getting a case to the Supreme Court that could overturn Roe v. Wade. However, so far none of these laws have been upheld by federal judges. Without a split among the federal courts on the abortion bans the Supreme Court is unlikely to take up any of these cases, says Stephen Wermiel, a constitutional law professor at American University.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúI think the Supreme Court isn‚Äôt sitting around anxious to have to decide one of these,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúThe real question will be: Does the court have to pick one of those cases [as a result of] the federal appeals courts being in conflict? But so far, none of the federal courts have upheld any of these pre-viability bans.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Even major anti-abortion organizations such as Americans United for Life have spoken out against these bans, arguing that they are not the best strategy to roll back abortion access.‚Å†
‚Å†

The climate change solution that scientists have been overlooking? Increased access to effective contraceptives.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúGlobal climate change represents a grave threat to the future of human welfare and our natural environment,‚Äù write doctors John Bongaarts and R√©gine Sitruk-Ware of the Population Council in New York in an article published in BMJ Sexual & Reproductive Health.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúThe contentious ongoing policy debate about potential interventions focuses on switching to renewable energy sources and increasing energy use efficiency," says the study. "But given the urgency of the problem and the lack of political will, other approaches to limit greenhouse gas emissions should be given higher priority. Improving access to effective contraception is one such policy that has thus far been largely ignored by the international climate community."‚Å†
‚Å†
The authors claim that improved access to contraception could slow population growth and thereby reduce long-term greenhouse gas emissions globally by 40 percent or more.‚Å†
‚Å†
Bongaarts and Sitruk-Ware write that many married women‚Äîmore than half in some countries‚Äîwho do not wish to become pregnant still fail to use contraception due to barriers to access, high costs, and social stigma. Consequently, there are about 99 million unintended pregnancies worldwide each year.‚Å†
‚Å†
As Paul Ehrlich, author of "The Population Bomb," told Mother Jones in 2010, ‚Äúoverpopulation, combined with overconsumption, is the elephant in the room‚Äù in climate discussions. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt talk about overpopulation because of real fears from the past‚Äîof racism, eugenics, colonialism, forced sterilization, forced family planning, plus the fears from some of contraception, abortion, and sex. We don‚Äôt really talk about overconsumption because of ignorance about the economics of overpopulation and the true ecological limits of Earth.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†

Pop music can suck‚Äîlike really suck‚Äîsometimes. It also can be really good‚Äîlike really good‚Äîsometimes.‚Å†
‚Å†
For too long the genre was demeaned as exclusively ‚Äúthe taste of 13-year-olds.‚Äù Critics were long given license to tear into the genre and its stars. In a 2014 60 Minutes and Vanity Fair poll, they asked, ‚ÄúWhich decade had the worst music?‚Äù and an overwhelming 42 percent of respondents said it was the current decade. Pop music, according to one headline, has been ‚ÄúLiterally Ruining Our Brains.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
That critical consensus has shifted. While pop music has always had stars both mainstream and underground defying stereotypes, only recently has the modern pop genre been dissected and intellectualized with thorough fanfare. Which is good: Because artists like @ldevinemusic deserve it.‚Å†
‚Å†
Devine‚ÄîBritish-born Olivia Devine‚Äîrepresents the type of pop artist shaping the future of the genre. ‚ÄúI got into pop music, not because I listen to it more than other genres, but because pop music is the one you can bend the most,‚Äù she told @readdork.‚Å†
‚Å†
Part of what defines pop music is its inability to be defined, writes @sam.vp. Devine‚Äôs newest single, ‚ÄúPeachy Keen,‚Äù asks: Why should we even try to define it?‚Å†
‚Å†
Click the link in our bio to read how Devine is helping define a new era of pop music‚Äîby making it messier.‚Å†
(üì∏: Robin Pope/Zuma)

The largest-ever survey of campus sexual assault shows how outrageously common it is.‚Å†
‚Å†
A new survey of campus sexual violence in the United States has found that more than one in four undergraduate women from 33 large universities have experienced sexual assault while they were students. Fewer than 30 percent of those women, who were assaulted by force or while they were unable to consent, filed a report or sought help or counseling from their schools‚Äîtypically because they believed they could handle it alone, were too embarrassed or ashamed, or felt that what they had experienced was not serious enough to merit assistance.‚Å†
‚Å†
The survey of more than 181,000 students, conducted last spring and published this week by the Association of American Universities, is the largest of its kind.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúThe disturbing news from this year‚Äôs survey is that sexual assault and misconduct remain far too prevalent among students at all levels of study,‚Äù AAU president Mary Sue Coleman wrote in a letter accompanying the results.‚Å†
‚Å†
According to David Cantor, a senior statistical fellow at the research firm Westat and lead author of the report, it‚Äôs unclear whether the small increase reflects a rising rate of sexual assault, or whether it‚Äôs the result of other factors. ‚ÄúMeToo may have led to a somewhat different mix of students responding to the survey,‚Äù Cantor explains.‚Å†
‚Å†
But even as student awareness of sexual assault has grown, Cantor says there is no evidence that the survey was influenced by more students recognizing incidents of sexual assault. We dive into the study, click the link in our bio to read.‚Å†
(üì∏J. Lawler Duggan/For The Washington Post/Getty)

@kamalaharris wants to hold oil companies and utilities responsible for their roles in the climate crisis‚Äîby prosecuting them.‚Å†
‚Å†
California Senator and 2020 Democratic presidential hopeful Kamala Harris believes the next commander in chief should hold fossil fuel companies accountable for misleading the public about climate change‚Äîand she wants to use the full force of the federal government to do so. In an exclusive interview with Mother Jones last week in Dubuque, Iowa, she promised to mobilize the Department of Justice and the EPA to ensure ‚Äúthat we‚Äôre going to put pressure on the big companies to do what is required and what is responsible.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Asked if the federal government should play a role in investigating fossil fuel companies, Harris said ‚Äúabsolutely,‚Äù adding ‚Äúlet‚Äôs get them not only in the pocketbook, but let‚Äôs make sure there are severe and serious penalties for their behaviors.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
One of those companies, Harris suggested, could be California‚Äôs largest utility, Pacific Gas & Electric (PG&E). In recent years, PG&E has invested heavily in renewables, but from 1989 to 1991, the utility was part of the campaign to delay and derail climate action through the Global Climate Coalition, a group of industry groups that worked to delay and derail regulation through 2002.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúEveryone that was part of misinforming the public, misleading the public, and false advertising should be held accountable,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúThere is, in my vision of the future, a very important role for utilities to play in being held accountable.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†

Republican representatives are pushing ridiculous conspiracy theories to defend Trump.‚Å†
‚Å†
On Tuesday the House Judiciary Committee held a hearing to ask federal officials about election security efforts. The witnesses‚ÄîMatt Masterson of the Department of Homeland Security, Nikki Floris of the FBI, Adam Hickey of the Department of Justice, and Ben Hovland of the Election Assistance Commission‚Äîrepresent some of the most active and knowledgeable experts on the subject heading into the 2020 election.‚Å†
‚Å†
But even against this backdrop of serious concerns, some Republicans on the committee used their time with the experts to attempt to defend President Donald Trump against revelations linked to the Russian influence campaign that aided his election, and to push a thoroughly debunked conspiracy theory that the hack that targeted the Democratic National Committee either never happened or was carried out by someone other than Russia.‚Å†
‚Å†
Rep. Matt Gaetz, a Florida Republican and one of the president‚Äôs most enthusiastic congressional defenders, used his time to say Tuesday‚Äôs hearing was ‚Äúabout smearing the president of the United States and validating the corrupt people who have been involved in de-legitimizing his historic election.‚Äù He then badgered Floris into commenting on former FBI agent Peter Strzok‚Äôs affair.‚Å†
‚Å†

The conspiracy theories‚Äô persistence shows how the president can lob disinformation bombs into the national discourse and expect to find congressional Republicans willing to validate them, even in the face of all evidence.‚Å†

@ocasio2018 asked Mark Zuckerberg about Facebook's fact-checking process. He didn't give her the full truth.

During his congressional testimony on Wednesday, Zuckerberg tried to side-step responsibility for partnering with the conservative site the Daily Caller, giving an at-best misleading answer to a pretty direct question from Ocasio-Cortez.

She asked Zuckerberg why Facebook partnered with ‚Äúthe Daily Caller, a publication well-documented with ties to white supremacists, as an official fact-checker for Facebook.‚Äù Her question refers to the organization‚Äôs history of employing people like Scott Greer, a deputy editor who's previously written for a white supremacist publication, and running articles from prominent white supremacists like Jason Kessler and Peter Brimelow. ‚ÄúWe actually don‚Äôt appoint the independent fact-checkers,‚Äù Zuckerberg said. ‚ÄúThey go through an independent organization called the Independent Fact-Checking Network, that has a rigorous standard for who they allow to serve as a fact-checker.‚Äù ‚ÄúSo you would say that white supremacist‚Äìtied publications meet a rigorous standard for fact-checking?‚Äù she asked skeptically. Zuckerberg dodged, deferring to the outside organization.

While the Independent Fact-Checking Network (IFCN), a unit of the Poynter Institute for Media Studies, does make decisions as to who makes it into the pool of Facebook‚Äôs fact-checkers, the platform makes its own choices about which IFCN organizations actually get to fact-check the articles shared‚Äîa detail Zuckerberg conveniently left out.

@voxdotcom's Aaron Rupar explained the Facebook fact-checking process back in May: "IFCN certification is a necessary condition for partnering with Facebook, but once a site is certified, it‚Äôs up to Facebook to decide whether to partner with it." What‚Äôs interesting about Zuckerberg not mentioning Facebook‚Äôs responsibility here is, according to the @wsj, Zuckerberg was directly involved in discussions with Facebook vice president and former Bush staffer Joel Kaplan about whether or not to include the Daily Caller.

So yes, Facebook doesn‚Äôt accredit its fact-checkers, but, as Zuckerberg knows, it does pick them.
(üì∏: Stefani Reynolds/ZUMA)

Last week, after months of negotiations, tens of thousands of Chicago teachers stepped away from the classroom to strike on behalf of what the city‚Äôs schools CEO, Janice Jackson, calls a ‚Äúsocial justice bargaining‚Äù agenda.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
She used the phrase sneeringly, but what was there to sneer at? In addition to the standard suite of educator demands‚Äîpay raises, a reduction in class sizes, more social workers and nurses‚Äîthe Chicago Teachers Union is calling on the city to increase funding for affordable housing, hire staff to help homeless students, and expand community schools that offer ‚Äúwraparound‚Äù services for students. Educators are asking Chicago to address the gaps in social provisions they‚Äôre too often called upon to fill themselves.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
These are a unique set of demands, from a union that played an outsized role in re-energizing the labor movement and raising worker expectations around the country. Going up against then-Mayor Rahm Emanuel during their 2012 strike, Chicago teachers likewise went beyond simple bread-and-butter issues like pay and made demands for broader social change, framing the issue as one of racial equity.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
This is known as ‚Äúbargaining for the public good,‚Äù and teachers' unions are increasingly adopting the approach. Earlier this year, in Los Angeles, teachers parlayed a walkout during contract negotiations into more funding for nurses and social workers, reduced class sizes, and even limits to police searches.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Mother Jones reporter Edwin Rios spoke to Stacy Davis Gates, vice president of the Chicago Teachers Union, to get all the questions answered. What‚Äôs the current status of negotiations? What are the core differences between the two sides? Why is it important to talk about education in harmony with other issues like support staff and affordable housing?‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Click the link in our bio for all those answers and more.‚Å†‚†Ä

Climate change is coming for America's favorite wine grape.‚Å†
‚Å†
The cabernet sauvignon grape produces the type of cabernet wines that have defined Napa Valley for decades. A wine made with Napa cabernet sauvignon grapes, picked at the height of ripeness, will be intensely flavored with ripe plum, black currant, and floral notes.‚Å†
‚Å†
But as the valley sees warmer nights, less fog, and more days that surpass 100 degrees, cabernet producers are struggling to ripen their grapes as they lose the conditions that once gave their wines a flavorful edge. As the planet trends warmer, a number of researchers predict that, at some point in the next two to three decades, cabernet will stop thriving in Napa.‚Å†
‚Å†
Wine grapes grow only under very specific conditions: the narrow bands of 30 to 50 degrees of latitude in each hemisphere, where the average temperature during the hottest months hovers in the mid-60s and just south of freezing during the coldest. Their sensitivity makes them a bellwether for climactic shifts, sounding the alarm for agricultural production more broadly.‚Å†
‚Å†
Click the link in our bio to read more about the ecological threats facing California's wine region‚Äîand to listen to our latest Bite podcast featuring Mother Jones reporter Kara Voght in Napa.‚Å†
‚Å†
(üì∏: CaroleGomez/Getty)

Facebook updated its election policies, but they still give Trump room to lie.‚Å†
‚Å†
On Monday, Facebook founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg announced the removal of four manipulation campaigns from the company‚Äôs platforms. During a call announcing elections-related policy changes, Facebook said the operations, three of which originated in Iran and the other from Russia and targeted the US, North Africa, and Latin America, were examples of ‚Äúcoordinated inauthentic behavior‚Äù campaigns designed to make content artificially popular while concealing who is behind a message.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúActors in these nations are continuing to attempt to interfere in elections and public debate around the world, and including in the US,‚Äù Zuckerberg said on a Monday call with reporters, boasting that the company was ‚Äúmore prepared heading into 2020,‚Äù and that its detection of the networks ‚Äúshould provide some confidence that our systems here are working.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
The company also announced several new and updated policies around elections, including a ban on voter suppression ads encouraging people not to cast ballots. A number of steps are aimed at increasing information about who is spreading messages on the platform, including showing the confirmed owner of a page, labeling state-controlled media on their pages and in the company‚Äôs Ad Library, instituting a US presidential candidate spending tracker, making fact-checking labels clearer, and promising an ‚Äúinitial investment of $2 million‚Äù for media literacy projects ‚Äúto help people better understand the information they see online.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
But one policy rolled out in late September remains unaffected by Monday's announcement: Politicians are exempt from third-party fact-checking on the grounds that what politicians say is inherently newsworthy and should be ‚Äúseen and heard,‚Äù even if untruthful.‚Å†
‚Å†

Shortly after a new poll showed that half of Americans now support his removal from office, President Donald Trump on Tuesday offered up a wildly inappropriate and offensive comparison.‚Å†
‚Å†
"So some day, if a Democrat becomes President and the Republicans win the House, even by a tiny margin, they can impeach the President, without due process or fairness or any legal rights," he tweeted. "All Republicans must remember what they are witnessing here - a lynching. But we will WIN!"‚Å†
‚Å†
The ‚Äúlynching‚Äù description does not resonate with most Americans, who increasingly support Democrats‚Äô impeachment inquiry. Even a handful of Republican lawmakers now back the probe. It does, however, come as the latest self-victimizing tantrum Trump has thrown in recent weeks, as key witnesses in the Ukraine scandal have ignored the White House‚Äôs demand for silence with testimony damning for Trump and his allies.‚Å†

As pop sensation Rosal√≠a rises to global superstardom, it might be time to assess what it means to be a Latin artist.‚Å†
‚Å†
Flamenco singer Rosal√≠a‚Äôs ascent on the charts has felt almost instantaneous. Since her acclaimed and controversial sophomore album El Mal Querer dropped in November 2018, the 26-year-old artist, whose full name is Rosal√≠a Vila Tobella, has skyrocketed out of the Spanish underground into full-fledged pop stardom in less than a year.‚Å†
‚Å†
Rosal√≠a became the first Catalan artist in MTV‚Äôs Video Music Award history to win multiple awards, snatching trophies for Best Choreography and Best Latin video for her hit ‚ÄúCon Altura.‚Äù ‚ÄúI come from Barcelona,‚Äù Rosal√≠a said while accepting the VMA for Best Latin video. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so happy to be here‚Ä¶representing my culture.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
That acceptance speech earned Rosal√≠a a strong side-eye from some viewers. As Afro-Dominican journalist Jennifer Mota put it: ‚ÄúWhat part of ‚ÄòCon Altura‚Äô was Rosal√≠a‚Äôs culture, exactly?‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
While Rosal√≠a‚Äôs wildly popular song draws heavily from Afro-Caribbean music traditions, the artist herself has no Latin American heritage‚Äîa fact that has sparked cries of cultural appropriation from many Latinx fans. Since the artist‚Äôs catapult into the upper-crust of Latin music over the past year, a debate about race, class, privilege, and who gets to be considered Latinx has followed close behind.‚Å†
‚Å†
Mother Jones writer Justin Agrelo dives into the complicated and messy history of the reasons the media continues to misidentify Spanish artists as Latinx, and how if Rosal√≠a wants to continue to make reggaeton music, she should, at the very least, do a better job acting as an ally for Afro-Latinx people. Artist Chiraag Bhakta created an artwork about appropriation. San Francisco‚Äôs Asian Art Museum tried to appropriate it.‚Å†
‚Å†
In 2013, the Asian Art Museum in San Francisco hosted an exhibition called Yoga: The Art of Transformation, the first major show about the 2,500-year history of yoga. Curators invited Bhakta to contribute to an educational exhibit for the show. But he didn‚Äôt expect the absurdities that would follow‚Äîa parade of condescension, passive aggressiveness, and white fragility in which the Asian Art Museum revealed itself to be in a losing struggle with the whiteness at the core of its identity.‚Å†
‚Å†
Bhakta included an assemblage of yoga ephemera he's collected in the form of magazines, books, posters, and album covers. Together they told the story of how the $16 billion yoga industry in this country had rebranded a South Asian discipline to sell yoga as a line of products‚Äîhow yoga became Yoga‚Ñ¢. He titled his work #WhitePeopleDoingYoga.‚Å†
‚Å†
The show‚Äôs lead curators and education staffers Bhakta had met‚Äîall but one of whom were white‚Äîdidn‚Äôt feel completely comfortable with the title. They wanted something innocuous like #PeopleDoingYoga, without the word ‚Äúwhite,‚Äù because the term ‚Äúwhite people‚Äù could be ‚Äúoffensive‚Äù to museumgoers, donors, and staff.‚Å†
‚Å†
Bhakta says they insisted he remove a section of the installation‚Äîa Hindu-inspired shrine featuring photographs of a white couple as South Asian gurus. ‚ÄúThis might be offensive to Indian people,‚Äù staffers said‚Äîwhite authorities telling an Indian person what Indian people might find offensive. Bhakta stood firm on the title #WhitePeopleDoingYoga, but he took down the shrine depicting a white couple as South Asian gurus.‚Å†
‚Å†
After taking parts of the exhibit down, Bhakta thought the worst was over, but it was only the beginning. Click the link in our bio to read more about Bhakta's experience with the Asian Art Museum, which he calls "an exercise in watching white people work out their identity on the back of mine."‚Å†
‚Å†
(üì∏: Claudine Gossett for Drew Altizer Photography)

From the day Donald Trump assumed the presidency, it‚Äôs been clear that he planned to burn it down.‚Å†
‚Å†
He didn't plan to burn down the office itself, but the system on which it is built: the credibility of the electoral system by which that formidable power is attained. The norms, customs, and processes that constrain it. And, perhaps most importantly, the idea that the people who bestow that power are entitled to know how it is being used.‚Å†
‚Å†
Trump is now going ballistic because the walls are closing in. Even Fox News‚Äô polling finds that more than half of voters support the impeachment inquiry‚Äîand a Washington Post poll finds a quarter of Republicans and right-leaning independents back it too. A growing number of people trust the media to tell the truth more so than they do Donald Trump. In court, some of his claims that he is above the law are getting pulverized. And the revelations have only just begun.‚Å†
‚Å†
For the facts to come out, journalism must remain steadfast and keep digging. Trump knows his biggest enemy is not the media: It‚Äôs the truth. We‚Äôre seeing that when his misdeeds are revealed, he is forced to increase his lying, spinning, and gaslighting‚Äîto the point where it may no longer work even for him. ‚Å†
‚Å†
At Mother Jones, we have been doing all we can to serve the truth‚Äîto uncover the stories that others miss, discount, or ignore, to keep a harsh light trained on those in power. We‚Äôre a little exhausted, just as you are. But just like you, we realize it is time to shift up a gear and keep going strong. ‚Å†
‚Å†
If you can help us do it‚Äîbecause the only people who will pay for this kind of journalism are readers like you‚Äîyour donation of any amount will be doubled as part of our huge Moment for Mother Jones campaign. And it will be a powerful signal that during this critical moment for our democracy, you came down on the side of truth and transparency.‚Å†
‚Å†
Click the link in our bio to find out how you can help us provide the hard-hitting journalism this pivotal time demands.‚Å†

Police have routinely failed to test women's rape kits. Women all over the country are suing.‚Å†
‚Å†
Heather Marlowe had DNA evidence collected for a rape kit at San Francisco General Hospital in May 2010. A year later, the San Francisco Police Department had yet to analyze the kit. A year after that, the department said her still-unprocessed rape kit had been put in storage and the case labeled ‚Äúinactive.‚Äù It took until November 2012 for the crime lab to analyze the box of evidence collected by the nurse that night, and though the evidence did not get a hit in the statewide DNA database, the results were never uploaded to the FBI‚Äôs national database due to ‚Äúirregularities.‚Äù Marlowe, who believes she was drugged before she was raped by a stranger she met at a city-wide festival, says that today, she has still not received any information about her toxicology or bloodwork.‚Å†
‚Å†
In the years after her rape, she learned that she was not alone. In 2014, the SFPD announced results of an audit which showed there were hundreds of unprocessed rape kits in its possession.‚Å†
‚Å†
In 2016, Marlowe filed a federal civil rights lawsuit against the city, accusing the police department of mishandling sexual assault reports by neglecting to process rape kits, allotting too few resources to sexual violence investigations, and failing to properly train and supervise personnel‚Äîall of which, the lawsuit argued, had a ‚Äúdiscriminatory impact‚Äù on women. Her complaint alleged that the police department‚Äôs delay in testing her kit was part of a larger pattern of treating sexual assault with ‚Äúdeliberate indifference.‚Äù But her case was dismissed by a federal judge, and an appeal was denied by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals. The Supreme Court recently denied a petition to reconsider the ruling.‚Å†
‚Å†
Click the link in our bio to read more about the stunning number of untested rape kits, and about how women's lawsuits attempt to hold police departments accountable for failing sexual assault survivors.‚Å†

PG&E was once part of the climate denial machine that helped fuel California's blackout crisis.‚Å†
‚Å†
Rather than take the chance that its downed power lines would spark another blaze like last year‚Äôs Camp Fire, Pacific Gas and Electric, the largest utility in California, shut off the power for more than 600,000 of its 16 million customers this week.‚Å†
‚Å†
Earlier this year, after the damages of the Camp Fire, PG&E filed for bankruptcy, a move the @wsj called ‚Äúthe first major corporate casualty of climate change.‚Äù The Journal noted: ‚ÄúPG&E has long accepted the science of climate change. It is one of several California utilities that, with prodding from state politicians, has been rapidly shifting to a cleaner energy future.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
PG&E draws far more of its power from renewable energy sources such as hydro, and nuclear than its coal-reliant counterparts. But the utility played a part in propping up climate change denial in the early, pivotal days when the public first learned of the threat.‚Å†
‚Å†
PG&E helped to sow confusion around climate change as an early member of the Global Climate Coalition, which led the successful campaign to stall regulation of greenhouse gas pollution. Working from 1989 to 2002, the Global Climate Coalition represented coal, oil, automakers, manufacturers, and utilities that all had a stake in maintaining the status quo.‚Å†
‚Å†
The broader utility sector‚Äôs work in promoting skepticism around climate change continued, often through the trade group Edison Electric Institute that represents investor-owned utilities. (PG&E is still a member).‚Å†
‚Å†
Edison Electric Institute‚Äôs work today is far more subtle than the early days. In this 1991 ad, for example, it compared concern over warming to ‚ÄúChicken Little‚Äôs hysteria.‚Äù This past year, Edison Electric Institute lobbied California on PG&E‚Äôs behalf, claiming that it is the state‚Äôs responsibility (not the utility‚Äôs) to prevent ‚Äúa future in which electric service is subject to frequent interruption during wildfire season (which may become nearly year-round with climate change).‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†

California now has the nation's strictest private prison ban.‚Å†
‚Å†
In his inaugural address in January, California Gov. Gavin Newsom declared private prisons an ‚Äúoutrage‚Äù and promised to end them ‚Äúonce and for all.‚Äù And last week, he signed the strictest private prison ban in the country, setting the stage for thousands of immigration detainees and prisoners to be transferred out of facilities operated by for-profit corporations.‚Å†
‚Å†
The move comes as major banks are abandoning the private prison industry, Democratic presidential candidates are calling to abolish it, and outrage is mounting over its role in facilitating President Donald Trump‚Äôs hardline immigration policies.‚Å†
‚Å†
Like similar private prison bans in New York, Illinois, Iowa, and Nevada, the California law will prohibit the state‚Äôs corrections department from signing new contracts with private prison companies or extending existing ones. But California‚Äôs version goes further, banning all for-profit detention facilities from operating inside state lines‚Äîincluding four major Immigrations and Customs Enforcement (ICE) detention centers.‚Å†
‚Å†
The law will end the California corrections system‚Äôs experiment with private prisons, which accelerated in 2009 when a federal court ordered the state to reduce dangerous overcrowding in its prison system. As part of its overhaul of its criminal justice system, the state sent some of its prisoners to a handful of private prisons, including facilities in other states. But over the last few years, as the state‚Äôs prison population has fallen, it has gradually moved inmates out of private prisons and into state-operated facilities.‚Å†
‚Å†
But the ban may first have to survive a legal challenge. In July, the state Senate‚Äôs judiciary committee predicted that the Trump administration will sue the state for infringing on federal immigration law and contractual obligations, and it guessed that California would prevail in such a suit.‚Å†

Google's made some generous donations to some of the most notorious climate deniers in Washington‚Äîdespite its insistence that it supports political action on the climate crisis.‚Å†
‚Å†
Among groups the company has listed as beneficiaries of its political giving are more than a dozen organizations that have campaigned against climate legislation, questioned the need for action, or sought to roll back environmental protections.‚Å†
‚Å†
The list includes the Competitive Enterprise Institute, a conservative policy group that was key in the Trump administration's abandonment of the Paris agreement and has criticized the White House for not dismantling more environmental rules.‚Å†
‚Å†
Google is also listed as a sponsor for an upcoming annual meeting of the State Policy Network, an umbrella organization that supports conservative groups including the Heartland Institute, a radical anti-science group that has chided the teenage activist Greta Thunberg for ‚Äúclimate delusion hysterics.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre hardly alone among companies that contribute to organizations while strongly disagreeing with them on climate policy,‚Äù Google's spokesperson said. Amazon has, like Google, also sponsored a CEI gala, according to a program for the event reported in the @nytimes. Google donates to such groups, people close to the company say, to try to influence conservative lawmakers, and‚Äîmost importantly‚Äîto help finance the deregulatory agenda the groups espouse.‚Å†
‚Å†
But environmental activists and other critics say that, for a company that purports to support global action on climate change, such tradeoffs are not acceptable.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt get a pass on it. It ought to be disqualifying to support what is primarily a phony climate denying front group. It ought to be unacceptable given how wicked they have been,‚Äù said Sheldon Whitehouse, a Democratic senator from Rhode Island who is one of the most vocal proponents of climate action in Congress. ‚ÄúWhat all of corporate America should be doing is saying if you are a trade organization or lobby group and you are interfering on climate, we are out. Period,‚Äù he added.‚Å†

Where do our ideas about queerness come from? According to author Hugh Ryan, they stem from what we used to think about pickpockets.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
In January 2011, more than 300 people piled into Ryan‚Äôs loft in Brooklyn. It was a special evening for Ryan. His Pop-Up Museum of Queer History was making its debut. Together with more than 30 exhibit makers, he had curated a makeshift museum that offered a vast exhibit of queer history.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Yet, as history has shown, where queer people congregate, police tend to follow. Among those 300-plus people who filled every corner of his loft? Undercover cops‚Äî14 of them, in Ryan‚Äôs telling. When the clock struck midnight, the event got shut down, thus ending the exhibit‚Äôs life. Briefly. ‚ÄúMy plan beyond this was to clean up and have breakfast,‚Äù Ryan remembers. ‚ÄúBut people were so hungry for it.‚Äù‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Ryan, along with other local curators and queer community leaders, took the pop-up concept around the country, from Philadelphia to Indianapolis. Each new local event, Ryan recalls, was met with ‚Äúan incredible response,‚Äù but when they brought the museum back to Brooklyn, ‚Äúpeople kind of scratched their heads and were like, ‚ÄòQueer history‚Äô?‚Äù‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
That‚Äôs when Ryan realized, ‚ÄúWait, I don‚Äôt know anything about the queer history of Brooklyn, either.‚Äù‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Ryan didn‚Äôt set out to write the book on Brooklyn‚Äôs queer history, but that‚Äôs what happened. ‚ÄúI was like, shit, I gotta do this research, I‚Äôm really just interested,‚Äù he says.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
That book turned out to be "When Brooklyn Was Queer." It opens in 1855 with Walt Whitman, maybe one of Brooklyn‚Äôs most famous queers, and from there Ryan takes the reader through a century of queerness, from Whitman‚Äôs "Leaves of Grass" to what Ryan calls ‚ÄúThe Great Erasure‚Äù in the mid-1900s. ‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Telling a story of people so often lost to the straight-washing of history books, Ryan joined Mother Jones to expand on Brooklyn‚Äôs queer history and dive into the history of sexuality and gender.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä

California has become the first state to require public universities to provide medication abortions.‚Å†
‚Å†
California Gov. Gavin Newsom signed a bill last week requiring the state‚Äôs public universities to offer medication abortions on campus. The new law, which will take effect in 2023, will apply to 34 schools that serve almost 750,000 students.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúFor four years, students have been fighting for a future where reproductive health services, including abortion, are available to all students who need them,‚Äù said Adiba Khan, co-founder of Berkeley Students United for Reproductive Justice.‚Å†
‚Å†
As Mother Jones reported in August 2018, this first-of-its-kind legislation started out as a resolution dreamed up by the UC-Berkeley group Students United for Reproductive Justice. Adiba Khan, one of the group‚Äôs co-founders, told Mother Jones that she and her fellow student activists were inspired to change the lack of abortion services at their university clinic, which otherwise offers ‚Äúcomprehensive reproductive health services.‚Äù At least two pregnant students Khan knew were forced to take time away from work and classes to seek abortion services off campus.‚Å†
‚Å†
Amid a growing legislative assault on abortion rights nationwide, state Sen. Connie Leyva introduced the bill mandating medication abortion provision on campuses for a second time, and California lawmakers again approved the legislation in September, though anti-abortion groups have signaled they will challenge the new law in court.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúIn a time when states across our country are rolling back women‚Äôs health care and access to abortion, California continues to lead the nation to protect every individual‚Äôs right to choose,‚Äù Leyva said. ‚ÄúSB 24 reaffirms the right of every college student to access abortion. By ensuring that abortion care is available on campus, college students will not have to choose between delaying important medical care or having to travel long distances or miss classes or work.‚Äù‚Å†

The Democratic primary no longer revolves around Joe Biden.‚Å†
‚Å†
Since late April, when the former vice president kicked off his campaign with a rally in Pittsburgh, the primary has been the Biden show. He led every national poll for months and was the centerpiece of every debate stage he appeared on. And over the last month, Biden‚Äôs centrality to the race has taken on a new dimension, as the House of Representatives investigates whether President Donald Trump committed an impeachable offense in asking the government of Ukraine to investigate Biden and his son Hunter.‚Å†
‚Å†
But for most of Tuesday‚Äôs debate in Ohio, Biden was largely an afterthought. Instead, Elizabeth Warren‚Äîwho has recently overtaken Biden in a number of polls‚Äîdictated the terms of the debate.‚Å†
‚Å†
Over the first half of the debate she talked twice as much as Biden, and, somewhat relatedly, was also talked about by everyone else. South Bend Mayor Pete Buttigieg went after her on Medicare for All. Minnesota Sen. Amy Klobuchar tried to pick a fight with Warren over the Massachusetts senator‚Äôs proposal for a wealth tax. Hawaii Rep. Tulsi Gabbard twice tried to use her time to get into a one-on-one debate with Warren on foreign policy. California Sen. Kamala Harris tried‚Äîfor a surprisingly long time‚Äîto get Warren to sign onto her letter asking Twitter to delete Trump‚Äôs account. (No dice.)‚Å†
‚Å†
Warren‚Äôs public statements and policy proposals were also the impetus for questions that the moderators directed to other candidates. In a campaign, you make a name for yourself by going after the biggest figure on stage. And for one night at least, there was no bigger figure than Warren.‚Å†
‚Å†
When Warren touted her work in creating the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, Biden was indignant. ‚ÄúI went on the floor and got you votes,‚Äù he said, referring to the law creating the bureau. ‚ÄúI am deeply grateful to President Obama, who fought so hard to make sure that agency was passed into law‚Äù she began, very pointedly. Biden broke into a huge grin at the omission. He‚Äôd been erased from his own administration.‚Å†

A radical approach to helping former prisoners start over: Let them into your home.‚Å†
‚Å†
After serving eight years of a 13-year sentence, London Croudy was released to live in a halfway house in Oakland, California. She had to share a room with several people, and the beds and food were similar to those in prison. ‚ÄúJust pretty much a step over incarceration,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúStill walking around with fear.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
That changed when she met Sabina Crocette, a lawyer who was working at a prisoner-rights nonprofit. They started hanging out, and when Croudy asked Crocette if she knew anyone with an extra room to rent, Crocette remembered a new pilot program she‚Äôd heard about: the Homecoming Project, which pays people with a spare room to house those returning to the community after long prison sentences.‚Å†
‚Å†
Crocette had previously taken in formerly incarcerated people with mixed results, but she‚Äôd connected with Croudy and wanted to try it again. About two months later, Croudy moved in.‚Å†
‚Å†
Croudy tears up remembering the first time she saw her new bedroom in Crocette‚Äôs West Oakland townhouse. Croudy assumed she‚Äôd basically be sleeping on the floor, but after she saw the queen-size bed and dresser dotted with fake candles, ‚Äúthis peace just came over me,‚Äù she says.‚Å†
‚Å†
Few formerly incarcerated people land in such welcoming accommodations, particularly in the Bay Area‚Äôs absurdly overpriced housing market. In Alameda County, where the Homecoming Project operates, 4,800 people returned from state prisons in 2014. About one-quarter of the county‚Äôs residents have a criminal history, and at least 20,000 people‚Äîdisproportionately people of color‚Äîface housing insta¬≠bility because of their records.‚Å†
‚Å†
The Oakland-based nonprofit Impact Justice looked to Airbnb‚Äôs model and flipped it on its head as a way to offer affordable, stable short-term housing. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs hidden assets in our midst, and if we were able to pay the homeowner for housing someone coming home from prison, what would that look like?‚Äù says Terah Lawyer, Homecoming‚Äôs program manager.‚Å†
‚Å†

It didn't take long for the candidates at Tuesday's Democratic presidential debate to call for President Donald Trump's impeachment.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) said that Congress need to impeach Trump in order to ensure the survival of the Constitution. "This is about Donald Trump," she said. "But understand, it's about the next president and the next president and the next president and the future of this country. The impeachment must go forward."‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Sen. Bernie Sanders (D-Vt.) took to superlatives, calling Trump "the most corrupt president in the history of this country."‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
"I think that the House will find him worthy of impeachment because of the emoluments clause," he said. "This is a president who is enriching himself while using the Oval Office to do that, and that is outrageous."‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
It's not just incumbent on the House to impeach Trump, Sanders said. "Mitch McConnell has got to do the right thing and allow a free and fair trial in the Senate."‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Former Vice President Joe Biden said that he agrees, reiterating what he said when House Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced the start of an impeachment inquiry: that he would support impeachment if the White House continued to stonewall Congress. Trump "is the most corrupt president in modern history, and I think all of our history," he said. House Democrats "have no choice but to move."‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Sen. Kamala Harris (D-Calif.) said that, as a former prosecutor, she can tell Trump has shown a "clear consciousness of guilt." She, like Biden and Sanders, referred to Trump as "corrupt."‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
"Our framers imagined this moment, a moment where we would have a corrupt president," she said. "And our framers then rightly designed our system of democracy to say there will be checks and balances. This is one of those moments, and so Congress must act."‚Å†‚†Ä

Elizabeth Warren is calling out Facebook...on Facebook.

Facebook allows politicians to lie in political ads on its platform. Democratic presidential hopeful Elizabeth Warren is calling out Facebook for this reckless policy‚Äîby running Facebook ads with a false statement. ‚ÄúBreaking news: Mark Zuckerberg and Facebook just endorsed Donald Trump for re-election,‚Äù the ad announces, above a picture of Trump and Zuckerberg shaking hands. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre probably shocked, and you might be thinking, ‚Äòhow could this possibly be true?'‚Äù
‚Å†‚†Ä
At this point, Warren‚Äôs campaign, unable to lie for more than two sentences, comes clean. ‚ÄúWell, it‚Äôs not. (Sorry.)‚Äù the ad continues. ‚ÄúBut what Zuckerberg *has* done is given Donald Trump free rein to lie on his platform‚Äîand then to pay Facebook gobs of money to push out their lies to American voters.‚Äù
‚Å†‚†Ä
By letting politicians spread debunked claims, a policy the company announced last month but says is not new, Facebook has opened up a huge loophole for politicians to spread fake news on its platform‚Äîthey just have to pay for it themselves. The Trump campaign was quick to exploit the loophole, running ads with false accusations against former Vice President Joe Biden.

Facebook makes nearly all of its profits from advertising, and political ads are a growing chunk of revenue as the 2020 elections ramp up. In the last year and a half alone, the platform has raked in more than $800 million to run 5.2 million political ads‚Äînumbers that are growing by the day. The Trump campaign has poured more than $20.6 million into Facebook ads in that time frame, spending that has ramped up in recent weeks as Trump faces an impeachment inquiry.

Warren‚Äôs ad presses on the point that Facebook profits when Trump or any other politician turns to its platform to spread false information. ‚ÄúIf Trump tries to lie in a TV ad, most networks will refuse to air it,‚Äù the ad reads. ‚ÄúBut Facebook just cashes Trump‚Äôs checks. Facebook already helped elect Donald Trump once. Now, they‚Äôre deliberately allowing a candidate to intentionally lie to the American people.‚Äù

Columbus Day is dying. Indigenous Peoples Day is the future.
‚Å†‚†Ä
‚ÄúIn 1492, Columbus sailed the ocean blue‚Äù‚Äîand in 2019, a growing number of US cities and states are recognizing that the cutesy rhyme we learned in school, and the federal holiday named in the explorer‚Äôs honor, belies a dark history.

Indigenous people have long resented the holiday, as Columbus‚Äô arrival was the first step in their unfathomable genocide. He and his men enslaved and massacred the indigenous Ta√≠no people, who numbered in the millions upon Columbus‚Äô arrival, and saw their population reduced by as much as 85 percent within a few decades. The brutal colonization of two continents ensued.

The federal holiday, which is always the second Monday in October, plus a bevy of statues and municipal names, continue to glorify Columbus. Yet in recent years, a reevaluation of history has prompted many state and local governments to distance themselves from his legacy.

South Dakota was the first to axe Columbus Day, replacing it with ‚ÄúNative American Day‚Äù in 1989. Two California cities, Berkeley and Santa Cruz, soon followed suit, renaming the second Monday in October as ‚ÄúIndigenous Peoples Day.‚Äù Since 2014, about 100 cities have started observing Indigenous Peoples Day, usually in place of Columbus Day (a few cities celebrate both). Seven states are now on board: Alaska and Oregon enacted the holiday in 2017, and this year, Vermont, Maine, New Mexico, and Washington, DC, joined them. In many places, the Indigenous Peoples Day involves parades, ceremonies, and other displays of Native cultures.

But some Natives point out that celebrating Indigenous Peoples Day isn‚Äôt enough. Critics say that symbolic displays of apology and reconciliation do not put an end to the racism, land grabs, and resource theft that Indigenous people continue to face.

Will the Supreme Court condone the discrimination of LGBTQ people in the workplace?‚Å†
‚Å†
Three cases are being argued in front of the Supreme Court on Tuesday, all of which involve LGBTQ people who say they were fired because of their sexual orientation or gender identity. Aimee Stephens, a trans woman from Michigan, was fired from her job at a funeral home after she informed her boss that she was transitioning and intended to begin dressing according to the company‚Äôs dress code for women. The other two cases, from New York and Georgia, involve gay men who were dismissed after coming out.‚Å†
‚Å†
The ACLU and other advocacy groups are arguing that gay and trans people are protected under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act, which says employers aren‚Äôt allowed to discriminate on the basis of sex, race, color, national origin, or religion. Sexuality and gender identity discrimination, the lawyers say, is a form of sex discrimination. Tuesday‚Äôs oral arguments mark the first time the Court has considered this question.‚Å†
‚Å†
If the court agrees that orientation and gender identity fall under Title VII, all workers, both public and private, would be protected from anti-LGBTQ workplace discrimination. A ruling in the other direction wouldn‚Äôt overturn state employment protection laws, but it could open the door to state-level attacks on LGBTQ people in the workplace.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúThe Trump administration has indicated that it plans to really roll back protections, especially for trans people,‚Äù said Gabriel Arkles, who is on the ACLU team representing Stephens. ‚ÄúAnd so if the Supreme Court rules the wrong way here, then it would really green light that.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Advocates note that the Supreme Court‚Äôs ruling, which is not expected until 2020, might not directly affect most state laws, but could be significant in terms of legal precedent. If the court decides those two categories aren‚Äôt protected under Title VII, federal enforcement directives would also be nullified.‚Å†
‚Å†
Mother Jones breaks it all down for you, and shows you which states have laws in place to protect LGBTQ people no matter what the Supreme Court rules. Click the link in our bio to read more.‚Å†

Ever wonder why your parents don't seem to know how to use emoji? Internet linguist Gretchen McCulloch, author of the new book Because Internet, has answers.‚Å†

Emojis don‚Äôt detract from formal language, McCulloch argues. But McCulloch's book isn't just about emojis. It‚Äôs a field guide for navigating internet language, written by someone who has been charting these waters on her blog since 2012. Thanks to social media and instant messaging, McCulloch explains, internet users are generating unprecedented amounts and varieties of informal writing. Whether we‚Äôre ~signaling irony~ through creative uses of punctuation or LOLing at the bizarre syntactical gymnastics of the latest memes, we‚Äôre contributing to the richness of modern language that McCulloch so delights in.‚Å†

From the moment Chanel Miller woke up in the hospital following her attack, her decision to pursue a criminal case against her rapist inflicted additional harm on her.‚Å†

‚Å†
Driven in part by the knowledge that most sexual assault survivors never get a chance to hold their assailants accountable in court, Miller spent the next year working with police and prosecutors, sticking with the legal process, despite the retraumatization that came along with it. After intense media attention and a 16-day trial, a jury convicted Turner of three counts of felony sexual assault.‚Å†
‚Å†
Judge Aaron Persky sentenced Turner to six months in county jail, probation, and sex offender registration, saying that anything tougher would have a ‚Äúsevere impact‚Äù on the Olympic swimming hopeful. Miller, then known only as Emily Doe, wrote a victim impact statement that went viral after it was published by BuzzFeed News. California changed its laws to impose mandatory prison sentences for sexual assault perpetrators whose victims are unconscious or intoxicated, and voters recalled Persky from the bench.‚Å†
‚Å†
Miller, now 27, tells the story of her life‚Äîand her attempts to piece it back together‚Äîfollowing the now-notorious attack, in her new memoir, "Know My Name."‚Å†
‚Å†
While Miller‚Äôs victim impact statement sparked outrage about Turner‚Äôs brief jail sentence and the deference he received as a white Stanford athlete, the outrage that builds over the course of her book is not directed at Turner, or even Persky, but at a justice system that requires victims to go through hell all over again.‚Å†
‚Å†
Miller‚Äôs experience is largely a story of the system working exactly as it was designed to. Click the link in our bio to read more.‚Å†

Solutions to climate change cannot overlook this key factor: judicial action.‚Å†
‚Å†
In advance of the UN Climate Summit this month, the Global Commission on Adaptation released its first-ever report. But one thing is missing: any mention of judicial action as a means to accelerate adaptation.‚Å†

Courts can act as a powerful accelerant to flame the revolutions‚Äîparticularly in the United States, with its robust independent court system based on precedent. This summer, the Yurok Tribe declared rights of personhood for the Klamath River‚Äîlikely the first for a river in North America.‚Å†
‚Å†
A concept previously restricted to humans (and corporations), ‚Äúrights of personhood‚Äù means that an individual or entity has rights, and they‚Äôre now being extended to nonhumans. With the declaration, the Yurok Tribe joins other Indigenous communities in a growing Rights of Nature movement aimed at protecting the environment.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúBy granting the rights of personhood to the Klamath River, not only does it create laws and legal advocacy routes, but it‚Äôs also an expression of Yurok values,‚Äù says Geneva Thompson, associate general counsel for the tribe and citizen of the Cherokee Nation, who worked on the resolution. ‚ÄúThe idea is that the laws of a nation are an expression of the nation‚Äôs values.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Legal personhood provides a different framework for dealing with problems like pollution, drought, and climate change. The crucial aspect to establishing these legal frameworks, Indigenous lawyers say, involves shifting relationships and codifying Indigenous knowledge‚Äîrecognizing nonhuman entities not as resources, but as rights holders.‚Å†
‚Å†
The Yurok resolution means that if the river is harmed, a case can be made in tribal court to remedy the problem. Currently, says Yurok Tribe General Counsel Amy Cordalis, laws like the Clean Water or Endangered Species acts can be used to protect rivers by addressing symptoms of problems like diseased fish or pollution. But the Yurok resolution seeks to address the river‚Äôs problems directly and holistically, including the impacts of climate change.‚Å†
‚Å†
The resolutions give tribal nations new legal strategies for use in court, especially relating to climate change: ‚ÄúThe idea of having legal avenues to address the harms of climate change is an important next step as legal systems adapt to the climate crisis,‚Äù says Thompson.‚Å†
‚Å†
But it's not just happening here. Click the link in our bio to learn how Indigenous communities around the world are gaining legal personhood for rivers‚Äîand even rice‚Äîto protect them from climate change.‚Å†
(üì∏: Buyenlarge/Getty)‚Å†
‚Å†

Black workers are the heartbeat of the GM strike.

The strike began September 16 after GM failed to reach an agreement with the United Auto Workers. In a general sense, the walkout is an effort by workers to reclaim some of the ground lost over the past dozen years.

In 2009, GM received a $51 billion public bailout after filing for bankruptcy and in short order was flourishing again. Over the past three years the company has raked in $35 billion in North American profits. Its CEO, Mary Barra, has amassed a fortune, making more than $20 million in each of the previous two years, 281 times the median GM worker, the Detroit Free Press reports. And since the bailout, the company has paid almost nothing in federal taxes.

In 2007, following a brief strike by 73,000 UAW members, a much-reviled tiered wage system was installed‚Äîtemp workers earn as little as $15 an hour at the start compared with the $30 an hour or so that so-called ‚Äúlegacy‚Äù workers make.

The wage tiers have awakened the old, overlapping fault lines of race and class within the auto industry. While the demographic breakdown for GM isn‚Äôt known, temporary workers across the American economy are disproportionately black and brown.

Today, temps are completely at GM‚Äôs mercy in countless other ways. As the Detroit Metro Times reports, they can‚Äôt miss more than three pre-approved and unpaid days of work in a given year. they can be forced to work every day‚Äîturning their weekend, a cherished labor victory, into a matter of company whim. But many hope to one day achieve full-time status, and so endure years of uncertainty and rickety economic prospects.

We take you to the front lines of the UAW strike and talk to those leading it. Click the link in our bio to read.
(üì∏: Jeremy Hogan/Zuma)

But Trump‚Äôs alleged Ukrainian shakedown‚Äîand his subsequent, conspiracy-laden handling of the fallout‚Äîhas made it possible for Rose to change his position without really budging from the safety of the middle-of-the-road. ‚Å†

Trump's gag rule from August is already costing women in these states their health care.‚Å†
‚Å†
Since 1970, Title X has been the nation‚Äôs only comprehensive reproductive health care program. In 2018 it served over over four million patients, mostly low-income women who relied on the program for everything from pap smears to IUD‚Äôs.‚Å†
‚Å†
But in August, the Trump administration instituted a ‚Äúdomestic gag rule‚Äù that blocked the nearly 4,000 health care facilities receiving $286 million in Title X funds from performing or even referring patients for abortions. The effects of that rule are already being felt, especially in states where Planned Parenthood has few options to make up for the lost funds.‚Å†
‚Å†
As Mother Jones' reporter Marisa Endicott wrote in August: Title X funding is never used to provide abortion care‚Äîunder the Hyde Amendment, the use of federal funds toward abortion procedures is illegal‚Äîand abortion services account for only 3 percent of Planned Parenthood‚Äôs medical services. But the new policy may jeopardize access to health care for more than 1.5 million low-income women.‚Å†
‚Å†
Planned Parenthood resigned from the program, arguing that it would no longer be able to provide their patients with a full spectrum of care if it remained. Since then, the nation‚Äôs largest single provider of reproductive healthcare for women has been scrambling to make up the difference.‚Å†
‚Å†
In some places, the state government has stepped in to fill the void, ensuring Title X patients are able to receive the full range of care they need. But in states like Iowa and Minnesota, whose state legislatures are dominated by Republican lawmakers, clinics receive no additional state funding and are unable make up the $4 million budget difference.‚Å†
‚Å†
Roughly 60 percent of women who use Title X facilities say it‚Äôs their only source of health care at all. Which means some of the most vulnerable individuals in these states may now be going without medical care of any kind.‚Å†
‚Å†
We dive into how Trump's taking health care away from women around the country. Click the link in our bio to read.‚Å†

Rising sea levels aren't even the scariest part of how climate change is affecting the oceans.‚Å†
‚Å†
Climate change has already taken an irreversible toll on our oceans and frozen places, warns a major new report from the United Nations‚Äô Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.‚Å†
‚Å†
Much of the carbon pollution we‚Äôve pumped into the air has gone directly into the world‚Äôs seas: They have absorbed 90 percent of the excess heat from the atmosphere, warming without pause for the past 50 years. Because oceans are so unfathomably big and complex‚Äîcovering two-thirds of Earth‚Äôs surface‚Äîthat warming has consequences for the entire planet.‚Å†
‚Å†
The IPCC Special Report on Ocean and Cryosphere in a Changing Climate is a collaboration of 130 scientists around the world who have assembled data from more than 7,000 papers. The new report manages to paint an even bleaker picture, showing that the oceans have been expanding, acidifying, and losing oxygen at an accelerated rate.‚Å†
‚Å†
Here's some of what they found:‚Å†
‚Ä¢ The oceans are warming and rising faster than we thought: The seas are rising twice as fast as 20th-century averages. The ocean is also heating up twice as fast, absorbing more carbon and acidifying.‚Å†
‚Ä¢ More than a billion people live in affected areas: Just another 0.3 to 0.4 degrees Celsius of warming will reshape the lives of people who rely on ice or fishing for their livelihoods in low-lying coastal regions, high-mountain areas, and the Arctic.‚Å†
‚Ä¢ We‚Äôre closer than we realized to irreversible melting of permafrost: Even in the best-case scenario for warming, the world‚Äôs permafrost will thaw 25 percent by 2100. Under the more realistic scenarios, it could melt entirely. If that happens, permafrost will release extra methane and carbon that had been frozen for thousands of years‚Äîand those gases further intensify climate change‚Äîcausing more melting.‚Å†
‚Å†
Mother Jones' climate reporter Rebecca Leber breaks down the report's most jaw-dropping finds. Click the link in our bio to read more.‚Å†

We have some bad news about trees: Researchers have found that forests may store far less carbon than we think.‚Å†
‚Å†
Cross-sections of tree trunks, known as stem disks‚Äîor more informally as cookies‚Äîare telling a potentially worrisome tale about the ability of forests to be critical hedges against accelerating climate change. As anyone following the fires burning in the Amazon rainforest knows by now, trees play an important role in helping to offset global warming by storing carbon from atmospheric carbon dioxide‚Äîa major contributor to rising temperatures‚Äîin their wood, leaves, and roots. The worldwide level of CO2 is currently averaging more than 400 parts per million‚Äîthe highest amount by far in the last 800,000 years.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúWhat we‚Äôre suggesting is that internal decay in trees has just not been properly accounted for,‚Äù says Bob Marra, a forest pathologist.‚Å†
‚Å†
The Forest Service estimates that carbon makes up 48 to 50 percent of a tree‚Äôs biomass, so ones with decay will be less dense and therefore hold less carbon. But Marra contends that the visual signs monitored by the Forest Service, such as canopy and tree size, along with conspicuous problems such as lesions or cankers, don‚Äôt accurately reflect internal decay‚Äîa tree that looks healthy may have decay and one that appears problematic may be fine inside.‚Å†
‚Å†
Marra focuses on a technique called tomography (the ‚ÄúT‚Äù in CAT scan). This particular tomography was developed for use by arborists to detect decay in urban and suburban trees, mainly for safety purposes. Marra, however, may be the first to deploy it for measuring carbon content and loss associated with internal decay.‚Å†

‚Å†
Ibram X. Kendi, a black man descended from slaves, raised predominantly in black neighborhoods, and educated at a historically black college, admits he was a racist. In his new book, "How to Be An Antiracist," Kendi combines searing autobiography with pointed analysis to show just how deeply racism is woven into our national‚Äîand global‚Äîfabric. And his first step for combatting bigotry and hatred: dispensing of the term ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not racist.‚Äù‚Å†

‚ÄúThe term ‚Äònot racist‚Äô has been a term of denial,‚Äù Kendi tells host @jamilahking in the latest episode of the Mother Jones podcast. ‚ÄúHow can we be antiracist if we are so convinced that we‚Äôre ‚Äònot racist,‚Äô when to be ‚Äònot racist‚Äô is to fundamentally be in denial of our own racism?‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
According to Kendi, it‚Äôs time to start accepting our own racism so that we can begin working to erase it‚Äîjust as he himself is doing. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm striving each day to be an antiracist, to see the racial groups as equals, to support policies that lead to racial equity,‚Äù he says.‚Å†

In a remarkable display of global collective action, hundreds of thousands of people around the world skipped school and work on Friday to protest the lack of meaningful governmental action against climate change.‚Å†‚†Ä

The Global Climate Strike, a youth-led movement that has partnered with environmental organizations around the world, scheduled the strike to take place three days before the United Nations 2019 Climate Action Summit. The protests began in Australia, where an estimated 100,000 people marched in Melbourne, with 80,000 more marching in Sydney and 30,000 in Brisbane, CNN reports. As Friday dawned in time zones across the world, cities from Mumbai to Nairobi to Berlin joined in what is expected to be the largest day of climate demonstrations in history.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Greta Thunberg, the 16-year-old Swedish activist who first inspired students to skip school to protest climate change in August 2018, will join protestors in New York City, whose public school students were excused from class Friday and encouraged to join in the march.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
In March, Mother Jones environmental reporter Rebecca Leber wrote about what is driving young people like Thunberg to take climate action: "They‚Äôre coming of age when the window to ward off this nightmare scenario is rapidly shrinking. Many older adults have been warning for decades that ‚Äúfuture generations‚Äù will suffer for our selfishness and inertia from continued inaction. Now, those so-called future victims are finding their voice to try and shape the agenda."‚Å†‚†Ä

Bird populations are slowly but steadily dying off, solidifying their status as canaries in the ecological coal mine.‚Å†
‚Å†
The North American bird population has declined by 3 billion, or 27 percent, since 1970, according to an extensive study published Thursday in Science. The authors of the study used population data from bird-watchers and biomass data from weather radars to calculate the decline. A majority of the 529 bird species studied experienced population loss, even species we tend to think of as abundant, such as warblers and blackbirds.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúWe were stunned by the result‚Äîit‚Äôs just staggering,‚Äù Kenneth V. Rosenberg, a conservation scientist at Cornell University and the lead author of the survey, told the New York Times. ‚Å†
‚Å†
In addition to habitat loss, birds are suffering from the widespread use of pesticides, which kills the insects they eat. The study warns that the loss of birds could threaten ecosystems that depend on them as pollinators, predators, and prey, as the Washington Post explains.‚Å†
‚Å†
Still, the populations of some species, like ducks and geese, are increasing thanks to conservation efforts. Other species, like vireos‚Äîsmall, grayish migratory songbirds that live throughout North America‚Äîare increasing as well, though scientists aren‚Äôt exactly sure why. The study was designed to quantify bird populations, but not to explain the factors affecting them.‚Å†
‚Å†
Rosenberg told the Post that decreased pesticide use through sustainable agriculture is one thing that could help restore bird populations.‚Å†

Humans unleash mountains of plastic into the sea each year, and that rate is only accelerating as plastic production grows around the world.‚Å†
‚Å†
The confounding bit is that scientists know little about where all that plastic is ending up‚Äîin gyres like the Great Pacific Garbage Patch, yes, but that‚Äôs just a fraction of the debris released into the ocean each year. When plastic debris end up in the ocean, they break into smaller microplastics, often invisible to the human eye, that swirl in the water column or sink to the bottom of the sea.‚Å†
‚Å†
Two recent studies have backed that up: One sampled water down thousands of feet in Monterey Bay and found particles, while the other took sediment samples off the coast of Southern California and found plastic in layers dating back to the 1940s, when its production began in earnest.
‚Å†
The science of ocean plastic pollution is so new, it‚Äôs still hard to tell what‚Äôs doing the most harm, and what most needs fixing. Macroplastics like single-use bags get into sea turtle stomachs, but microplastics are small enough to embed in organisms like shellfish.‚Å†
‚Å†
Along the coast, you‚Äôll find plastic that‚Äôs typically less than five years old. The plastic they found out at sea, by contrast, is older and more weathered.‚Å†
‚Å†
"The age and the look of plastic in coastal environments versus the plastic that we find in offshore waters is completely different,‚Äù says Laurent Lebreton, chief scientist at Ocean Cleanup and lead author of a new paper in Nature Scientific Reports detailing the research.‚Å†
‚Å†
For all its size and fame, the Garbage Patch might not be our biggest plastic problem. Click the link in our bio to read more.‚Å†

For Matt Bevin, the Trump-loving Republican governor of Kentucky, winning a second term should be a breeze. But Kentuckians are growing tired of their governor‚Äôs unfiltered, Trumpian persona and penchant for generating headlines with ill-advised remarks. ‚Å†

‚Å†

But Bevin‚Äôs biggest mistake may be spending the past two years picking fights with public school teachers. He successfully pushed a law to allow charter schools, saying he wanted to ‚Äúend the monopoly that exists in Kentucky‚Äôs school system,‚Äù and he‚Äôs attempted to weaken pension benefits for public employees. Evidence of possible tax fraud is lying in plain sight on Donald Trump's financial disclosures.‚Å†
‚Å†
Trump owes $50 million to one of his own companies. Tax and financial experts think the loan, which Trump has never fully explained, might be part of a controversial tax avoidance scheme known as debt parking.‚Å†
‚Å†
Yet a Mother Jones investigation has uncovered information that raises questions about the very existence of this loan, presenting the possibility that this debt was concocted as a ploy to evade income taxes‚Äîa move that could constitute tax fraud.‚Å†
‚Å†
Here‚Äôs what is publicly known about this mystery debt: On the personal financial disclosure forms that Trump must file each year as president, he has divulged that he owes ‚Äúover $50 million‚Äù to a company called Chicago Unit Acquisition LLC. The forms note that this entity is fully owned by Trump. In other words, Trump owes a large chunk of money to a company he controls.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt assess any value to it because we don‚Äôt care,‚Äù Trump said of the loan. ‚ÄúI have the mortgage. That is all there is. Very simple. I am the bank.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
The disclosures state that this loan is connected to Trump‚Äôs hotel and tower in Chicago, and the forms reveal puzzling details about Chicago Unit Acquisition: It earns no revenue‚Äîsuggesting that Trump was not paying interest or principal on the loan‚Äîand Trump assigns virtually no value to Chicago Unit Acquisition.‚Å†
‚Å†
Something doesn‚Äôt add up.‚Å†
‚Å†
