Climate change is forcing people to retreat from rising sea levels, wreaking profound effects on the world's coastal communities.‚Å†
‚Å†
In a bold move, Indonesia just found itself a new capital. The country‚Äôs president, Joko Widodo, recently announced that the new seat of government will be on the island of Borneo, hundreds of miles to the northeast of the current capital, Jakarta. The crowded city‚Äôs aquifers have been drained and the ground is caving in, making it one of the fastest sinking cities in the world. The Java Sea threatens to swallow 95 percent of the city over the next 30 years.‚Å†
‚Å†
Retreating from coastlines and riversides might have once been considered unthinkable. But across the world, it‚Äôs already happening‚Äîin Australia, Colombia, Vietnam, and here in the United States.‚Å†
‚Å†
An overheating planet and unchecked development along the coasts have let the sea expand into new territory, leaving many people who live along the shores unsettled. According to the United Nations, up to 1 billion people could be displaced by storms, droughts, and floods in 30 years. In the United States, the cost for protecting people and property from rising seas and intense downpours is expected to climb into the hundreds of billions of dollars in the coming decades‚Äîand that‚Äôs a conservative estimate.‚Å†
‚Å†
There‚Äôs ‚Äúan ongoing mass migration‚Äù away from our coasts, said Elizabeth Rush, author of the Pulitzer Prize‚Äìnominated book "Rising: Dispatches from the New American Shore." ‚ÄúThese changes will happen whether we like it or not,‚Äù Rush said. ‚ÄúHow profoundly and how detrimentally they reshape our coastal communities is up to us.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†

But the book also revisits the story Goldberg has told about her own origins, that after being stalked by a ‚Äúpsycho ex,‚Äù she became the lawyer that she desperately needed. Mother Jones called Goldberg to talk about the decision to share her own story, her battles against little men and Big Tech, and the differences between living in fear and staying vigilant. Click the link in our bio to read more.‚Å†

One day after another mass shooting in Texas, new gun laws that expand gun access went into effect this week.‚Å†
‚Å†
After a gunman killed seven people and wounded 20 others in Midland and Odessa, Texas‚Äînearly a dozen new laws vastly expand where individuals can bring their guns, including school parking lots, foster homes, churches, and rental properties. But instead of making it harder to obtain guns, the Texas legislature pushed the ‚Äúgood guy with a gun‚Äù narrative, which holds that someone else with a gun is the best equipped to stop a shooter.‚Å†
‚Å†
At the NRA convention in 2018 in Dallas, Abbott proposed a solution for gun violence plaguing his state. ‚ÄúThe answer to gun violence is not to take guns away. The answer is to strengthen the Second Amendment rights of law-abiding citizens,‚Äù he said during a speech. ‚ÄúThe problem is not guns, it‚Äôs hearts without God.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Texas already had some of the least restrictive gun laws in the country, and now, after two mass shootings in one month, gun laws will be even more relaxed. Click the link in our bio to read more.‚Å†

Protesters in Brazil are demanding action on the Amazon fires.‚Å†
‚Å†
Last Friday, in the streets outside the government buildings in Brazil‚Äôs capital city, a swarm of people took over Brasilia, protesting in Brazilian/carnival style. People screamed, danced, and sang, led by a giant banner that read ‚ÄúAmaz√¥nia fica, Bolsonaro sai‚Äù (‚Äúthe Amazon stays, Bolsonaro goes‚Äù).‚Å†

But it wasn‚Äôt a time to celebrate, and the mood wasn‚Äôt entirely jovial. Protesters fired smoke bombs outside the Ministry of the Environment, screaming ‚ÄúSai Salles‚Äù (Get out Salles), referring to Ricardo Salles, Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro‚Äôs environment minister.‚Å†

Young or old, the entire crowd shared the same concern: Bolsonaro doesn‚Äôt care about the environment, he doesn‚Äôt care about the Amazon, and he doesn‚Äôt care about indigenous people‚Äôs constitutionally protected and internationally recognized rights.‚Å†
‚Å†
The president campaigned on pledges to stop the demarcation of indigenous lands, sell large parts of the Amazon rainforest to mining and agribusiness, discredit scientific data pointing to a drastic increase in deforestation in recent years, and cut back on environmental protection and regulation measures. ‚Å†
It‚Äôs not a new phenomenon for a Brazilian government to take a pro-industry stance‚Äîthe country is, after all, the biggest exporter of beef in the world‚Äîbut in recent memory, no other president has taken such bold measures against indigenous rights and the environment.‚Å†

While Tropical Storm Dorian skirted Puerto Rico's coast, sparing it of major damage, it raised attention to how the island is still in recovery mode‚Äîand ill-equipped for another natural disaster.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Hurricane Irma struck Puerto Rico in early September 2017. Two weeks later, Hurricane Maria made landfall in the municipality of Yabucoa. When the debris settled, almost 3,000 people were dead, thousands more were displaced, and the island‚Äôs already aging infrastructure was severely weakened.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
The island‚Äôs antiquated power grid, which had been neglected for years, took an especially hard blow. Immediately after the storm, at least 1.5 million people were left without electricity, some for almost a year, casting the island into the longest blackout in US history.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
As Puerto Ricans prepare themselves for another hurricane season, under shifting local leadership and in a world with increasingly unstable weather, swipe through for five numbers that highlight just how vulnerable Hurricane Maria left the island, and click the link in our bio for a breakdown of each.‚Å†‚†Ä

Walmart will no longer sell ammunition for handguns and certain types of short-barrel rifle, the company announced Tuesday.‚Å†
‚Å†
The retail giant made its decision in response to a shooting that killed 22 people in its El Paso store last month. In a memo sent to employees, CEO Doug McMillon cited additional shootings in Dayton, Ohio and Midland and Odessa, Texas as factors in his decision.‚Å†
‚Å†
"We want what‚Äôs best for our customers, our associates and our communities. In a complex situation lacking a simple solution, we are trying to take constructive steps to reduce the risk that events like these will happen again. The status quo is unacceptable."‚Å†

In 2015, facing mounting public pressure, Walmart stopped selling military-style assault rifles. With yesterday's announcement, the nation's largest retailer has gone a step further. "After selling through our current inventory commitments, we will discontinue sales of short-barrel rifle ammunition such as the .223 caliber and 5.56 caliber that, while commonly used in some hunting rifles, can also be used in large capacity clips on military-style weapons; We will sell through and discontinue handgun ammunition." The company will also stop selling handguns entirely in Alaska. (Walmart stopped selling handguns in the rest of the US in 1993.)‚Å†

It was late November 2017, and Matthew Bowen, a veteran Border Patrol agent, was seething. A fellow Border Patrol agent in Texas had just been found dead in the field, and Bowen was certain someone who‚Äôd been crossing the border illegally was responsible for murdering him.‚Å†

‚Å†
Two weeks later, Bowen climbed behind the wheel of a Border Patrol pickup truck and used it to strike a Guatemalan migrant in a dusty parking lot in southern Arizona. Click the link in our bio to read more about Bowen's hate-filled career and the crime that finally ended it.‚Å†

They were almost wiped out, but now Atlantic puffins are prospering and pairing up nonstop.‚Å†
‚Å†
They‚Äôre increasingly vulnerable, threatened by warming oceans, predators, and a fluctuating food supply. ‚Å†

The puffins, once hunted by people, had nearly disappeared from the Maine coast before a program to reintroduce them began in the 1970s. Since then, more than 500 Audubon Society interns have helped out in the summers as the colonies have grown, Kress told NPR. The most important lesson, he said: People can nearly kill a species‚Äîbut they can also help bring it back.‚Å†

‚Å†

Trump's businesses could save MILLIONS if the Federal Reserve cuts interest rates.‚Å†
‚Å†
In recent months, Donald Trump has repeatedly attacked the Federal Reserve and its chairperson, Jerome Powell, for setting interest rates higher than Trump would like. ‚ÄúThe only problem we have is Jay Powell and the Fed,‚Äù the president tweeted last Wednesday. ‚ÄúBig U.S. growth if he does the right thing, BIG CUT ‚Äì but don‚Äôt count on him! So far he has called it wrong, and only let us down.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Trump pretty clearly sees recent economic turmoil‚Äîmuch of which he has caused by provoking a trade war with China‚Äîas a major threat to his reelection bid. He‚Äôs hoping the Fed can juice the economy enough for him to win a second term. But as the Washington Post reported Saturday, Trump may have an ulterior motive. It turns out that his businesses could save millions of dollars in interest payments if rates fall:‚Å†
‚Å†
"He has already benefited from falling interest rates that were spurred in part by a cut the Federal Reserve announced in July, the first in more than a decade‚Äîand his payments could drop by millions of dollars more annually if the central bank grants Trump‚Äôs wish and further lowers short-term rates, experts said."‚Å†
‚Å†
When Trump became president, he refused to divest from his vast array of business ventures‚Äîdespite the obvious conflicts of interest they pose. His hotels and clubs have continued raking in money from foreign officials (though the Trump Organization says it donates these profits), and he‚Äôs threatened to impose tariffs on wine imports that compete with his winery. Nearly 37,000 Louisianians who have recently had their voting rights restored by the state legislature are joining a potential wave of new voters from across the country.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
While little is known about the political leanings of formerly incarcerated people, many political observers assume they would vote for Democrats. For one thing, black adults are four times more likely to be barred from voting because of felony disenfranchisement laws, according to the @endlifeimprisonment. And black voters have consistently favored Democrats. But these assumptions could be overblown.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
People who are formerly incarcerated must overcome daunting hurdles, both personal and administrative, in order to vote. In Florida, newly eligible voters have to pay outstanding fines and fees before registering, which critics say is akin to a poll tax. In Louisiana these potential voters are consumed by the struggle to rebuild their lives after prison.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
But they must also combat the apathy born of their ordeals: In interviews, several formerly incarcerated people said they were not sure that elected officials can make a difference in their lives. In order of appearance, here's what they have to say:‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Lionel Paul Dugas, 45, New Iberia: "State prisons will eat you inside out. When I say I came out with nothing, I mean I really didn‚Äôt have nothing.‚Äù‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Charles Blue, 42, Shreveport: ‚ÄúWhen something is taken away from you, you regret the fact that you want to use it but you can‚Äôt. You are trying to connect with people who at so many points don‚Äôt see the value."‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Detric Linner, 41, Shreveport: ‚ÄúI feel like [politicians] all have their own personal agendas they are trying to push. Right now, I am just trying to be obedient to the laws so I can stay free."‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Patrice Sparks, 36, Shreveport: ‚ÄúNobody explained anything to us."‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Clint Williams, 58, New Orleans: ‚ÄúThere are senators and lawyers and doctors and everyday men, I know these people and I support them and I want my voice to matter.‚Äù‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Click the link in our bio to read more.‚Å†‚†Ä

Fishermen don't know how to stop hordes of hungry sea lions from stealing their catch, and now, their option seems to be illegally shooting them.‚Å†
‚Å†
West Coast fishermen from California to Alaska use "seal bombs" to scare away seals and sea lions trying to steal their catch, including squid, anchovies and salmon. These 3-inch explosives create a blast comparable to that of a small stick of dynamite, and once thrown overboard, the bombs detonate below the water‚Äôs surface, producing a noise that can travel for over 40 miles underwater. But according to fishermen, they're highly ineffective.‚Å†
‚Å†
Interviews with fishermen and marine biologists and a review of studies reveal that seal bombs are unsuccessful at scaring sea lions away from fishing nets. And the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the federal agency in charge of handling nuisance sea lions, knows that seal bombs are ineffective. Yet the agency continues to enforce its policy against lethal deterrents, leaving fishermen with few options other than to illegally kill sea lions or watch the animals gobble up their valuable catch.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúThis is our livelihood. This is what we do to pay our bills and help our families,‚Äù said commercial fishermen Clark Walker, who works on the a large commercial fishing boat, Merva W. ‚ÄúIf they leave us with no resources, we‚Äôre screwed.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
There is growing concern over whether the bombs pose a significant risk to other marine life, both directly, by hitting animals, and indirectly, by blasting loud noises, researchers say. The noise ripples out into a marine ecosystem filled with animals that rely on underwater sounds to find their next meal.‚Å†
‚Å†
What‚Äôs more, research across the West Coast indicates that these explosions are only somewhat effective in fending off sea lions. Click the link in our bio to read more.‚Å†
(üì∏: Caters News/ZUMA)‚Å†

Two weeks after a mass shooting at Gilroy, California‚Äôs annual garlic festival in late July, the mayor of San Jose proposed a radical plan to address gun violence: Require all firearm owners to own liability insurance.‚Å†
‚Å†
Under a local ordinance that Mayor Sam Liccardo proposed earlier this month, residents of San Jose who own a gun would be required to either have firearm liability insurance or, if they can‚Äôt obtain that insurance, possibly pay a per-household fee to help cover taxpayer costs of gun violence‚Äîsuch as emergency medical response and hospital treatment fees‚Äîby creating a ‚Äúpublic compensation pool.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
According to the ordinance, which needs the approval of the San Jose city council to become law, mandatory liability insurance would cover both the accidental discharge of a gun and intentional acts of harm by third parties ‚Äúwho steal, borrow, or otherwise acquire the gun.‚Äù But insurers would not be responsible for covering the liability of a policyholder for their ‚Äúown intentional conduct.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
The proposed ordinance also includes other measures to help curb gun violence, including a proposal to explore imposing a gun and ammunition tax, and a consent-to-search program that, similar to red flag laws in some states around the country, would enable parents to allow law enforcement to search and seize for weapons owned by their dependents. The ordinance also proposes exploring the implementation of a bounty program that would offer cash rewards to people who tip off police to illegal guns.‚Å†
‚Å†
But getting it passed may prove to be riskier than it sounds. California is known for having some of the strictest gun laws in the country, but nearly all of them have been challenged in court. Eric Ruben, a weapons law and Second Amendment expert at the Brennan Center for Justice, doesn‚Äôt think requiring liability insurance for gun owners would be a violation of the Second Amendment in principle, but he says if it‚Äôs not written carefully, it could present a tricky case for the courts.‚Å†
‚Å†
Click the link in our bio to read.‚Å†

This week marked the 23rd anniversary of welfare reform, a law that ripped a hole in the nation‚Äôs safety net under the guise of encouraging personal responsibility among poor families.‚Å†
‚Å†
Very few eligible families now receive cash benefits compared with 23 years ago. The nonpartisan Center on Budget and Policy Priorities estimates that the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families program could be serving 2.5 million more families living below the poverty line than it does now.‚Å†
‚Å†
The reason for that large drop? Congress passed legislation in 1996 to eliminate the old Aid to Families with Dependent Children program, which provided cash benefits mostly to single mothers in poverty. But by the mid-1990s, it had become hugely controversial and plagued with false, racist stereotypes about layabout welfare recipients supposedly living large on the public dime.‚Å†
‚Å†
With a seal of approval from President Bill Clinton, the GOP-controlled Congress replaced AFDC with TANF, which gave states a fixed amount of funding, regardless of how many people were on the welfare rolls or how high the unemployment rate went. States took the opportunity to drop millions of families from the welfare rolls, all while keeping the federal money.‚Å†
‚Å†
States today spend only about a quarter of their TANF budgets on cash assistance to help families buy diapers, keep the lights on, and avoid evictions. The rest of the money goes into other things, including anti-abortion crisis pregnancy centers, abstinence-only sex education, and the foster care system‚Äîthe very place where welfare benefits were supposed to keep kids out of.‚Å†
‚Å†
In November, President Donald Trump issued an executive order demanding that federal agencies review their welfare policies and find ways to crack down. ‚ÄúOur country still struggles from nearly record high welfare enrollments,‚Äù White House adviser Andrew Bremberg said when the order was issued. ‚ÄúPart of President Trump‚Äôs effort to create a booming American economy includes moving Americans from welfare to work.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Click the link in our bio for more.‚Å†
(üì∏: J. Scott Applewhite/AP)‚Å†

A federal judge just blocked Missouri's abortion ban from taking effect.‚Å†
‚Å†
In May, Missouri passed a law banning abortion after eight weeks gestation, with no exceptions for rape or incest. The law, which includes exceptions for medical emergencies, criminalizes physicians who perform abortions after eight weeks of gestation‚Äîbefore many women know they are pregnant. ‚Å†
‚Å†
After Missouri‚Äôs Republican Gov. Mike Parson signed the bill into law, Planned Parenthood and the ACLU sued the state, calling its attempt to challenge Roe v. Wade unconstitutional. A day before the law was scheduled to go into effect, US District Judge Howard Sachs put it on hold to allow the legal proceedings to unfold, the AP reports.‚Å†
‚Å†
This means that, for now, obtaining an early-term abortion in Missouri is still legal.‚Å†

‚ÄúSadly, when Americans think about a burrito, they think about the Chipotle burrito,‚Äù says writer Gustavo Arellano on our latest episode of Bite. ‚ÄúThis Chipotle burrito is now eradicating all these burrito cultures across the United States, created by Mexican Americans, for Mexican Americans in their communities, and now they‚Äôre in danger of disappearing.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Steve Ells opened the first Chipotle Mexican Grill in Denver in 1993. Ells modeled the restaurant off of the taquer√≠as he frequented while working at the former San Francisco restaurant, Stars. By turning tortilla-wrapped proteins and rice into a fast-casual empire, Chipotle ‚Äútook a known commodity among Mexicans that suddenly turned trendy in the hands of white Americans, for white Americans,‚Äù Arellano wrote in an essay for Eater last April.‚Å†
‚Å†
But rather than expose everyone to the vast universe of different styles of burritos, Chipotle has instead convinced everyone that there‚Äôs only one type of the dish: the overstuffed, under-spiced Mission-style behemoth. As a result, the masses are being deprived of burritos like Denver‚Äôs ‚ÄúMexican hamburger,‚Äù a burrito bursting with chicharrones (fried pork skins) and refried beans, topped with a hamburger patty, and covered in orange chili or El Paso, Texas‚Äôs guisado burritos, a small, flavorful burrito filled with stewed vegetables and meats.‚Å†
‚Å†
Lucky for us, Arellano has some delicious ideas for how we can bring these burritos back. Listen on our latest episode. Link in bio!‚Å†

Look no further than Brazil's Amazon fire for the dangers of deregulation.‚Å†
‚Å†
Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro took power this year promising to open the Amazon rainforest to industry, roll back environmental and indigenous protections, and stack his Cabinet with ideologues who dismiss climate change as a Marxist hoax.‚Å†
‚Å†
But the record wildfires now raging in the Amazon offer a terrifying rebuke and serve as a stark reminder of what‚Äôs at stake as Bolsonaro‚Äôs policies allow ranchers, loggers, and miners to destroy the world‚Äôs largest forest and repository of carbon dioxide at an unprecedented pace.‚Å†
‚Å†
The disaster eerily paralleled the historic storms and wildfires that rocked the United States in 2017, just as President Donald Trump‚Äîto whom Bolsonaro is often compared‚Äîbegan his assault on environmental regulations and announced plans to withdraw from the Paris climate accord.‚Å†
‚Å†
Fires are common in the Amazon during the region‚Äôs dry season, but this year has not been drier or windier than normal, experts have said, meaning many of the outbreaks have likely come from ranchers and farmers. And environmental advocates have pointed to rapid destruction of the forest as the driver in the spread of the flames.‚Å†
‚Å†
The right-wing president who relied on the backing of influential agribusiness interests to win election in 2018 has loosened or attempted to eliminate environmental protections over the Amazon, and Brazil is now felling trees at a rate of roughly one soccer field per minute.‚Å†
‚Å†
The move was only one of Bolsonaro‚Äôs most brazen. Click the link in our bio to read how Bolsonaro is changing Brazil.‚Å†
(üì∏: Mauro Pimentel//Getty)‚Å†

On Monday, Trump continued his longheld campaign to readmit Russia to the G7, arguing that having the Kremlin ‚Äúinside the tent‚Äù rather than outside would strengthen the world‚Äôs security.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúA lot of people say having Russia, which is a power, having them inside the room is better than having them outside the room,‚Äù Trump told reporters at a press conference from the G7 summit in Biarritz, France. ‚ÄúBy the way, there were numerous people during the G7 that felt that way. We didn‚Äôt take a vote or anything but we did discuss it.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
The president continued by again mischaracterizing the events that lead to Russia‚Äôs expulsion, claiming that the 2014 decision came after former President Barack Obama was supposedly frustrated that Vladimir Putin had ‚Äúoutsmarted‚Äù him in the region. That, of course, is not true: a majority of countries in the group, including the US, booted Russia to protest the illegal annexation of Crimea.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúPresident Obama was not happy that this happened because it was embarrassing to him, and he wanted Russia to be out of what was called the G8,‚Äù Trump said. ‚ÄúHe was outsmarted by Putin, he was outsmarted. President Putin outsmarted President Obama.‚Äù‚Å†

The remarks follow a statement from European Council President Donald Tusk on Saturday when he categorically rejected the suggestion to invite Russia back. ‚ÄúUnder no condition can we agree with this logic,‚Äù Tusk said in a press conference.‚Å†
‚Å†
The criticism does not appear to have dimmed the president‚Äôs enthusiasm. Asked if he would welcome Putin to next year‚Äôs summit, which Trump is hosting, Trump told reporters on Monday said that he would ‚Äúcertainly‚Äù extend an invite. ‚ÄúWhether or not he could come psychologically, I think that‚Äôs a tough thing for him to do.‚Äù‚Å†

@elizabethwarren wants to reduce gun violence‚Äîby 80 percent.‚Å†
‚Å†
The deadly shootings in Dayton, Ohio, and El Paso, Texas, catapulted gun violence to the forefront of the Democratic presidential primary. ‚ÄúWe might not know how to get all the way there yet,‚Äù Warren wrote in a post on @medium, where she has laid out most of her campaign‚Äôs policy proposals. ‚ÄúBut we‚Äôll start by implementing solutions that we believe will work.‚Äù ‚Å†
‚Å†
Like many of her Democratic rivals, Warren supports an assault weapons ban and universal background checks before gun purchases, but her plan also would hike taxes on gun manufacturers, establish a federal licensing system for gun owners, set a uniform, one-week waiting period for purchases, bar anyone convicted of a hate crime from owning guns, and support urban-intervention programs.‚Å†
‚Å†
Warren‚Äôs most ambitious ideas, such as raising tax rates by 30 percent on guns and 50 percent on ammunition, would require congressional approval, but other solutions detailed in her plan would not. She proposes signing executive orders to raise the minimum age for gun purchasers to 18, crack down on gun trafficking across state lines, and reverse Trump administration rules that have allowed weapons to be modified in ways that evade legal restrictions.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúThe next president has a moral obligation to use whatever executive authority she has to address the gun crisis,‚Äù Warren wrote. ‚ÄúBut it is obvious that executive action is not enough.‚Äù Click the link in our bio to read more about Warren's latest plan.‚Å†

Michigan Democrat Rashida Tlaib has clearly gotten under the skin of President Trump, who has frequently attacked the first-term congresswoman in starkly racist terms and even lobbied Israel to block her from visiting the country.‚Å†
‚Å†
Now Tlaib says she knows why: He‚Äôs afraid.‚Å†
‚Å†
In a recent conversation with the @guardian_us, billed as her first in-depth interview since the cancellation of her Israel trip, Tlaib said, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been very clear to me, especially this last week, that he‚Äôs scared of us.‚Äù She continued, ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs afraid of women of color‚Ä¶because we‚Äôre not afraid of him and we‚Äôre not afraid to speak up and say that we have a white supremacist in the White House who has a hate agenda.‚Äù‚Å†

Koalas are starving and the key to saving them might be their poop.‚Å†
‚Å†
A few years ago, koalas were literally dropping dead off tree branches in Cape Otway, Australia. The furry, cute marsupials were dying because, free of fur-trade hunters, the koala numbers there boomed‚Äîfrom 75 individuals in 1981 to nearly 8,000 in 2013‚Äîand the increased population actually depleted the koalas‚Äô favorite food source. The manna gum trees, a species of eucalyptus, were stripped clean of leaves. More than 70 percent of the koalas would starve to death or be euthanized by wildlife officials who had deemed them too weak to survive.‚Å†
‚Å†
The odd thing was, it didn‚Äôt seem like they had to starve. There was another food source available to the koalas on Cape Otway: a species of eucalyptus tree called messmate. In fact, other koalas there actually prefer messmate to manna gum and spend their entire lives eating it. But the manna-gum-preferring koalas, rather than adapt to a new food source, just died.‚Å†
‚Å†
There was no real understanding of why‚Äîand no way to help the koalas adapt.‚Å†
‚Å†
But a study published Tuesday in the journal Animal Microbiome may have found a way to help these koalas change their diets and survive. Australian researchers reveal they‚Äôve performed the first-ever fecal transplants on a small group of koalas, which resulted in the individuals finally eating their non-preferred food source‚Äîsuggesting the refusal to eat certain leaves is not random, but the result of gut bacteria.‚Å†
‚Å†
Click the link in our bio to read more about how koalas' own poop could help them adapt their diets to new food sources as they are threatened by habitat loss, climate change, and other forces.‚Å†
‚Å†(üì∏: Mosebach, K/Zuma)

Former press secretary Sean Spicer will do anything to get back on TV, even if that means humiliating himself.‚Å†
‚Å†
Reality television came to the rescue for Donald Trump when his real estate empire was in shambles and his reputation downgraded to a punchline in the early 2000s. On NBC's The Apprentice, a man who had lost more than a billion dollars, according to his tax returns, played the role of the ultimate business success story.‚Å†
‚Å†

Still more new laws will make it easier for gun owners to store firearms and ammunition in foster homes, and prevent landlords from banning guns on rental property. For a full week after natural disasters, it will no longer be a crime for Texans to carry handgun a without a license.‚Å†

Anti-immigrant ideology has been part of American conservationism since the first national park was founded, in part to keep white-owned nature away from Mexicans and Native Americans. Racist myths of national "purity" and natural "purity" were inextricably linked.‚Å†
‚Å†
The current rise of eco-minded white supremacy follows a direct line from the powerful attorney, conservationist, and eugenicist Madison Grant‚Äîa friend of trees, Teddy Roosevelt, and the colonial claims of superiority by white land stewardship. Grant, along with the influential naturalist John Muir and other early Anglo-Saxon conservationists, was critical in keeping the country‚Äôs lands for white enjoyment.‚Å†
‚Å†
Muir, who founded the Sierra Club environmental group in 1892, was disturbed by the purported ‚Äúuncleanliness‚Äù of Native Americans, whom he wanted removed from Yosemite. Grant successfully lobbied for the creation of protected national parks and the restriction of immigration by nonwhite people.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúEnvironmentalists were hardcore eugenicists. They were as committed to racial thinking as they were to protecting the great redwoods in California,‚Äù said Heidi Beirich, intelligence project director at the Southern Poverty Law Center.‚Å†
‚Å†

Trump's reviving a 19th-century scheme to block poor immigrants from the US.‚Å†
‚Å†
In 1882, four decades before the creation of the Border Patrol, the United States established one of its first ways of keeping out poor immigrants. ‚Å†
Last Monday, the Trump administration revived the public charge rule to keep out working-class immigrants who now disproportionately come from Mexico and Central America. The new rule, which goes into effect in October, could block hundreds of thousands of immigrants from receiving green cards by making them ineligible for permanent legal status if immigration officers decide they‚Äôre likely to use modest amounts of government assistance.‚Å†
‚Å†
The plan has the potential to be the Trump administration‚Äôs most dramatic restriction on legal immigration.‚Å†
‚Å†
The original public charge rule grew out of a nativist backlash against Irish immigrants. In later decades, it went on to target the new populations from Eastern and Southern Europe arriving in large numbers. Now, the rule is being as a weapon in a new nativist backlash against Latinos.‚Å†
‚Å†
But immigrants applying for green cards, which provide permanent legal status and a path to citizenship, are already barred from receiving most government assistance. As a result, the new rule would rarely block people from getting green cards because of benefits they‚Äôve already used. Click the link in our bio for more.‚Å†

Photographer @jimmyfike thinks often of the stories his grandmother liked to tell him, in a lively Southern drawl, about her early days on a farm in rural Alabama.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
She hunted for wild game and picked persimmons, filberts, and blackberries for cobblers. So far, he‚Äôs photographed between 140 and 150 edible plants native or common to communities across 15 states. He isn‚Äôt a botanist, so he trusts his instincts and consults field guides to determine which ones are edible. ‚ÄúYou learn as you go,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúReally look at stuff closely, get to know it, and invariably stuff we‚Äôre surrounded by is edible, useful, medicinal. It‚Äôs got a reason to be here.‚Äù‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Once he chooses a plant, Fike carefully digs it up, cleans it, and takes it back to the studio, where he pins it to a white backdrop, quickly arranging the plant to showcase its distinct features before it wilts. The Title X Family Planning program has been around since 1970, and as the government describes it, it‚Äôs ‚Äúdesigned to provide access to contraceptive services, supplies, and information to all who want and need them.‚Äù But those services, and information on reproductive care, soon won‚Äôt include abortion.‚Å†

The new rule is expected to cut up to $60 million from Planned Parenthood‚Äôs operating budget. ‚ÄúIf,‚Äù Planned Parenthood said in a call to action against the gag rule, ‚ÄúTrump wanted to roll back access to birth control and sexual and reproductive care‚Äîwhich he‚Äôs made clear time and time again‚Äîthen launching an all-out attack on the nation‚Äôs Title X program is a surefire way to do that.‚Äù Click the link in our bio for more.‚Å†

We started counting calories more than 120 years ago. It was a terrible idea.‚Å†
‚Å†
In a series of experiments, a scientist named Wilbur Atwater started meticulously counting calories by setting fire to hundreds of foods and measuring the released energy. In another experiment, he and his team planted a grad student in an airtight ‚Äúroom calorimeter‚Äù and passed him portions of bread and beans and determined how much heat, carbon dioxide, and waste he generated. To this day, when the food industry lists calories on labels, as required by federal law, it often relies on Atwater‚Äôs calculations.‚Å†
‚Å†
Atwater‚Äôs work helped give rise to the nutritional dogma that your body weight is governed by whether you burn off all the calories you eat. But recent research challenges this belief.‚Å†
‚Å†
The scientists during Atwater‚Äôs era saw the human digestive system as a single engine producing a predictable quantity of energy from a given amount of fuel. Yet the human gut contains a multitude of engines, and they interact with each other in ways science is just beginning to unravel. Over the past 15 years, a fast-growing body of literature suggests that the gut microbiome‚Äîthe trillions of microbes that live inside us‚Äîshapes the way we metabolize food and may play an important role in how we gain weight.‚Å†
‚Å†
Click the link in our bio to read more about the gut microbiome and how understanding it can help us develop better ways to maintain a healthy weight.‚Å†

What if our courts treated young sex trafficking victims like Cyntoia Brown as people, not perpetrators?‚Å†
‚Å†
Enter the STAR Court‚ÄîSucceeding Through Achievement and Resilience‚Äîa groundbreaking program for sex trafficking victims under 18, and those at risk of being trafficked, who have gotten caught up in the legal system for crimes like robbery or assault. Pratt often attends their high school graduations and gives Walmart or grocery store gift cards to girls who are trying to get back on their feet after having every aspect of their lives controlled by a pimp. ‚ÄúWhat can we do for you?‚Äù is a common question from Pratt. If girls fulfill the conditions Pratt sets‚Äîgoing to school, getting a job, staying out of trouble‚Äîtheir criminal records may be wiped clean.‚Å†

Pratt created the court in 2012 based on the premise that children who have been sold for sex aren‚Äôt like other juvenile defendants, and that the trauma of their experiences should be taken into account when considering their cases.‚Å†

The story of how AMI came under scrutiny by the feds as a possible agent of Saudi influence is a dizzying saga of Trumpian proportions, featuring a cast of characters that includes the world‚Äôs richest man, a Saudi leader who has forged deep ties to the Trump administration, and an embattled media baron with a reputation for using his flagship tabloid to protect his allies and punish his enemies. Planting trees is good, but eliminating deforestation is better.‚Å†
‚Å†
Every year, an estimated 15 billion trees are chopped down across the planet to make room for agricultural and urban lands and other uses. We‚Äôve cut down so many that what‚Äôs left is about half of the number of trees that the Earth supported before the rise of human civilization, and scientists warn that it‚Äôs not helping our climate.‚Å†
‚Å†
Planting more trees is one way to offset deforestation. But now, a report from the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change finds that to have a shot at combatting the climate crisis, we‚Äôll need to cut down fewer trees.‚Å†
‚Å†
Global deforestation is a major source of greenhouse gas emissions. As a Mother Jones reporter explains: "The way we eat, farm, and cut down forests contributes in a major way to the climate problem. Deforestation, agriculture, and other land use are already responsible for 23 percent of the rise in human-caused greenhouse gases, and agriculture is responsible for 44 percent of methane emissions."‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúWe cannot plant trees to get ourselves out of the problem that we‚Äôre in,‚Äù Pamela McElwee, a professor of human ecology at Rutgers University and an author on the report, said. ‚ÄúThe trade-offs that would keep us below 1.5 degrees, we‚Äôre not talking about them. We‚Äôre not ready to confront them yet.‚Äù‚Å†

On a Monday in July, the phones of 16,800 New Yorkers near Chinatown lit up with a push notification reading, ‚ÄúMan Stabbed in Park.‚Äù Another 51,700 people were notified of a ‚ÄúMan Slashed‚Äù in the Bronx. On the Upper West Side, 13,500 people were alerted that a Chase Bank had been robbed.‚Å†

The notifications, sent from a mobile app called Citizen, can create the impression that the city is teeming with errant slashers and other dangerous criminals. But crime rates in New York have been declining steadily for decades.‚Å†

Citizen uses information from police scanners and social media to alert users to emergencies going on around them. While the app purports to make communities safer, experts say that constant notifications about local crime, sent to thousands of city dwellers multiple times a day, can actually create a culture of fear. What‚Äôs more, when people are unduly afraid of their neighborhoods, that paranoia is often misdirected at people of color.‚Å†

Short-term, limited-duration health insurance plans‚ÄîObamacare workarounds that do not have to comply to the Affordable Care Act‚Äîspend less than ACA-compliant plans on medical care, according to a data published last week in the National Association of Insurance Commissioner‚Äôs 2018 Accident and Health Policy Report, as Modern Healthcare reported.‚Å†

Nancy Pelosi still hasn't learned the biggest lesson from Watergate.

Forty-five years ago, Richard Nixon became the first president to resign from office. Pop culture has embraced the Watergate scandal for decades. (There are at least nine films about it.) But neither the films nor the revisionist histories like @slate's Slow Burn podcast have quite pinned down how Nixon‚Äôs dramatic exit from the White House changed America like writer Rick Perlstein.

In Nixonland, a sprawling historical account that spans 800 pages, he traces Nixon‚Äôs rise and, as the subtitle puts it, ‚Äúthe fracturing of America.‚Äù The ‚Äúsilent majority‚Äù of angry white suburbanites, rising nationalism, and the misdeeds of a president all swirl then as they do today.

Now, some within the Democratic ranks are pushing hard for the impeachment of Trump; others, like House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, decry impeachment as imperiling Democrats‚Äô shot at the White House in 2020, if not shattering the reputation of the party altogether. The debate often hinges on preserving ‚Äúnorms‚Äù and ‚Äúinstitutions.‚Äù Watergate‚Äôs legacy regarding those is surprisingly murky. Did Watergate destroy our trust in Washington? Or did it affirm our faith in the government to throw out crooks?

Mother Jones called up Perlstein to discuss Nixon‚Äôs resignation and what the Watergate scandal means in a moment in which ‚Äúimpeach‚Äù is never far from the headlines. Click the link in our bio to read the conversation.
(üì∏: Arnie Sachs/AP)

Contrary to what you may think, Americans do trust scientists‚Äîuntil politics gets in the way.

Like many surveys and studies before it, a new report from the Pew Research Center confirms this truth: Americans love and trust scientists. In 2019, 86 percent of Americans said they had a great deal or a fair amount of confidence in them‚Äîup 3 percent from the year before.

That‚Äôs higher than confidence in the military (82 percent) and even in public school principals (80 percent)! It‚Äôs even higher than, can you believe it, the news media (47 percent, ahem) or elected officials (35 percent). Then the pollsters asked for respondents‚Äô political affiliations. Which‚Äîuh oh. Of Democrats with high levels of scientific knowledge, just about 9 out of 10 people trust environmental scientists.
‚†Ä
Of Republicans with high levels of scientific knowledge? Less than half.
‚†Ä
‚ÄúWe often see that public attitudes around climate, energy, and environmental issues are strongly correlated with party ideology, where other kinds of science issues are not,‚Äù says Cary Funk, a social scientist and lead author of the new study. This is called ‚Äúmotivated reasoning,‚Äù Funk says. ‚ÄúThe idea is that your partisan identity kind of trumps the role of knowledge in your beliefs.‚Äù

The Trump administration deported a man to Iraq, where he had never lived. He soon died on the streets.

Detroit resident Jimmy Aldaoud, 41, recently died in Iraq because he was unable to obtain insulin for his diabetes. A Greek-born Iraqi national, he had lived in the United States since he was 6 months old, had never been to Iraq, and didn't speak the language.

Aldaoud was a Chaldean Catholic, a member of a religious group that traces its roots to Iraq, where its members face a high risk of persecution by ISIS, Politico reports. In 2017, Trump struck a deal with Iraq that took the country off the president‚Äôs travel ban list in exchange for allowing the United States to deport Iraqis back to the country. Soon Chaldeans were being rounded up for deportation to a country some had never lived in‚Äîmany Chaldeans were born in refugee camps‚Äîeven though US law prohibits sending people to countries where they‚Äôre likely to be tortured or persecuted. Last year, some Chaldeans in detention reported being coerced by US immigration authorities into signing documents granting permission to deport them.

‚Å†

Why do child-abuse conspiracies explode into public consciousness at certain moments? Explanations offered for the peculiar resonance of Pizzagate and QAnon tend to focus on pathologies in the media ecosystem‚Äîepistemic bubbles, polarization, the unruly growth of social media.‚Å†

Video games have nothing to do with mass shootings. But you know what kinda does? Gamers.

In the wake of consecutive mass shootings in El Paso, Texas, and Dayton, Ohio, GOP politicians went rummaging through the dated bargain bin of excuses for gun violence and latched on to a familiar find: video games. ‚ÄúWe must stop the glorification of violence in our society. This includes the gruesome and grisly video games that are now commonplace,‚Äù Trump said on Monday morning in remarks about the shootings. His words came just one day after Rep. Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) voiced similar concerns, saying, ‚ÄúThe idea of these video games that dehumanize individuals to have a game of shooting individuals and others‚ÄîI‚Äôve always felt that is a problem.‚Äù The idea that video games might be a substantial driver of violence has been pushed at least since the Columbine shootings in 1999. It‚Äôs also been debunked since then. Other countries with large video game markets like Japan and China don‚Äôt have mass shooting or gun violence rates anywhere close to those in the United States.

While McCarthy and Trump are wrong about the link between video games and guns, recent years have shown there is a link between some parts of video game culture and extremist violence. The 8chan imageboard, where multiple recent attackers have spread word of their actions, was born out of #Gamergate, an extensive online culture war that started in 2014, featuring vicious harassment campaigns targeting women in the gaming industry.

Gaming culture as a whole does not, of course, advocate mass shootings, nor is it necessarily extremist. Marginalized groups and individuals have found welcoming, helpful, and supportive pockets across video gaming, and there is a wealth of healthy and inclusive communities that don‚Äôt support white nationalism or reactionary politics.

Whitney Phillips, who researches online extremism at Syracuse University, told Mother Jones that targeting gaming culture as the source of white supremacist shootings is about as misguided as blaming the video games themselves. So how is it all connected? Click the link in our bio to read more.
(üì∏: Mother Jones illustration; Getty)

For crimes involving these weapons, however, it is possible to convict if the perpetrator was motivated by a connection to an international extremist group. ‚ÄúIf I‚Äôm the San Bernardino shooter, or if I‚Äôm Omar Mateen at Pulse nightclub and I commit my crime with a firearm, I‚Äôve done it on behalf of ISIS, so I can be charged with material support to a terrorist organization,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúIf I do the same as a white supremacist there‚Äôs no terrorism crime I can be charged with‚Ä¶There ends up being a gap.‚Äù‚Å†

Michael German, a former special agent with the FBI who specialized in domestic terrorism, says the Justice Department has long deprioritized far-right violence. So how do we close that gap? Click the link in our bio to read.‚Å†

Burn. Build. Repeat: Why is our wildfire policy so deadly?‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Wildfire‚Äôs lethal tendency to surge up slopes was driven home last summer, when an inferno called the Carr Fire ripped through Shasta County, a chunk of Northern California pocked by crests and canyons as gorgeous as they are combustible. Lit by a spark from the wheel rim of a flat tire scraping the ground, the fire raged for 39 days, destroying more than 1,000 homes, killing eight people, and requiring some 3,500 firefighters from around the world and more than a dozen planes dropping chemicals to finally quell it. In November came the Camp Fire, which incinerated the nearby town of Paradise, killing 85 people.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Together, the fires caused at least $18 billion in damage; bankrupted California‚Äôs largest utility, Pacific Gas and Electric; and forced the liquidation of at least one insurer. For weeks, Northern Californians breathed smoky air.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Today‚Äôs monster fires result largely from three human forces: taxpayer-funded fire suppression that has made the forest a tinderbox; policies that encourage construction in places that are clearly prone to burning; and climate change, which has worsened everything. And our policies aren't fit to handle it.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Click through the link in our bio to read about California's endless cycle of destruction.‚†Ä
(üì∏: @justinmeadmaxon)

By Thursday morning, Trump had turned his attention to a much-maligned New York Times headline that had originally read ‚ÄúTrump Urges Unity vs. Racism‚Äù‚Äîa framing that many said ran counter to the president‚Äôs longstanding record of divisiveness and racist rhetoric. ‚ÄúRadical Left Democrats went absolutely CRAZY!‚Äù Trump said on Thursday, referring to the headline change. ‚ÄúFake News‚ÄîThat‚Äôs what we‚Äôre up against.‚Äù‚Å†

This string of tweets highlights the wholly inconsistent messaging shaping Trump‚Äôs response to the massacres: one that rejects divisiveness before the television cameras while relentlessly attacking his political opponents in other forums.‚Å†

Following this past weekend's two mass shootings, former President Barack Obama called for action to combat gun violence, urged law enforcement and Silicon Valley to act to combat the ‚Äúdangerous trend‚Äù of white nationalism, and alluded to Trump‚Äôs history of hateful, racist rhetoric.‚Å†‚†Ä

Getting out of jail after dark can be dangerous‚Äîand sometimes deadly‚Äîso why do so many jails do it?‚Å†
‚Å†
It‚Äôs not unusual for jails large and small to release inmates after dark or in the early hours of the morning. For many people released before daybreak, the hours that follow are difficult, dangerous, and sometimes deadly. Many hit the streets without phones, money, a ride, or knowledge of local public transportation, if it‚Äôs still running.‚Å†
‚Å†
They may be struggling with addiction or mental health issues; some have no place to go. In Los Angeles, men and women let out at night often find their way to nearby Skid Row. Chicago‚Äôs Cook County Jail releases people into a dangerous neighborhood after dark. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard to think of a more counterproductive, self-defeating measure if we want people to succeed when they get out of jail than releasing them in the middle of the night,‚Äù says David Fathi, director of the American Civil Liberties Union‚Äôs prison project.‚Å†
‚Å†
Mother Jones reporter Madison Pauly dives into why jails release inmates at the worst possible times, and explores the efforts being made to change it. Click the link in our bio to read.‚Å†

Killer heat waves are becoming more and more common, but scientists are getting better at predicting them.‚Å†
‚Å†
As you might expect, the climate crisis is prolonging heat waves. Scientists say the number of heat waves in 50 major American cities has tripled since the 1960s. Last month was the hottest since record-keeping began 140 years ago.‚Å†
‚Å†
Using computer simulations and weather observations from ships, satellites, and roofs, scientists at the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder are developing a short-term forecast model for extreme summertime heat. And officials at the National Weather Service have also been pushing forward their predictions of heat waves in recent years.‚Å†
‚Å†
The ability to predict the next one is a big deal to meteorologists. That‚Äôs because more warning means extra time to prepare cooling centers and swimming pools, shore up the electric grid, and put supplies in place for heat-vulnerable populations and machines.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúThere are still things we don‚Äôt know,‚Äù Jon Gottschalck, operational prediction chief at the NWS Climate Prediction Center in College Park, Maryland, says. ‚ÄúAs you get further out in time, the atmosphere‚Äîchaos‚Äîtakes over. The predictability just drops.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Click the link in our bio to read more.‚Å†
(üì∏: Samuel Boivin/NurPhoto/Getty)‚Å†

Over eight years, an immigration judge has denied more than 200 asylum claims in a row. Meet Agnelis Reese, America‚Äôs harshest immigration judge.‚Å†
‚Å†
Asylum seekers come to the United States prepared to tell stories of persecution, fear, and torture, but their fate often depends less on their credibility than on luck. The luckiest might end up in Elizabeth, New Jersey, where they have a 44 percent chance of being granted asylum. For those who are released from detention and have their cases transferred to New York City, it‚Äôs almost 80 percent. The less lucky ones get locked up in Louisiana, where immigration judges reject 84 percent of asylum claims. And the least fortunate find themselves at the Oakdale Immigration Court before Reese.‚Å†
‚Å†
On paper, Reese might seem like someone who would be sympathetic to the challenges facing persecuted minorities: She‚Äôs a black woman, a Clinton administration appointee, a registered Democrat, and a preacher. But her unforgiving reputation precedes her. (Between 2011 and 2018, Reese denied every single one of the more than 200 asylum claims she heard.)‚Å†
‚Å†
When deciding asylum cases, immigration judges are supposed to impartially weigh the evidence presented by the asylee and the Department of Homeland Security. (Asylum seekers are not guaranteed an attorney.) But a review of transcripts from six asylum hearings and a visit to her courtroom showed that Reese often acts like a federal immigration prosecutor.‚Å†
‚Å†
Immigration reporter Noah Lanard pored over transcripts and legal documents and talked with asylees denied by Reese. Click the link in our bio to read.‚Å†
(üì∏: Alex Nabaum/@alexnabaum)‚Å†

They‚Äôre the United States‚Äô only native marsupial, but they‚Äôre virtually nobody‚Äôs favorite animal. No one has ever squealed, ‚ÄúTrash panda!,‚Äù after spotting one digging through a garbage bin, as so many people (somehow) lovingly do with raccoons.‚Å†
‚Å†
Sure, they‚Äôre ugly. They‚Äôve got beady eyes, a hairless tail, and dozens of pointed teeth. When Captain John Smith came to America in the 17th century, he wrote that opossums have a head ‚Äúlike a Swine,‚Äù a tail ‚Äúlike a Rat,‚Äù and are about the size of a cat, which...is pretty spot-on. But opossums do more for us than we recognize!‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúJust because they‚Äôre ugly doesn‚Äôt mean that they‚Äôre not important and worthy of protecting,‚Äù David Mizejewski, a naturalist at the National Wildlife Federation and author of the book Attracting Birds, Butterflies, and Other Backyard Wildlife, tells Mother Jones. ‚ÄúIf you just open your mind a little bit, you can see them as beautiful creatures.‚Å†
‚Å†
Opossums protect humans by eating ticks, dead animals, and venomous snakes‚Äîand as nature‚Äôs trash collectors, they play a vital role in the ecosystem, all while protecting humans from disease. ‚ÄúDespite, again, their appearance and stereotype, they‚Äôre not filthy animals,‚Äù says Mizejewski. ‚ÄúIn fact, they‚Äôre fastidious groomers.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
If all this wasn‚Äôt enough evidence for you that the opossum deserves an award for its service to humanity, know that opossums are also some of the animal kingdom‚Äôs most devoted mothers. Click the link in our bio to read more.‚Å†
(üì∏: Wittek/ZUMA)‚Å†

Did you know that the government can make you legally "dead," even when you're very much alive?‚Å†
‚Å†
Under a century-old law, Rhode Island classifies everyone serving a life sentence in the state as ‚Äúcivilly dead,‚Äù meaning they have absolutely no civil rights. Unlike other prisoners, they can‚Äôt sue or raise complaints in state court, even if they‚Äôve been mistreated or abused.‚Å†
‚Å†
They can‚Äôt get married or divorced, they lose rights over their children, and they can‚Äôt own property in their name or sign a contract. In these matters, as the law puts it, they are ‚Äúdeemed to be dead in all respects, as if [their] natural death had taken place at the time of conviction.‚Äù It doesn‚Äôt matter if they are eligible for parole and will eventually leave prison.‚Å†
‚Å†
New York and Rhode Island are the only two states that never got rid of their civil death statutes. (Neither did the US Virgin Islands.) But Rhode Island is the only place where civil death is still enforced, says Sonja Deyoe, an attorney in the state who for years has fought against the statute. But she isn't the only one who's tried, and failed, to fight the statue. Click the link in our bio to read more.‚Å†
‚Å†
(üì∏: Mother Jones illustration; Getty)‚Å†

John Ratcliffe, the Texas representative who President Donald Trump picked Sunday to be his next national intelligence director, has never served in the intelligence community.‚Å†

Trump met with Ratcliffe to discuss the job five days before the Mueller hearing, turning the event into a virtual audition for him, the @nytimes reported. Ratcliffe has also frequently suggested the national security establishment is aligned against Trump.‚Å†

Ratcliffe, if confirmed by the Senate, is expected to infuse a traditionally apolitical job with a partisan edge. That has Trump critics concerned, given that the national intelligence director‚Äôs main role is to deliver the president‚Äôs daily intelligence briefing. Click the link in our bio for more.‚Å†

The Pentagon's top ranks have been empty for a long time. Now there are 1,581 problems waiting to be solved.‚Å†
‚Å†
One day after taking over as the Pentagon‚Äôs first Senate-confirmed leader in seven months, new Secretary of Defense Mark Esper was asked by a reporter to assess what the impact has been of the months-long lack of stable leadership at the largest federal agency. His careful answer attempted to endorse the department‚Äôs vast civilian workforce, whose ranks have been depleted since the exit of President Trump‚Äôs first defense secretary, James Mattis, while also providing reassurance.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúWe have a great cadre of DOD civilians,‚Äù Esper responded. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm confident we didn‚Äôt miss any beats, any steps if you will.‚Äù That very same day, the Pentagon‚Äôs internal watchdog released more than 400 pages rebutting the notion that the Defense Department ‚Äúdidn‚Äôt miss any beats‚Äù during the last seven months, when temporary officials have increasingly taken more active roles among the Pentagon‚Äôs leadership.‚Å†
‚Å†
On Wednesday, the Office of the Inspector General, which itself is run by an acting leader, published its second-ever list of all recommendations the office has made to Defense officials, but which remain unfulfilled‚Äînot because DOD officials disagree with them, though sometimes they do, but because the department simply never followed through.‚Å†
‚Å†
Resolving these issues is a crucial step toward combating the waste, fraud, and abuse that have bedeviled DOD management for decades, but with so many of these action items unresolved, there is still no indication that any timeline exists for dealing with them. Donald Trump's war on abortion could make the opioid epidemic much worse.‚Å†
‚Å†
Last week the Trump administration announced it would go forward with a new regulation affecting Title X that many are calling a ‚Äúdomestic gag rule.‚Äù If an organization wants to continue receiving funds, health care professionals will be forbidden from offering abortions‚Äîor even referrals to abortion services.‚Å†
‚Å†
One consequence of this new rule is the harm it causes for many recipients in underserved rural communities where clinics don‚Äôt just provide reproductive health care, but also serve as the only medical point of contact for people struggling with opioid addictions.‚Å†
‚Å†
Organizations throughout the country now face a difficult choice under Trump‚Äôs new restrictions: Reject crucial funding or comply with rules that they consider bad medicine for patients. ‚ÄúI predict a worsening of the opioid epidemic,‚Äù says Dr. Mishka Terplan, a professor at Virginia Commonwealth University. ‚ÄúThere are some [clinics] that get a whole lot of money from fundraising, and this gag rule is a problem, but is not a death sentence for their clinics. [But] there are clinics for which this is desperate.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
In addition to preventing health care professionals from detecting and treating opioid addiction, the change harms clinics that serve a vital role in trying to improve maternal mortality rates for people struggling with addiction. While maternal mortality and addiction are often discussed as separate issues, one of the leading causes of postpartum deaths in the United States is overdosing.‚Å†
‚Å†
Terplan says that in states like West Virginia and Kentucky, a funding cut could essentially cripple providers who have been the first line of defense in the opioid crisis. ‚ÄúSo yes, this is definitely going to get worse.‚Äù Click the link in our bio to read more.‚Å†
(üì∏: Brendan Smialowski/Getty)‚Å†

‚Å†‚†Ä
The senator extolled the virtues of the health care plan, calling it a comprehensive solution.‚Å†‚†Ä

‚Äú[Phillips] concluded that he was being ‚Äòblocked‚Äô and not allowed to ‚Äòretreat.‚Äô He passed these conclusions on to the Post," Judge William Bertelsman wrote in his order. "They may have been erroneous, but as discussed above, they are opinion protected by the First Amendment. And The Post is not liable for publishing these opinions.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúTherefore, having reviewed this matter carefully, and being fully advised, it is ordered that the Post‚Äôs motion to dismiss be, and is hereby, granted.‚Äù‚Å†

State courts hear 95 percent of cases filed in the United States, setting sweeping legal precedents that influence generations. They‚Äôre the final word on interpreting state law and constitution. ‚Å†‚†Ä

TIP üëèüèº YOUR üëèüèº DELIVERY üëèüèº PERSON üëèüèº IN üëèüèº CASH üëèüèº (No‚Äîseriously‚Äîwhatever else you do, just tip in cash.)‚Å†
‚Å†
You're feeling hungry, you're feeling like indulging, and the weather outside is nasty. So you open up one of your apps to order delivery. Pad Thai? No. Pizza? That sounds pretty good. But whatever it is you end up ordering, do not tip through the app on DoorDash.‚Å†
‚Å†
On DoorDash, tipping with a credit card is kind of a lie. Back in February, @nbcnews reported that the company was doing something unusual with tips submitted through the app: "Drivers get a pay guarantee depending on the size and complexity of the delivery job. If that pay guarantee is $6 and the customer doesn‚Äôt tip, Doordash pays the full fee to the courier. However, if the customer tips $5, the courier still only gets $6 and the portion that Doordash pays drops to just $1."‚Å†
‚Å†
This is...not tipping! It means that instead of paying the driver something extra, you are actually just saving the company from paying what it owes if you tip through the app.‚Å†
‚Å†
In response to some understandable rage, Instacart (the other company featured in the NBC story) changed its policy. But a few weeks ago, DoorDash announced it would keep things as they are. Which is why you should tip in cash!‚Å†
‚Å†
Even if DoorDash does change or even if you use Postmates (which allocates its tips normally, like tips), maybe you should just get into the habit of tipping in cash because you just can‚Äôt trust these companies. The tech-based gig economy is a race to the bottom for service workers, and the livelihood of delivery workers making sub-living wages in dangerous conditions is probably never going to be their first priority.‚Å†
‚Å†
Tip cash, and tip a lot. Or, you know, just go outside yourself.‚Å†

A federal court appears ready to buy the GOP's argument to kill Obamacare, a move that could see the number of uninsured Americans skyrocket by 19.9 million.‚Å†
‚Å†
The fate of the Affordable Care Act remains uncertain following a hearing about the law at a federal appeals court in New Orleans. The hearing concerned a lawsuit originally filed by Republican state attorneys general in a Texas district court in 2018, which alleges that the entirety of Obamacare should be invalidated because Congress used the 2017 tax cut law to zero out the financial penalty for the ACA‚Äôs individual mandate. In 2012, the Supreme Court upheld the ACA on the grounds that the individual mandate counted as a tax.‚Å†
‚Å†
In December, a district court judge in Texas sided with the Republicans and struck down all parts of Obamacare, everything from the law‚Äôs provision expanding Medicaid, to subsidies for middle-class families to buy insurance on the marketplaces, to mandates for calorie counts on menus‚Äînot just the individual mandate. If the Texas decision stands, 19.9 million more people in the US would be uninsured, according to an analysis by the Urban Institute.‚Å†
‚Å†
The Trump administration has sided with the GOP attorneys general in the case. After the suit was filed last year, then‚ÄìAttorney General Jeff Sessions filed a brief on behalf of President Trump saying that it supported overturning the individual mandate and other aspects of the law, including the ACA‚Äôs ban on charging higher rates or denying coverage for people with preexisting conditions.‚Å†

Sen. @kamalaharris (D-Calif.) and Rep. @ocasio2018 (D-N.Y.) recently introduced a bill that would help formerly incarcerated people secure government housing assistance.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúToo many people become involved in our criminal justice system and serve their time only to return home to face additional barriers to employment, education, and housing,‚Äù said Harris in a statement. ‚ÄúBy requiring a higher standard of evidence and a more holistic review process, we are taking a significant step toward giving Americans a fair chance to succeed.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Lack of access to housing is one of the main causes of recidivism‚Äîwhen a formerly incarcerated person returns to prison or jail. Because many landlords refuse to rent to people with criminal records and also because of stringent rules in government assisted homes, one in five people who leave prison will end up homeless.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúThe Fair Chance at Housing Act of 2019‚Äù would reform the current eviction and screening policies for housing that are currently in place. As part of the war on drugs from the 1990s, the Department of Housing and Urban Development, which oversees local public housing authorities, issued guidance that compelled local public housing authorities to adopt extremely strict policies regarding criminal activity. This bill takes aim at eliminating those rules.‚Å†
‚Å†
The proposed legislation attempts to reverse a number of policies that public housing residents and advocates have long said are unfair to those attempting to rebuild their lives after living prison, and that have imposed a burden on families with a member who has a criminal record. And for Harris, the proposed legislation comes at a time when the presidential candidate wants to prove that she‚Äôs got the progressive chops to be the Democratic nominee.‚Å†
‚Å†

56,000 kids showed up alone at our border this year, but cages are just part of the story.‚Å†
‚Å†
Last October, Carlos decided to flee Honduras with hopes of seeking asylum in the United States. A large migrant caravan was forming, so he rushed to meet up with the thousands of migrants already in Guatemala to avoid making the trek north alone.‚Å†
‚Å†
Carlos was homeless for most of his life in a city where a teenage boy is expected to work with gangs or be killed. He lived under a bridge for a while, but last fall, not long after he moved into a small shack, ‚Äúsomething happened.‚Äù Shortly after, gangs shot up his shelter. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre supposed to just put up with it there,‚Äù he said.‚Å†
‚Å†
But unlike thousands of unaccompanied minors from Central America migrating recently, Carlos didn‚Äôt have anyone in Honduras looking out for him, and he didn‚Äôt have anyone in the United States waiting for him, either. He was 17, and he was truly alone.‚Å†
‚Å†
From October to May, US Customs and Border Protection encountered some 56,200 unaccompanied children and teens along the border with Mexico. That‚Äôs a 74 percent increase from the same period last fiscal year and the highest annual number yet for the agency. In the past, when underage migrants presented themselves at the border, US immigration officials would typically take them in and process their cases. They would then end up in US custody, first in temporary facilities operated by Border Patrol (like the Clint patrol station), then in long-term shelters run by the US Department of Health and Human Services. Eventually, HHS would connect the kids with distant relatives or with sponsors.‚Å†
‚Å†
But in recent months, the Trump administration has put an extra hurdle in front of underage migrants. Since last fall, US officials have been turning away underage asylum seekers, often sending them back to Mexican authorities or to the dangerous streets of Mexican border towns.‚Å†
‚Å†
Click the link in our bio to read about Carlos's journey north and how cages were just the beginning of the crisis at our border.‚Å†

When Kim Cobb, a professor at the School of Earth and Atmospheric Sciences at Georgia Tech, saw Donald Trump's victory on election night 2016, she soon descended into severe depression.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúI had the firm belief that Washington would act on climate change and would be acting soon,‚Äù the 44-year-old Cobb says. ‚ÄúWhen Trump was elected, it came crashing down.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Back home in Atlanta, Cobb entered what she now calls ‚Äúan acute mental health crisis.‚Äù Most mornings, she could not get out of bed, despite having four children to tend to. She would sob spontaneously. She obsessed about the notion that the US government would take no action to address climate change and confront its consequences.‚Å†
‚Å†
Increasingly, Cobb and other climate scientists have begun publicly talking about the psychological impact of contending with data pointing to a looming catastrophe, dealing with denialism and attacks on science, and observing government inaction in the face of climate change.‚Å†
‚Å†
Are scientists canaries in a psychological coal mine? Is understanding their grief important because their anxiety could become more widespread within the general population?‚Å†

It began after he'd heard a rumor on Capitol Hill that Chuck Hagel, who had recently been nominated by President Barack Obama as defense secretary, might have given paid speeches to controversial foreign groups. Hagel was already under attack by some conservatives for his allegedly anti-Israel views. He asked around about it, suggesting sarcastically to a Republican Senate aide that maybe Hagel had addressed a group called ‚ÄúFriends of Hamas.‚Äù He‚Äôd made that name up. It was supposed to sound so absurd and controversial that it was obviously fake.‚Å†
‚Å†
Through a game of Capitol Hill telephone, Friedman's invention reached Ben Shapiro, then a writer for the conservative news site Breitbart. Shapiro wrote an article stating that ‚ÄúSenate sources‚Äù told him that Hagel had received ‚Äúforeign funding‚Äù from a group ‚Äúpurportedly called ‚ÄòFriends of Hamas.‚Äô‚Äú "The story as reported is correct,‚Äù he told Friedman then. It faded away, laying dormant for six years.‚Å†
‚Å†
But this willful misunderstanding sprang back to life recently. The Washington Free Beacon, a conservative publication, ran a hit piece on Max Berger, a staffer on the presidential campaign of Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.). Click the link in our bio to read more.‚Å†

Tennessee honored Nathan Bedford Forrest, a slave trader, confederate general, and Ku Klux Klan leader Saturday, according to a state law that Republican Gov. Bill Lee and his predecessors have kept in place.‚Å†
‚Å†
Despite recent controversy around Confederate monuments across the country, the state of Tennessee celebrated Forrest, a man who took part in slaughtering African Americans after the Civil War as the leader of the KKK and whose bust still sits in the Tennessee state capitol. According to a Tennessee law, each year the governor must sign proclamations for six state holidays, including one for Forrest, one for Confederate army leader Robert E. Lee, and Confederate Memorial Day on the birthday of the Confederacy‚Äôs president, Jefferson Davis.‚Å†
‚Å†
The proclamation signed by Lee, and Republican Gov. Bill Haslam before him, calls Bedford a ‚Äúrecognized military figure in American history and a native Tennessean‚Äù and encourages citizens to join the governor in ‚Äúthis worthy observance.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Lee said he signed the proclamation in accordance with state law and declined to say if he believes the law should change, according to The Tennessean. Lee has defended the presence of the Forrest statue in the capitol in the past, saying that removing it would ‚Äúwhitewash history.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
And get this: Even members of Lee‚Äôs own party believe this holiday goes too far. On Friday, Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) criticized the holiday, even as he maintained his general support for maintaining Confederate monuments. Click the link in our bio to read more.‚Å†

Why did millennials turn left? Keir Milburn, lecturer in political economy and organization at the University of Leicester in the UK, may have the answer in his new book, "Generation Left." Scholars and political commentators are getting used to talking in terms of generational cohorts even if they‚Äôre not always happy about it. Once a popular cluster of jokes about interns and avocados, the generational label has become a political battleground, with Democratic presidential candidates vying for the votes of angry, indebted young Americans.

While some researchers were caught flat-footed by the millennial political turn, Milburn was ready to interpret. "During a period of declining wages, welfare rights and living standards, stories that chip away at young people‚Äôs expectations are useful to the Right. But the Generation Snowflake stories are not really aimed at the young. They are best seen as self-justifying and comforting morality tales for the wealthier sections of older generations," he writes in "Generation Left." Milburn tracks the development of this political cohort from its birth in the streets in the wake of the 2007‚Äì08 financial crisis to its run at political office and perhaps back again. Reporter Malcolm Harris chatted with Milburn about his book, and what this political generation could mean for the world at large. Click the link in bio to read.

When it comes to climate change research, most studies deliver bad news about the looming, very real threat of a heating planet. But a new study, out Thursday, offers a sliver of hope: Researchers based in Switzerland, Italy, and France found that expanding forests, which sequester carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, could seriously make up for humans‚Äô toxic carbon emissions.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúWe know a single tree can capture a lot of carbon. What we don‚Äôt know is how many trees the planet can support,‚Äù says Jean-Fran√ßois Bastin, the study‚Äôs lead author, adding, ‚ÄúThis gives us an idea.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
There‚Äôs space on the planet for an extra 900 million hectares of canopy cover, the researchers found, which translates to storage for a whopping 205 gigatonnes of carbon. To put that in perspective, humans emit about 10 gigatonnes of carbon from burning fossil fuels every year, according to Richard Houghton, a senior scientist at the Woods Hole Research Center.‚Å†
‚Å†
Overall, there are about 850 gigatonnes of carbon in the atmosphere now; a tree-planting effort on that scale could, in theory, cut carbon by about 25 percent, according to the authors. Houghton says trees are relatively cheap carbon consumers, and ‚Äúthere are technologies people are working on to take carbon dioxide out of the air. And trees do it‚Äîfor nothing.‚Äù‚Å†

In a 5-4 opinion by Chief Justice John Roberts, the Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that partisan gerrymandering cannot be challenged in federal court. A devastating blow to voters in gerrymandered districts and the voting rights advocates who have tried to rein in extreme gerrymandering that benefits one party, the ruling comes at a pivotal time: The 2020 elections will determine who controls the state legislative bodies that in most states will draw new district lines in 2021, following the 2020 census. These cases were the last chance for the Supreme Court to curb partisan gerrymandering before the next election.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
The Supreme Court also ruled on Thursday that the Trump administration failed to justify a controversial question about US citizenship on the 2020 census. The administration said the question was needed to better enforce the Voting Rights Act, but nearly every piece of evidence in the case says different. Civil rights groups argue that the citizenship question will deter immigrants from responding to the census out of fear that it‚Äôll be used to initiate their deportations. And the stakes are huge: The census determines how $880 billion in federal funding is allocated, how much representation states receive, and how political districts are drawn.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Voting rights reporter Ari Berman and politics reporter Pema Levy walk you through what‚Äôs at stake. Click the link in our bio to read.‚Å†‚†Ä

Debates matter more than you'd think.Ôªø
Ôªø
It‚Äôs finally happening. On Wednesday, 10 Democratic candidates will take the stage in Miami for the first debate of the 2020 presidential campaign. On Thursday, 10 different Democrats will do it. Sure, it will be entertaining. But do debates actually matter?Ôªø
Ôªø
According to University of Alabama‚ÄìBirmingham political scientist William Benoit, who has spent years studying the effects of candidate debates, the answer is yes. ‚ÄúLots of things in the campaign have effects on the voters, and they accumulate over time,‚Äù Benoit says. "Debates are useful for voters. They can help candidates. They can‚Äôt guarantee a win, but I think they can lose you the campaign if you mess up too badly.‚ÄùÔªø
Ôªø
The idea that a debate can really hurt a candidate is fairly intuitive‚Äîin extreme cases, it‚Äôs like a nationally televised implosion. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a mass communication theory about agenda-setting that was started about news coverage, and got extended to debates,‚Äù Benoit says. ‚ÄúAnd what they found was, the more the news talks about a given topic‚Äîlike energy, or immigration, or inflation‚Äîthe more important the voters think it is."Ôªø

Nine years ago, Rocky Kistner traveled down to the bustling Louisiana bayou fishing town of Venice. But in the decade since the spill, government agencies have set no major rules governing the use of the toxic chemicals. And with President Trump rolling back drilling safety regulations and pushing for new drilling in areas like the East Coast and the Arctic, the matter has taken on new urgency: The next big oil spill may be just around the corner.‚†Ä

In fact, it's the opposite. A recent study from Binnall mixed felons and non-felons on mock juries and found that people convicted of felonies outperformed their counterparts. They were more likely to introduce new facts and participate for a greater amount of time, and were equally likely to convict.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
While many of us avoid the civic duty, for those with felony convictions, jury duty can feel humanizing‚Äîa path back to society. Click the link in our bio to see how.‚†Ä

California's fires hit rich and poor communities. Can you guess which ones are recovering faster?‚†Ä

The 2015 Valley Fire and the 2017 North Bay fires occurred in adjacent counties, but the recovery of the communities has been disparate. According to a 2018 study published in PLOS One, the socioeconomics of a community and its ability‚Äîor inability‚Äîto recover following a disaster are linked.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Overwhelming insurance company requirements, gaps in financial support, and lack of local political power make rebuilding a far more arduous process for poorer counties such as Lake County than wealthy ones like Sonoma County. As a result, recovery takes longer for less affluent communities.‚†Ä
