In recent days, Republican-dominated legislatures in Alabama, Georgia, Ohio, and Missouri have passed some of the harshest abortion restrictions in decades. And they used voter suppression and gerrymandering to make it happen.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
These tactics have greased the way for near-total bans on abortion and other extreme right-wing policies. Georgia is a perfect example. As secretary of state, Republican gubernatorial candidate Brian Kemp essentially oversaw his own election, allowing Georgia to purge 1.4 million people from the voter rolls from 2012 to 2016. He also put the registrations of 53,000 people, 80 percent of whom were voters of color, on hold before the election and closed 214 polling places in six years.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Extreme partisan gerrymandering has helped Republicans establish strangleholds on state legislatures around the country. After winning control of the redistricting process after the 2010 election, Georgia Republicans concentrated black voters into as few districts as possible to maximize the number of heavily white Republican seats.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
This helps insulate GOP lawmakers from any public backlash over their votes. Click the link in our bio to read how.‚†Ä

Getting your period in prison is hell. We've got the numbers to prove it.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Women are the fastest-growing incarcerated population, but in many states, prisons only offer cheap pads that don‚Äôt stick or absorb well. Female prisoners often have to fashion their own makeshift tampons out of bedding, clothes, toilet paper, or whatever else they can find.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Missouri Appleseed, a nonprofit, working with the state Department of Corrections, surveyed 90 incarcerated women, 20 prison nurses, and 20 correctional case managers about their access to sanitary products. The findings were pretty shocking:‚†Ä
‚Ä¢ Half of the women said they had to change the free pads they were given at least every half hour.‚†Ä
‚Ä¢ 88 percent of women reported leaking blood onto their clothes, their bedding, or the floor.‚†Ä
‚Ä¢ 80 percent used homemade tampons, whether made from clothing or the free pads.‚†Ä
‚Ä¢ Of these, 28 percent said they‚Äôd had a vaginal infection over the past six months.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
The department estimates it would cost about $171,000 to give free tampons in prisons, assuming that half of the state‚Äôs roughly 3,100 women inmates would request them. The department‚Äôs total budget is $786 million annually. Click the link in our bio to read what's being done about it.‚†Ä

Why are so many violent white supremacists not charged with domestic terrorism? It‚Äôs because US terrorism laws make it harder to convict for certain acts of violence if they are motivated by white supremacy.‚Å£

Sri Lanka‚Äôs government blocked residents of the island nation from accessing several social media platforms on Sunday, following bombings of luxury hotels and churches during the Easter holiday that killed at least 290, in an effort to stop false information about the attacks from spreading.‚Å£
‚Å£
The country‚Äôs defense ministry said that it is currently conducting investigations regarding the bombings and that it ‚Äúhas taken steps to temporarily block all the social media avenues until the investigations are concluded.‚Äù Facebook‚Äîalong with its messaging apps WhatsApp and Messenger and its image-sharing app Instagram‚Äîas well as Snapchat, YouTube, and Viber were all blocked by the Sri Lankan government on Sunday, according to NetBlocks, an internet rights organization based in London.‚Å£
‚Å£
Sunday is not the first time Sri Lanka has blocked domestic access to social media platforms. The country also did this in March 2018 in an attempt to stop sectarian violence.  The country is one of many where social media has exacerbated deadly violence. Myanmar, India, Nigeria, and South Sudan have all dealt with their own varying levels of violence at least partially motivated by misinformation spread on Facebook and other social media platforms.‚Å£

In 2016, Henry Montgomery won a landmark Supreme Court case that gave him and thousands of other inmates hope for a second chance. ‚Å£
The court ruled that because he was a kid at the time of his crime, the state should revisit his case and consider granting him a new sentence; it ordered other states to do the same for the roughly 2,800 juvenile lifers serving mandatory prisons terms all around the country. ‚Å£

On Wednesday morning, the House of Representatives passed a bill to restore Obama-era net neutrality protections‚Äîbut the effort is likely to stop there, with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) saying his chamber won‚Äôt consider the measure and the White House threatening to veto the bill as well.‚Å£

However Republicans argue that there are very few examples of proven net neutrality violations in the past, especially violations that are indicative of a systemic or structural issue that would require new Title II regulations like those in the new net neutrality bill in the House this week. To no surprise, the most substantial reference to climate change in the three 2016 presidential debates was so brief and unspecific, it would've been missed in the blink of an eye. ‚ÄúI think the science is real,‚Äù Hillary Clinton affirmed in her first showdown with Donald Trump, not because she was asked about it, but because she wanted to highlight yet another contrast between them.‚Å£

The #GreenNewDeal and it's supporters aim to tackle the intertwined issues of social and environmental justice in our age of anthropogenic climate change in one sweeping legislative action. ‚Å£

It‚Äôs important to know the history of mammogram recommendations. For years, experts urged women 40 and older to get mammograms every year. The idea was that early cancer detection saves lives. But then science showed that mammograms for younger women aren‚Äôt very accurate and lead to lots of false positive results and unnecessary intervention.‚Å£
‚Å£
All that over-treatment is expensive. One study puts the cost at $4 billion a year. So in 2009, the task force changed its guidelines to recommend that most women start the exams at age 50 and get the test only every two years. ‚Å£
‚Å£
‚ÄúWhen you have finite capacity and you‚Äôre using it for stuff that people don‚Äôt need, it means it‚Äôs not available for people who do need it, especially if they need it fast,‚Äù says Shannon Brownlee, senior vice president of the Lown Institute, a think tank studying health care overuse.‚Å£
‚Å£
But there are indications that the issue could be remedied simply by urging doctors to follow the guidelines. Click the link in our bio to read the full article.‚Å£

Last Friday, as the two women who have accused Virginia Lt. Gov. Justin Fairfax of sexual assault prepared to go on ‚ÄúCBS This Morning‚Äù and recount their stories to anchor Gayle King, Fairfax was traveling to a Washington, DC, law office to sit down with a very different type of interviewer: polygraph examiner Jerry Hanafin.‚Å£

Hanafin, a retired FBI agent, had administered a polygraph test last fall to Christine Blasey Ford, who had just accused then-Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh of assaulting her. His report, obtained by CBS and published Wednesday, concluded that Fairfax‚Äôs physiological indicators‚Äîsuch as perspiration, breathing, and heart rate‚Äîwere ‚Äúnot indicative of deception.‚Äù when he denied engaging in ‚Äúnon-consensual sexual activity‚Äù with either of his accusers.‚Å£
‚Å£
But what does the polygraph exam‚Äîa controversial technique whose results are typically not admissible in court‚Äîreally tell us about Fairfax‚Äôs responsibility for the alleged sexual assaults? According to Leonard Saxe, a social psychologist at Brandeis University, the exam is basically useless. ‚ÄúThe lie detector is not a lie detector‚Äîit‚Äôs a fear detector,‚Äù Saxe says.‚Å£
‚Å£
That‚Äôs part of the reason sexual assault victim advocates have typically discouraged investigators from asking victims to take polygraphs. And on the other side, lie detector tests are perhaps even more flawed when used on those accused of sexual misconduct. Indeed, research shows that most offenders will not admit to ‚Äúrape‚Äù or to ‚Äúsexual assault,‚Äù even at the same time as they cop to behavior that amounts to it.‚Å£

Each year since the Paris climate agreement, major world banks have increased their financing of fossil fuels, pouring $1.9 trillion into the industry from 2016 through 2018. And, it turns out, US banks are the worst offenders, according to a recent report published by a group of environmental organizations.‚Å£
‚Å£
JP Morgan Chase, Wells Fargo, Citi, and Bank of America, lead the list, with Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs not far behind. ‚ÄúThe sad reality is that the fossil fuel sector has only grown since Paris,‚Äù says Patrick McCully, climate and energy director for the Rainforest Action Network and one of the authors of the new report. ‚ÄúThe banks are following what the industry is doing, and the industry‚Äôs able to expand because it‚Äôs able to keep getting capital from the banks‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs just this really alarming, really terrifying dynamic going on worldwide.‚Äù‚Å£
‚Å£
While American banks finance the oil and gas industries, European banks have effectively pulled out entirely. Click the link in our bio to read how.‚Å£

Presented with two cases of extreme partisan gerrymandering, the Supreme Court‚Äôs conservative majority hinted this week that it might preserve these politically motivated maps in order to avoid what it seemed to regard as the most dangerous possible outcome: equal representation for all citizens.‚Å£

In the two cases, from North Carolina and Maryland, the party controlling state government‚ÄîRepublicans in North Carolina and Democrats in Maryland‚Äîdrew district maps designed to limit the representation of their political opponents in Congress, giving Republicans a 9-3 advantage in North Carolina‚Äôs US House delegation and Democrats a 7-1 advantage in Maryland. ‚Å£
The two cases represent the last time the Supreme Court can realistically curb partisan gerrymandering before the 2020 elections. From Mother Jones Washington Bureau Chief, David Corn: On Sunday afternoon Attorney General William Barr sent a letter to Congress noting that Special Counsel Robert Mueller‚Äôs investigation ‚Äúdid not establish that members of the Trump Campaign conspired or coordinated with the Russian government in its election interference activities.‚Äù The message also noted that Mueller could not exonerate President Donald Trump of obstruction of justice, but that Barr himself had decided that the evidence Mueller developed was ‚Äúinsufficient to establish‚Äù that Trump had obstructed justice.Barr‚Äôs note is clear that Mueller did not uncover evidence Trump and his gang were in direct cahoots with Russia‚Äôs covert operation to interfere with the US election and boost Trump‚Äôs odds. But the hyper-focus on this sort of collusion‚Äîas if Trump instructed Russian hackers on how to penetrate the computer network of the Democratic National Committee‚Äîhas always diverted attention from a basic and important element of the scandal that was proven long before Mueller drafted his final report: Trump and his lieutenants interacted with Russia while Putin was attacking the 2016 election and provided encouraging signals to the Kremlin as it sought to subvert American democracy. They aided and abetted Moscow‚Äôs attempt to cover up its assault on the United States (which aimed to help Trump win the White House). And they lied about all this.‚Å£
‚Å£
And, yes, there were instances of collusion‚Äînot on the specifics of the attack, but secret scheming between Trumpworld and Russia.‚Å£
‚Å£
None of the evidence underlying this is in dispute. No matter what Mueller report contains, a harsh verdict remains: Trump and his gang betrayed the United States in the greatest scandal in American history. Continue reading David Corn's full Sunday evening analysis by clicking the link in our bio.

After a long two days of anticipation from members of Congress and the public, Attorney General William Barr delivered his ‚Äúprincipal conclusions‚Äù from Special Counsel Robert Mueller‚Äôs report to lawmakers on Sunday. Click the link in our bio to read Barr's letter.

Twenty-five years ago, Democrats and Republicans felt the same way about immigrants: The Pew Research Center found that nearly two-thirds of both parties agreed they were a burden. Last Friday, a gunman murdered at least 50 people at two mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand. While the terrorist‚Äôs exact path to radicalization is still unknown, one thing has become increasingly clear: This was an attack inspired by the internet and crafted for the internet, representing a new level of super-viral violence.‚Å£
‚Å£
On this week‚Äôs episode of the Mother Jones Podcast, we explore how the Christchurch shooter exploited unwitting allies in the form of giant tech companies, which have proven themselves unable or unwilling to stop the spread of hate speech on their platforms. In doing so, the 28-year-old Australian suspect, steeped in far-right hate found in the darkest corners of the internet, instantly turned some of America‚Äôs most profitable and influential companies into distributors of a lurid white nationalist recruitment video.‚Å£
‚Å£
The shooter essentially issued ‚Äúa press kit for this type of information to get out,‚Äù says Mother Jones reporter Ali Breland, who joined fellow reporter Pema Levy in our Washington, DC, studio for the podcast. ‚ÄúThen [he] gave people following him a way to very clearly find his ideology.‚Äù‚Å£
‚Å£
Listen to the show, and subscribe, by clicking the link in our bio. (Image: Mark Baker/AP)

When Trump was asked if he considered white nationalism a rising threat around the world, he responded, casually, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt really,‚Äù and added, ‚Äúit‚Äôs a small group of people‚Äù committing these crimes. ‚Å£
‚Å£
The Christchurch shooter left behind a manifesto rife with the kind of online rhetoric associated with the resurgent white nationalist movements that have taken hold in the US, Europe, and beyond.‚Å£ But if anything, the massacre that left 50 people dead in New Zealand last week highlights the white nationalist movement, as well as its dark online ecosystem, is not just an American phenomenon‚Äîit‚Äôs an interconnected global ideology. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Numbers don't lie: Last year, every single extremist murder in the United States was committed by a white supremacist or far-right extremist, according to the Anti-Defamation League‚Äôs annual report on extremist killings. In 2017, murders committed by white supremacists more than doubled from the previous year.‚Å£
‚Å£
Mother Jones chatted with @nytimes columnist Wjahat Ali, who has written extensively on extremism, in hopes of understanding more about this global movement. Click the link in our bio to read the conversation.‚Å£

After a 7.8-magnitude earthquake devastated their home in Kathmandu in 2015, Nepal, Keshav Raj Bhattarai and his wife came to the United States. ‚Å£
That June, the Obama administration announced that Nepalis were eligible for Temporary Protected Status, a special legal protection that allows people from certain countries grappling with the aftermath of a natural disaster or other catastrophic event to live in the US. Bhattarai and his wife promptly applied, becoming two of about 15,000 Nepalis to obtain the legal status.‚Å£
‚Å£
That all changed abruptly in April 2018, when the Department of Homeland Security announced it would be ending TPS for Nepal, effective June 24, 2019. It's part of a larger move by the Trump admin, which is suspending TPS for six of the 10 countries that are currently recognized, upending the lives of more than 300,000 people. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Now Bhattarai is one of eight plaintiffs named in a class action suit to stop the Trump administration. Click the link in our bio to read more.‚Å£

From the #MeToo movement to the continued fight for workplace equity and reproductive justice, we are in a moment of reckoning. As a society, we're confronting America's history of gender inequality and how it affects our everyday lives. Now, ahead of the 2020 presidential election, we want to understand how we can build a better future.

Women in the media are pivotal in shaping and amplifying the narrative of this critical moment. So as we gear up for this momentous election, we'll bring together some of today's leading journalists to tackle the biggest questions before us: How is the media industry changing as a result of women's voices? How do media narratives influence the way we think about women and power?

Join an extraordinary panel, moderated by Mother Jones' Jamilah King, as we discuss the challenges‚Äîand hope‚Äîof achieving a more equal conversation.

‚Ä¢ Imara Jones, creator and host, The Last Sip on Free Speech TV

Thursday, April 11, 2019 at 7pm
Tishman Auditorium
63 5th Avenue, New York, NY

The ‚ÄúFlorida shuffle" is a cycle wherein recovering addicts are wooed aggressively by rehabs and freelance ‚Äúpatient brokers‚Äù in an effort to fill beds and collect insurance money. The brokers, often current or former drug users, troll for customers on social media, at Narcotics Anonymous meetings, and on the streets of treatment hubs such as the Florida coast and Southern California.

These rehab centers are fairly widespread, according to experts, and exist in a quasi-medical realm where evidence-based care is rare, licensed medical staffers are optional, conflicts of interest are rampant, and regulation is stunningly lax. And to no surprise, they can often have horrifying effects on not only the addicts themselves, but on the families of those struggling with addiction as well.

Mother Jones reporter Julia Lurie takes you into this insane world where those promising a release from addiction are also supplying it; where companies pay people to use heroin, and families‚Äîlike Becki Sarnicky's above‚Äîare left to pick up the pieces. Click the link in our bio to read the full nine-month-long investigation.
(üì∏: Bryan Anselm/Redux for Mother Jones)

‚ÄúI could do the wall over a longer period of time,‚Äù Trump told reporters earlier this month. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt need to do this, but I‚Äôd rather do it much faster.‚Äù And so by his own admission, Trump declared a national emergency at the southern border to turbo-charge a border wall that Congress refused to fund‚Äîand that a majority of Americans don't want.‚Å£
‚Å£
In the rush to build his ‚Äúbig, beautiful‚Äù wall, Trump may have actually invited more backlash and oversight from Congress and the states. House Democrats have already introduced a bill to reverse the declaration and 16 states filed a lawsuit challenging Trump's authority.‚Å£
‚Å£
And there's a serious question that needs to be asked first: Can Trump even divert the funds he identified in the first place? (The White House is reportedly planning to steer billions of dollars away from the Pentagon and Treasury.) To reprogram funds from one division to another requires direct approval from senior lawmakers of both parties. Click the link in our bio to read more about all the obstacles Trump has in front of him when it comes to the wall.‚Å£

"Slave labor powered the White House kitchen and nourished our presidents," says Adrian Miller, an historian and former adviser to President Bill Clinton. It's a practice that dated back to before the White House even existed, to when George Washington maintained his executive manse in Philadelphia.‚Å£
‚Å£
But Pennsylvania‚Äôs ban on slavery lead the first President of the United States to engage in some very shady behavior. The state‚Äôs law ‚Äúfreed any enslaved person who stayed on Pennsylvania soil for longer than six continuous months,‚Äù Miller writes, ‚ÄúTo skirt the law, Washington decided to send all of his slaves back to Mount Vernon every time the six-month deadline was about to toll. They would stay at the plantation for a few weeks and then return to Philadelphia to restart the ‚Äòfreedom clock.'‚Äù‚Å£
‚Å£

On the long list of worst places to deal with a period, jail hovers near the top. When Christine Kolba was detained for a drug charge in the San Mateo County jail, she found that out first hand. Unable to afford the $6.99 box of tampons in the commissary‚Äîthe free pads from the facility didn‚Äôt stick properly to the papery underwear she‚Äôd been issued‚ÄîKolba was left with little to no options. In a meeting with her attorney, Paula Canny, Kolba broke into tears as menstrual blood ran down her leg. ‚ÄúI was horrified for her,‚Äù Canny says.‚Å£
‚Å£
So Canny, a no-nonsense defense attorney with about 40 years experience, convinced the jail to give her client free tampons. But the incident left her wondering whether other jails were also stingy with sanitary products. Filing a public records request in almost every California county, she soon had an answer: Most jails in the state offered free pads but charged for tampons, often at prices far above market rate.‚Å£
‚Å£
In California state prisons, which hold convicted criminals, inmates are guaranteed access to free pads and tampons. The same is true at federal prisons around the country. Why, Canny wondered, should the situation be different at local jails, which often hold people awaiting trial who are too poor to afford bail? Click the link in our bio to read about the class-action lawsuit she filed in order to fight for women's access to tampons in jails.‚Å£
(üì∏:Mother Jones illustration; Shutterstock; Getty)‚Å£
#news #politics #menstruation #womensrights‚Å£

When Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.) and Sen. Ed Markey (D-Mass.) introduced the Green New Deal resolution, it tackled a wide variety of issues with detail. ‚Å£‚Å£‚Å£
The GND called for a ‚Äú10-year national mobilization‚Äù to ‚Äúeliminate pollution and greenhouse gas emissions from the agricultural sector‚Äù by ‚Äúsupporting family farming,‚Äù ‚Äúinvesting in sustainable farming and land use practices that increase soil health,‚Äù and ‚Äúbuilding a more sustainable food system that ensures universal access to healthy food.‚Äù In other words: not many specifics.‚Å£‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£‚Å£
But what if that's the point? Ocasio-Cortez and Markey‚Äôs idea is to generate an upswell of grassroots support for policies that aren‚Äôt feasible under the current administration and Senate leadership‚Äîbut might soon be if the political tides change. So rather than go about it in a traditional way‚Äîa congressperson proposing ‚Äúpolitically feasible‚Äù or ‚Äúpassable‚Äù policies and then trying to push them through‚Äîthey're taking it to the public. $198,000. That's how much the the nine Democrats selected by Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) to serve on the Select Committee on the Climate Crisis received from fossil fuel industry political action committees in the 2018 election cycle.

For two years, before she would head off to her full-time job as a web developer, Ursula Wing would fill orders that had been submitted through her website, dropping a piece of inexpensive jewelry into a mailer with a return address for ‚ÄúFatima‚Äôs Bead Basket.‚Äù And tucked behind a hidden panel taped inside were one tablet of mifepristone and four tablets of misoprostol‚Äîabortion pills.

Wing didn't think of herself as an activist. She began this work because she needed money to pay legal fees during a protracted custody dispute with her former partner. In 2012, she had written on her blog, the "Macrobiotic Stoner," about terminating her own pregnancy with pills she‚Äôd bought online, and women regularly posted comments asking for help to do the same. So in May 2016, Wing launched a ‚Äúsecret bodega.‚Äù Over the next two years, she would serve more than 2,000 customers.

While filling out the orders, Wing corresponded with the women she sold to‚Äîa teenager afraid to tell her parents she was pregnant; a woman hiding her abortion from an abusive partner; another who wrote that she wore the necklace included in her package to remind her of what she had been through. Wing was, as one woman put it, doing ‚ÄúGod‚Äôs work.‚Äù Then one day the FDA showed up.

Click the link in our bio to read Wing's story.
(üì∏: Alvaro Dominguez)
#abortion #news #politics #women

While the field of Democratic candidates running for president in 2020 is still taking shape, so far all the contenders have agreed on one policy: Cash from corporate PACs is bad. To date, Sens. Kamala Harris (D-Calif.), Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.), Cory Booker (D-N.J.), and Kirstin Gillibrand (D-N.Y.), as well as Rep. Tulsi Gabbard (D-Hawaii), have all vowed not to take corporate PAC dollars for their 2020 campaigns.

There's no legal definition for what makes a corporate PAC, the general consensus is that it's a political action committee that is directly connected to a for-profit business. But here's the thing: Corporate PACs aren't big players in the campaign finance world for presidential elections. That means candidates aren't really giving up that much money. Nihal Krishan explores how this may be a broader message about how these candidates will approach money in politics if elected. Link in bio.

#OnThisDayInHistory Nelson Mandela was released from prison after 27 years.

Mandela had been sentenced to life in prison, convicted along with several other African National Congress members for trying to fight back against the white minority that ran South Africa. For the first 18 years of his sentence, Mandela was confined to a small cell with no bed or plumbing, forced to do hard labor. He was allowed a visitor for 30 minutes just once a year.

After his release, Mandela returned to the ANC and worked with SA President F.W. de Klerk to dismantle the racist apartheid system, eventually becoming president.
(üì∏: Aftonbladet/IBL/ZUMA Press)
#history

Before a vaccination program was introduced in in 1963, the United States had between 3 and 4 million measles cases annually. Now, outbreaks of the disease are rare.

But on January 25, Gov. Jay Inslee of Washington declared a state of emergency after a measles outbreak sickened 31 people in the southwest corner of his state. All but one of the patients were children, most under the age of 10. Public health officials said they expected the number of cases to rise in the coming weeks, and as of February 1, 43 cases had been confirmed across the state.

To stop a measles outbreak, ‚Äúit may be that you need a vaccination coverage rate as high as 95 percent,‚Äù explains Matthew Daley, a pediatrician at Kaiser Permanente Colorado. That‚Äôs because of "herd", or community, immunity: When enough people in an area are vaccinated against a disease, it loses its ability to spread. So what happened in Washington? Through a combination of laws and the rise in anti-vaxer rhetoric, just 85 percent of kids met all the school-entry immunization requirements.

Click the link in our bio to read the full report.
(üì∏: Jack Kurtz/ZUMA Press)
#vaccination #news #politics #measles

This past weekend marked the 40-year anniversary of this iconic photo of Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping during his historic 1979 trip to the US.

His visit was a pivotal moment in how Americans viewed Communist China in the late 70s, after the two countries officially normalized relations. The photograph of Deng donning a ten-gallon hat during a visit to a Texas rodeo came to represent the leader‚Äôs good humor and clever diplomatic theatrics, which in turn set the stage for increased cooperation between China and the US.

On the latest episode of The Mother Jones Podcast: The State of the Union address. What exactly is the point?

Meet pediatrician Dr. Nadine Burke Harris. A decade ago she worked at a clinic in San Francisco‚Äôs poverty-stricken Bayview neighborhood. A study of more than 17,000 patients found that those who had experienced more so-called Adverse Childhood Experiences‚Äîthings like physical or emotional abuse, exposure to domestic violence, neglect, and parental substance abuse‚Äîwere far more likely to experience a host of physical and psychological ailments down the line. In 2011, Burke Harris founded Bayview‚Äôs Center for Youth Wellness, a pediatric clinic where clinicians also study the effects of childhood trauma and develop ways to reverse the damage.

When a sperm whale carcass washed up the coast of Oahu, Hawaii, in early January, disposing of its remains shouldn't have been a big issue. ‚†Ä
But by the end of the week, the carcass had drifted back into the shallows where it was (illegally) climbed upon by local swimmers, who also reportedly removed its teeth. Forty-eight hours later, officials towed the whale out to sea once more.

Picture this: The Alaska Peninsula, a secluded national refuge protecting millions of seabirds, grizzly bears, and caribou. Now picture this: Seven noisy helicopters swooping in 80 times over two days last summer, and landing on the narrow isthmus where animals nest, feed, and migrate.

Then-Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke, prodded by Donald Trump, ordered the surprise helicopter survey to prepare to bulldoze a 12-mile road through the refuge‚Äôs federally protected wilderness. Evading Congress, Zinke engineered a deal that handed a swath of Izembek‚Äôs wilderness to Aleut Natives so their cannery town of King Cove can build the final 12 miles of a 37-mile gravel road to the Cold Bay Airport.

In crafting the deal, Zinke rejected the warnings of his department‚Äôs scientists that concluded allowing a road through the refuge would ‚Äúlead to significant degradation of irreplaceable ecological resources.‚Äù Read the full investigation by clicking the link in our bio.

In March 2017, the Trump administration announced an addition of a question about US citizenship to the 2020 census. Many quickly noted that this could endanger immigrant-heavy communities. The census is responsible for determining how $675 billion in federal funding is allocated, how much representation states receive, and how political districts are drawn.

Quickly following the decision, 17 states, the ACLU, and a few other immigrant rights groups filed a lawsuit claiming that it would depress response rates from immigrants, imperil the accuracy of the census, and shift political power to areas with fewer immigrants.

They won, for now.

This week, Judge Jesse Furman of the Southern District of New York agreed with the plaintiffs, but the decision is likely to be appealed to the Supreme Court, which could reinstate the question in time for it to be included on the 2020 census. Click the link in our bio to read Ari Berman's latest.
(üì∏: Jeff Malet/Newscom via ZUMA Press)

In a preliminary estimate out this week says carbon dioxide emissions climbed 3.4 percent last year, the second largest increase in two decades, and it looks like the golden green state of California is part of the problem.

Also to thank? An unusually cold spell last winter led people to turn up their furnaces, and after years of modest growth, the US economy picked up in 2018. At the peak of one of the worst recorded droughts in California history, Jeff Collins had his lawn ripped out in 2015. He opted for wood chips and Sago palms instead. ‚ÄúI just got tired of trying to keep the grass green,‚Äù he said.

California‚Äôs lawns receded during past droughts: Homeowners reduced their water use by adding flower beds and walkways where turf had previously been. This last drought was different: Thousands of homeowners took advantage of ‚Äúcash for grass‚Äù programs to remove their lawns entirely.

As Julie Saare-Edmonds, a senior environmental scientist with the landscape program of the California Department of Water Resources, put it: ‚ÄúWhy would you want to mow a really tiny yard? December 28th, 1973: President Richard Nixon, a Republican, signed a piece of monumental environmental legislation, the Endangered Species Act, into law.

The act now protects more than 1,500 species and remains one of the most powerful environmental laws on the books. Since its passage, several species, including the brown pelican, Louisiana black bear, and, of course, the bald eagle, have recovered. But what was then hailed as a historic bipartisan achievement, has become deeply political. In the 45 years since its signing, conservatives have gone to extraordinary lengths to weaken the Endangered Species Act for the sake of economic growth‚Äîand the Trump administration has carried on the task of environmental deregulation with renewed vigor.

Jackie Flynn Mogensen dives into the ESA on it's 45th anniversary. Click on the link in our bio to read more.
(üì∏: Leonardo Prest Mercon Ro/Getty)

Raising fears of fraud to make it harder for people to vote didn‚Äôt start with this administration, or even in the past 100 years. In some ways, Moira is like a lot of six-year-olds: She loves bubble baths, giggling with friends, and vanilla frosting. But in other ways‚Äîones you notice as soon as you meet her‚ÄîMoira is different.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
She can‚Äôt sit up and has only ever said a few words due to an incredibly rare disease called pontocerebellar hypoplasia Type 2A‚Äîan inherited mutation that interferes with the growth of the cerebellum, the brain hub that coordinates muscle movements, and the pons, part of the brain stem. She has frequent seizures and poor muscle control, and can‚Äôt swallow. For the rest of her life, Moira will need regular care at home and occasional emergency hospital care. And yet, Moira is a miracle of modern medicine. Had she been born a century ago, she likely would have starved to death as an infant, or succumbed to a deadly seizure. She is one of about 400,000 ‚Äúmedically complex‚Äù American children‚Äîkids who have serious health issues‚Äîwho, thanks to modern technology, can survive past infancy and even lead long, fulfilling lives.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
It‚Äôs easy to guess at why states deny care to children like Moira: They don‚Äôt want to pay for it. And with Medicaid funding in many states under threat, it means that many children like Moira are also threatened. Melinda Wenner Moyer's piece for our January/February issue is about how North Carolina is aiming to gut Moira's health care, with the Trump administration's help. Click through the link in our bio to read the story.‚†Ä

After an 11th-hour government-funding agreement collapsed amid President Donald Trump‚Äôs demands for a border wall, the government partially shut down at midnight on Friday.

Earlier last week, the Senate overwhelmingly approved a bipartisan bill to keep the government funded into February. That legislation did not include border wall funding. But on Thursday, Trump threatened to veto the measure, and House Republicans voted it down. The House then added $5 billion in border wall funding to the bill, and passed it Thursday night. But as expected, the measure died in the Senate on Friday, and lawmakers were unable to cobble together another last-minute deal.

More than 420,000 government workers will continue to work without pay during the shutdown. Another 380,000 workers will be furloughed, meaning they will not work or get paid during the shutdown‚Äîand there‚Äôs no guarantee that workers will be able to recoup losses if it doesn‚Äôt pass. Click through the link in our bio to read more.

The Green New Deal is the most popular policy hardly anyone has heard of yet. In the waning years of the Obama administration, a new generation of black activists emerged with a simple refrain for the streets and the tweets: black lives matter, a cry that would go on to spark an international organization led by black women, several lists of policy demands, and a vast ecosystem of activists dedicated to transformative change. One of the most prominent voices to emerge from that era was that of DeRay Mckesson.

An educator by trade, he famously ditched his day job and drove several hours from Minnesota to Ferguson, Missouri, in 2014 after the fatal police shooting of Michael Brown, Jr., an unarmed 18-year-old black man. As Ferguson‚Äôs mostly black residents rose up in protest over the killing, Mckesson, along with a swell of black activists and journalists, joined them and took to the streets. Since then, that ecosystem of black activists has gone on to advocate for systemic change in a myriad of ways. Mckesson‚Äôs high-profile approach has included running for mayor of Baltimore, his hometown.

More recently, he published a book called ‚ÄúOn the Other Side of Freedom: The Case for Hope,‚Äù in which he tells stories from the frontlines of activism and gives a stirring account of how his identity as a black, gay man in America prepared him for one of the most contentious moments in recent American history. Our host Jamilah King caught up with him on the newest episode of the Mother Jones Podcast. Click the link in our bio to listen/read.
(üì∏: Patrick Semansky/AP)
#blacklivesmatter #news #politics #podcast

Patrick Murphy didn‚Äôt say he was innocent. In the summer of 1999, when Murphy, a member of the Muscogee (Creek) Nation of eastern Oklahoma, killed his girlfriend‚Äôs ex-lover, also a Creek member, he soon confessed the crime to his girlfriend and cousin. And after he was brought to court, Murphy, then 30, was sentenced to death in 2000.

But since his sentencing, Murphy has put up a fight that has spanned nearly two decades and both state and federal court. So far, it has kept him alive. Murphy‚Äôs case, which was heard by the US Supreme Court late last month, has also burst open questions about land and tribal sovereignty in Oklahoma and it could, depending on how the court rules, affect hundreds or even thousands of Native Americans already convicted in the state.

On Tuesday, the NAACP launched a weeklong boycott of Facebook in response to two congressionally commissioned reports that illustrate how Russian trolls on the platform not only targeted people of color, but made stoking racial tensions one of their top priorities. The NAACP and other racial justice groups have been frustrated over Facebook‚Äôs failure to address racism on its platform and improve its internal staff diversity for years. In the wake of the reports‚Äô Monday release, they say the company should be held responsible for allowing the spread of racially divisive and racist content.

The reports were both commissioned by the Senate Intelligence Committee and conducted with data that tech companies provided to Congress. Their findings detail how Facebook missed social media manipulation attempts as Russian trolls misled and harassed minority users and launched a campaign to suppress the votes of African Americans. Russian trolls singled out black users more than other communities, according to Ren√©e DiResta, co-author of one of the reports, saying they ‚Äúbuilt a highly interlinked ecosystem‚Äîa mirage of black media.‚Äù Ali Breland, our Mother Jones reporter on internet disinformation has the full report. In an internal memo circulated within the Interior Department earlier this year, government scientists issued a stark warning: The Trump administration‚Äôs plans to allow oil exploration in Alaska‚Äôs Arctic National Wildlife Refuge (ANWR) could further jeopardize the region‚Äôs already fragile polar bear population. Written by the head of the state‚Äôs US Fish and Wildlife Service office, the document noted that the threat posed to the bears could make it legally challenging for the agency to authorize a series of seismic surveys of the area‚Äôs petroleum reserves. The memo, obtained by Mother Jones from a source outside the Alaska office, describes its finding as a ‚Äúpreliminary analysis‚Äù based on ‚Äúinformation currently available to us.‚Äù That analysis contrasts sharply with the administration‚Äôs public rhetoric suggesting that the project would be harmless and should therefore be quickly approved. Despite the Fish and Wildlife Service document warning of serious environmental and legal obstacles to the project, the administration has continued to downplay the impact that seismic surveys could have on the refuge.

The Trump administration unveiled a proposal on Tuesday to weaken federal protections for millions of acres of streams, wetlands, and waterways that will likely affect the drinking water for more than one-third of Americans. While the Trump administration specifically targeted the 2015 Obama-era rule known as the Clean Water Rule, the proposal goes further in rolling back environmental oversight than has occurred under any president since Ronald Reagan. The EPA and the US Army Corps of Engineers proposal, now open to 60 days of public comment, dramatically restricts which bodies of water fall under the 1972 Clean Water Act regulations.

A common talking point for conservatives against the act has been to claim that the EPA wanted to regulate ‚Äúpuddles‚Äù after it rained on farmland. But in some areas, the so-called puddles‚Äînow exempt from the Clean Water Act‚Äîinvolved over half the water flowing into major rivers, explains Blan Holman, managing attorney in Southern Environmental Law Center. ‚ÄúWhen you shrink that definition, you‚Äôve now reduced the universe of waters that are protected,‚Äù Holman tells Mother Jones. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre concerned about drinking water sources, you need to be concerned about what‚Äôs flowing into those reservoirs and those rivers.‚Äù Our environmental reporter Rebecca Leber has it all, just click through the link in our bio to read.
(üì∏: Cultura via ZUMA Press)
#news #politics #climatechange #trump #environment

In late 2016, as Donald Trump was readying to move into the White House, Elliott Broidy, then one of the Republican Party‚Äôs top fundraisers, was working on a deal to gain control of what a business partner called ‚Äúbillions of dollars in oil & gas, and mining assets‚Äù in Angola. While he was trying to pull together this gigantic venture‚Äîas well as beginning another project to provide intelligence services to the Angolan government‚ÄîBroidy used his clout to hook up top Angolan government officials with members of Congress and the Trump administration. Broidy is no longer a power player wielding sway in the Republican cosmos.

Earlier this year, he faced a series of stories that raised questions about his business dealings (which included ventures with the governments of Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Romania, and the Republic of Congo) and alleged influence peddling, which were all based on emails hacked from his personal accounts. After helping the GOP regain the White House, Broidy has become a poster child for Trump-era corruption. 
He has generated headlines about multiple controversies‚Äîpersonal, political, and business. And there could be more Broidy stories to come. David Corn explains how Broidy did business, just click through the link in our bio to read the full article.

A report made public this week by the Pentagon‚Äôs internal watchdog found that the Air Force neglected to prevent Devin Kelley, a veteran with a domestic violence conviction, from acquiring a firearm several times before he killed 26 people in a Texas church last November. In November 2012, Kelley pleaded guilty in a military court-martial to assaulting his wife and toddler stepson, a conviction that should have prevented Kelley from purchasing a variant of the AR-15 he used in the shooting. But because the Air Force failed to submit his fingerprints to the FBI‚Äîas Defense Department policy requires‚ÄîKelley did not appear in a background-check database.

The National Rifle Association spent $30 million to help elect Donald Trump‚Äîmore than any other independent conservative group. Most of that went to TV advertising, but a political message loses its power if it fails to reach the right audience at the right time, which is why for the complex and consequential task of placing ads in key markets across the nation in 2016, the NRA turned to a media strategy firm called Red Eagle Media.

One element of Red Eagle‚Äôs work for the NRA involved purchasing a slate of 52 ad slots on WVEC, the ABC affiliate in Norfolk, Virginia, in late October 2016. The ads targeted adults aged 35 to 64 and aired on local news programs and syndicated shows like "Jeopardy!" and "Wheel of Fortune;" adults that Red Eagle had described as ‚Äúanti-Hillary‚Äù and ‚Äúpro-Trump.‚Äù The Trump campaign pursued a strikingly similar advertising strategy. Shortly after the Red Eagle purchase, as Election Day loomed, it bought 33 ads on the same station, set to air during the same week. Red Eagle and the firm Trump's campaign hired to buy the ads appear at first glance to be separate. The issue, however, is that each firm is closely connected to a major conservative media-consulting firm called National Media Research, Planning and Placement. In fact, the three are so closely intertwined, that both the NRA‚Äôs and the Trump campaign‚Äôs ad buys were authorized by the same person. ‚ÄúThis is very strong evidence, if not proof, of illegal coordination,‚Äù said Larry Noble, a former general counsel for the Federal Election Commission. ‚ÄúThis is the heat of the general election, and the same person is acting as an agent for the NRA and the Trump campaign.‚Äù Mike Spies breaks down the complex web that points at illegal campaign coordination, click through our bio to read.
(üì∏: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press via ZUMA Wire)
#nra #guncontrol #news #politics #trump

Some 250 million years ago, back when the world was still comprised of the single, supercontinent Pangea, a geologic catastrophe wiped out nearly every single ocean-dwelling creature on the planet: fish, crustaceans, mollusks, even microbes. As few as 4 percent of ocean species survived, but despite the magnitude of the disaster, only in the past two decades have paleontologists found clues of it in the fossil record‚Äîand discovered it coincided with a massive volcanic event in modern-day Siberia.

There was a major blind spot in scientists‚Äô understanding of the Great Dying: While they knew about both the eruption and extinction, it was unclear how the two were related, and what exactly caused the massive die-off. Now, a new study published last week in the journal Science suggests the culprit of the Great Dying was likely something the planet is all too familiar with today: global warming, and, as a result, high ocean temperatures and a loss of oxygen in the water. Understanding the planet‚Äôs turbulent past is an important thing, and crucial for our understanding of what happens next.

Jackie Flynn Mogensen breaks down the science: click through the link in our bio to read the full report.
(üì∏: Omar Marques/SOPA Images via ZUMA Wire)
#climatechange #protest #news #politics #news

French police clashed with ‚Äúyellow vest‚Äù protesters in Paris over the weekend as country-wide demonstrations against President Emmanuel Macron‚Äôs leadership and economic policies continued for the fourth consecutive weekend. Tens of thousands of people took to the streets across the country, and nearly 1,000 protesters have been arrested so far, according to the Associated Press. The so-called ‚Äúyellow vest‚Äù movement, named for the bright hazard vest every French driver is required to keep in the car, began in mid-November when almost 300,000 French citizens took to the streets to demand a drop in gas prices and relief from President Macron‚Äôs planned fuel tax.

The protests have broadened into general anger against the declining standard of living and dislike of France‚Äôs centrist president. As of Monday, the President announced that he had heard the protesters message and is set to release new details of an economic plan in response on Tuesday, which includes cuts to taxes on overtime pay and a raise in the national minimum wage.

A school district in Rhode Island wants its lunch money back‚Äîand has hired a private debt collection agency to go after parents to get it. Transworld Systems, a private debt collector, has been hired by the chief operating officer of schools in Cranston, RI, a decision it announced recently in a letter sent to parents in the district. To put that in perspective: A week‚Äôs worth of lunches in Cranston elementary schools costs $12.50. In middle and high school, that price goes up to $16.25. According to the school‚Äôs ‚Äúunpaid lunch policy,‚Äù reported by ThinkProgress, students who do not have money for lunch can charge up to five hot meals. If at that point they do not repay their debt, they are fed a pack of ‚Äúsunny butter sandwich, fruit, and milk‚Äù instead‚Äîbut still charged the full lunch price.

In his letter, the Cranston school district COO, Raymond L. Votto Jr., argued that the step to hire a debt collector was a financial necessity for the district that has amassed an unpaid lunch balance of $45,859 since September. ‚ÄúThe District lunch program cannot continue to lose revenue,‚Äù he wrote, and on January 2, parents who do not pay‚Äîor who can't afford to‚Äîcould then be reported to national credit bureaus, affecting their credit score.

Madison Pauly has the whole report. Click through the link in our bio to read.

From Bakersfield to Stockton, the San Joaquin Valley in California stretches over 250 miles and comprises the southern two-thirds of the storied Central Valley‚Äîthe land of Big Agriculture. The Central Valley is a plowed-over promised land covering seven million acres of irrigated fields that generate more than $17 billion a year in crops, with the vast majority coming from three San Joaquin Valley counties, a region that that supplies a quarter of the food found on American plates.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
It's also awash in air pollution. Millions of beef and dairy cattle, millions of acres of dusty crops, and the truck traffic generate fine airborne particles that linger and swirl in what is, in effect, a gigantic, pollution-trapping bowl bounded by mountains. Add in use of wood stoves and barbecue pits, the second-hand smog blowing into the valley from cities to the west and the north, and emissions from some of the densest oil fields in the lower 48 states, and the result is some of the worst air pollution in the nation. It‚Äôs a burden that Shirley Hinslea, a resident of Kern County, knows well, diligently checking the air quality information every day before deciding whether her 6-year-old daughter Kira, who suffers from severe asthma, can leave their home without a mask.‚†Ä
‚†Ä

In mid-October, a group of asylum seekers met in San Pedro Sula, Honduras, to form a group with a common destination: the US-Mexico border. As the caravan moved through Mexico City, photographer @brett_gundlock set up a simple white backdrop in a temporary encampment, where the group was resting for a few days. Gundlock then followed the group north, all the way to Mexicali where many are now currently stuck‚Äîwaiting to apply for asylum or weighing other options, including returning to their home countries. 
This weekend we will be highlighting Gundlock's work, which includes photos, videos, and testimonials. The reality of the dire situation quickly becomes inescapable: the future for these migrants and asylum seekers is as uncertain today as the day they started their journey.

This is Kenia Arias who had to leave her six-month-old baby at home, and she said gangs killed members of her family. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very hard to leave the family, and yes, it really hurts, and one does the impossible to seek the American dream, to seek a better future, a better life, because in our country, you cannot even live,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThey want to kill you for nothing. Even then it is difficult to leave the country where you were raised, where you have spent all your life. It is very hard, but we have to go forward.‚Äù
#immigration #photography #news #politics #humanitarian

With Paul Ryan leaving Congress and power shifting in the House, Democrats plan to prioritize a bill that will require a background check for every gun sale, according to multiple sources. The legislation represents an aggressive shift in strategy by Democrats and their gun reform allies, who in previous years tended to pursue more modest approaches. Since the 2012 Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting that left 26 dead, attempts to strengthen background checks have languished at the federal level. ‚ÄúThe American people are on our side,‚Äù says Robin Lloyd, director of government affairs at Giffords, which was founded by former Arizona congresswoman and mass shooting survivor, Gabby Giffords. To take such a hard line with no track record of success could be a risky move, but gun control advocates point to the 2018 midterms as proof the political calculus on guns has shifted. A record 97 percent of people in one poll voiced support for universal background checks in the wake of the February shooting at Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida, and many Democratic congressional candidates successfully flipped red seats while running on platforms calling for stricter gun regulations. Read more by clicking through the link in our bio.
(üì∏: Emilee Mcgovern/SOPA Images via ZUMA Wire)

A few years ago, Evan Mills' 15-year-old son wanted to get into gaming by building his own computer, and so the two of them struck a deal: Mills would help build the computer if his son helped him measure how much energy it was consuming. Mills is an energy expert who is a senior scientist at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, so understands what is involved. ‚ÄúWe had a power meter and all the tools. And when the results came in‚Äîit was jaw dropping.‚Äù In 2015 they released a research paper, which then landed Mills $1.4 million in grant money to continue the research. Last week Mills released another report building off his 2015 findings, and the results were staggering. Mills and his team found that in the United States, games consumes $6 billion worth of electricity annually, and globally, PC gamers use about 75 billion kilowatt hours of electricity a year‚Äîequivalent to the output of 25 electric power plants. (And that doesn't include console games.) But it's not all doom and gloom.

Check out the rest of his findings, and what the future of green gaming could look like by clicking through the link in our bio.

Nearly 4 million babies are born in the United States every year, but there‚Äôs still a lot we still don‚Äôt know about how they come into the world. For example, scientists still can't explain why for two women who are roughly the same age and have all sorts of demographic variables in common, labor is quick and easy for one and long and difficult for the other. Many of the guidelines that doctors still use to assess how childbirth progresses‚Äîhow long each phase takes or when an obstetrician should call for a c-section‚Äîare based on studies conducted more than 50 years ago. But the data to answer these questions probably now exists in the form of decades of electronic medical records from hospitals around the world.
A big challenge: scientists aren't sure how best to manage data sets of that size. Our reporter Kiera Butler takes you inside the new ways scientists are studying childbirth in her newest piece. Click through the link in our bio to read.

A ‚Äútent city‚Äù for migrant children in Texas has been operating for months with staff who never completed the required FBI background checks, according to a federal watchdog memo released this week. The facility, called Tornilla, was opened in June, at the height of Trump's family separation policy, and was initially supposed to remain open for 30 days and accommodate 1,800 minors. But, as the crisis at the border continues, the Department of Health and Human Services announced that it would triple the size of the facility and keep it open till the end of the year. The new report found that the non-profit company that runs Tornillo wasn't conducting the minimal background checks, which included checking for "child abuse and neglect" in employees' backgrounds. You've heard the stereotype: Canadians, bless ‚Äôem, are the politest of people. Now some actual data to back that up. In the late 1990s, pediatricians in Boston and several other major US cities began comparing notes about a disturbing trend amongst their low-income patients: More of them were struggling to gain weight‚Äîa condition known as ‚Äúfailure to thrive‚Äù‚Äîand lagging on important developmental milestones. Chief Justice John Roberts rejected the notion that voting discrimination was still ‚Äúpervasive‚Äù or ‚Äúrampant,‚Äù asserting that ‚Äúour country has changed.‚Äù The midterms were a perfect illustration of just how wrong he was. Sendy Karina Ferrera Amaya has spent the three months since her 1-year-old daughter Liah was taken into U.S. custody, trying to get her released from foster care for unaccompanied immigrant children. She's doing her best to prove to the US government that she is Liah‚Äôs mother, and a good one. She spoke with ProPublica about that experience, shedding light on the bureaucratic maze that families encounter when trying to retrieve a child from the immigrant foster system run by the Department of Health and Human Services. She has provided US officials with her Honduran ID, birth certificates, passport, bank statements, proofs of address, fingerprints, extensive documentation for her fianc√©, phone contacts and identification for family in Honduras, call logs of her past video calls with her daughter‚Äîeven ultrasounds, doctors‚Äô records and a photo of matching hospital bracelets from the day Liah was born a year ago. Ferrera‚Äôs daughter is one of 11,800 unaccompanied minors in HHS care, many of whom are older kids who traveled alone to reunite with relatives or family friends here. This story was originally published by ProPublica. Read more about Ferrera's case and the HHS on http://motherjones.com #HHS #deportation #familyseparation #migrationpolicy #trumpadministration

Four-term incumbent Republican Rep. Martha Roby has defeated former Rep. Bobby Bright yesterday to officially clinch a spot on the November ballot. Roby‚Äôs opponents were eager to use her lack of support for the president against her in the primary race to position themselves as true, dyed-in-the-wool Trump Republicans. However, last month, Roby managed to secure the endorsements of Trump and Vice President Mike Pence. After yesterday's victory, Roby will now face off against political newcomer Tabitha Isner, the Democratic nominee who has served as a minister in the Christian Church. Amid the hottest summer on record for various regions across the globe, a team of researchers affiliated with the United Nations released a report calling on entrepreneurs and politicians to fund affordable ways for people to cool off without hurting the planet. Using 52 of the world‚Äôs warmest countries as a baseline, researchers classified cooling challenges in each country into four groups based on cultural and class lines. The report reserves special attention for the more than 2 billion people who are able to afford their own air conditioner, but who are perhaps not affluent enough to splurge on an expensive cooling device that might be more efficient. And because some studies have predicted the agreement could boost manufacturing jobs and increase American exports, an unlikely cross-section of Republican lawmakers and business leaders have publicly supported the agreement. The group behind the report, Sustainable Energy for All, was founded in 2011 by former UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon, who has said the Trump administration‚Äôs decision to exit the Paris climate agreement caused ‚Äúserious damage.‚Äù Read more on motherjones.com #coolingsystems #heatwave #climatechange #developingcountries #trumpadministration (üì∏: Sustainable Energy for All)

The Trump Administration plans to deport even more legal immigrants: In a memo made public July 5th, US Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS), the agency tasked with handling immigration benefits‚Äîthink work and student visas, green cards, and naturalization ceremonies‚Äîsaid it would now refer immigrants for deportation in a wider range of cases. The new memo gives USCIS officials the power to directly issue a Notice to Appear (NTA) in a broader range of circumstances, including evidence of a criminal offense or fraud in an applicant‚Äôs history, or if a case is denied and the applicant is found to be unlawfully present in the US. Further complicating this evolving landscape is a subsequent memo, issued July 13, that gives USCIS broad discretion to immediately deny any application without giving individuals the opportunity to submit further evidence or without having to notify them of the agency‚Äôs intent to deny the case. The NTA memo went into effect the day it was issued; the second memo will go into effect in September. Read more on motherjones.com #USCIS #deportation #Trumpadministration #immigration (üì∏: Bebeto Matthews/AP)

These new air sensors could revolutionize air pollution regulation: PurpleAir is a company that is placing air quality monitors across California‚Äôs San Joaquin Valley, run in part by the Central California Environmental Justice Network. The group has installed monitors in disadvantaged neighborhoods to measure how the area‚Äôs biomass plants interacts with the dozens of trucks that rumble through daily, pumping emissions into residents‚Äô lungs. Their findings could eventually reshape air-pollution regulation, as cheaper sensors are deployed to gather data in new places. Take western Colorado, where the environmental group Citizens for Clean Air has put up two dozen low-cost monitors around Grand Junction to supplement the two state-run monitors. This article was initially published by CityLab and appears on Mother Jones as part of the Climate Desk collaboration. Narwhals are sometimes called the ‚Äúunicorns of the sea.‚Äù But unlike unicorns, they happen to be real. Narwhals haven‚Äôt been in dire straits‚Äîlast year, the International Union for Conservation of Nature downgraded their status from ‚Äúnear threatened‚Äù to ‚Äúleast concern‚Äù‚Äîbut shipping traffic could be bad news for these whales, according to a recent report published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. Due to their inflexible summer habitats, Narwhals are often smack dab in the middle of shipping routes. They‚Äôve been beaten by guards and put in the hole, but now they‚Äôre suing: The feds have been locking up immigrant kids‚Äîwho have committed no crimes‚Äîin juvenile detention centers. These children report being awakened, without advanced notice or an explanation, during the early hours of morning at shelters and flown in shackles across the country to juvenile halls. Reveal and the Houston Chronicle have reported that some have been sent to psychiatric facilities, where they are forcibly held down and injected with powerful psychotropic drugs without their consent. A federal lawsuit was filed late last month in California by attorneys at the Center for Human Rights and Constitutional Law, the Immigration Law Clinic, and the National Center for Youth Law on behalf of five children from Mexico, El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras who have been detained and whose attorneys are seeking class-action status. The National Environmental Policy Act, commonly referred to as NEPA, dictates the environmental planning process for federal agencies. Any changes to the NEPA process could have far-reaching impacts on the vast public lands and infrastructure of the West. Now, it is being scrutinized by the Trump administration and could be targeted for reforms. The NEPA reform push traces political dividing lines, as pro-business and anti-regulation Republicans square off with environmental groups and conservation-minded Democrats hoping to preserve the law and implementation process. Caught between the vocal factions of each party are state governments and federal land managers arguing for a middle ground of limited reform. This article was initially published on High Country News and appears here as a part of the Climate Desk Collaboration. Read more about NEPA on motherjones.com #NEPA #conservatives #democrats #publiclands #environmentalissues #climatedesk

The Trump administration confirmed on Monday that it will not meet the deadline set by a federal judge for reuniting parents with their young children. To make matters worse, roughly 2,000 older children need to be reunited by the end of the month. Prosecutors are using Jailhouse informants, colloquially known as snitches, to send innocent people to death row: Snitches can be unreliable because the prosecution tempts them to offer testimony against the defendant with a number of enticing incentives such as a reduction in their sentences, for instance, or a transfer to a more desirable prison. According to the National Registry of Exonerations, a jailhouse snitch was used in 23 percent of death penalty cases where the defendant was later exonerated. Some states have enacted reforms. In 2017, Texas passed a law that would force prosecutors to disclose a host of data on jailhouse informants including what benefits they may be receiving for their testimony, and their history in speaking up about other cases. In other instances, civil liberties groups have filed lawsuits challenging the use of jailhouse informants. Read the case of Curtis Flowers and how he was saved by a snitch confessing when he was interviewed on America Public Media's "In the Dark" podcast. Read the story on Motherjones.com #jailhousesnitches #deathrow #incarceration #IntheDark

When Flint switched its water supply from Lake Huron to the Flint River in 2014, the residents of the mostly lower-income, black city almost immediately began noticing problems‚Äî the water's discoloration, unexplained rashes, and illnesses. It took another year-and-a-half for state officials to begin to acknowledge that something was seriously amiss, and that was only after a groundswell of community activism and local reporting shed light on the full extent of the lead-poisoning crisis. We spoke to Michigan journalist Anna Clark, whose book, The Poisoned City, focuses on the various public and private figures who became central to the Flint narrative, and also on the institutional factors that set the stage for the crisis. She also warns that the next water crisis could happen anywhere. Read the interview on motherjones.com #AnnaClark #Flint #watercrisis #Michigan #environmentalissues #environmentaljustice (üì∏: Jake May/The Flint Journal-MLive.com via AP)

The past seven days have set global heat milestones and sparked safety concerns from Quebec, where at least 18 people have died from the heat and humidity, to northern Siberia, home to the coldest town on Earth, which recorded temperatures ‚Äú40 degrees above normal‚Äù on Thursday. Last week‚Äôs weather is yet another example of how climate change has made the weather much more extreme. Nick Humphrey is a meteorologist and geoscientist in Lincoln, Nebraska, who runs the ‚ÄúOcean‚Äôs Wrath‚Äù blog and studies the nature of these events in relation to ocean storms and climate. We asked Humphrey to put the historically high temperatures in context of other heat waves and explain the ways in which climate change is responsible for an increasing number of extreme weather events. Read the interview on motherjones.com #Globalheat #climatechange #oceanswrath #heatwave #environmentalissues #climatedesk

Trade wars: On Friday, the United States plans to begin slapping a 25 percent tariff on $34 billion worth of goods from China, which has vowed to retaliate immediately with its own duties on US goods. Growers in corn and soybean country, United States‚Äô two biggest crops, have already been seeing a major slide in prices since May and now face billions of dollars in losses. The current slide comes at a perilous time for US farmers. They have about 179 million acres of the two crops growing in their fields‚Äîa combined land mass that is equal to nearly two Californias. To make a profit on these crops, farmers will have to make at least $4 per bushel on corn and $10.05 on soybeans for the 2018 harvest, a University of Illinois analysis found. Currently, the two commodities fetch $3.43 and $8.40, respectively. Meanwhile, vast portions of last years‚Äô bumper harvest remain unsold. Read more about Trump's trade war with China on motherjones.com #tradewars #tariffs #China #Trumpadministration #agriculture

Climate change is making it harder to revive damaged land: With climate change, landscape-level transformations are happening faster and becoming more extreme. As the West becomes warmer and drier, the idea of ‚Äúrecovery‚Äù is becoming increasingly unrealistic. Instead, ecologists attempt to help ecosystems transform, such as in northern New Mexico, where Gambel oaks may replace pine forest after a fire. This identity crisis is global. This year, at conferences from Iceland to Washington state, the Society for Ecological Restoration is grappling with the question of restoration versus transformation in response to climate change. Read about a specific case of restoration in the ecologically rich mountain ranges that dot southeastern Arizona and New Mexico and northern Sonora, Mexico, on motherjones.com. This article was initially published on High Country News and appears on Mother Jones as part of the Climate Desk collaboration. #ecology #climatechange #ecologicalrestoration  #Sonorandesert #environmentalissues (üì∏: Will Seberger/ZUMAPRESS.com)

California‚Äôs vineyard workers already faced long hours, low pay, and harsh conditions. Then came Trump‚Äôs immigration crackdown: Over the last few decades, millions of Mexicans have come north to work on US farms. In the last few years, the migrations have slowed both because the journey became more expensive and more dangerous, and the 2008 recession took hold and vineyards took a financial hit. But the Trump administration‚Äôs stance on immigration could scare off even more workers. Trump‚Äôs proposed immigration policies have been found by immigration policy advocate Ed Kissam to pose a ‚Äúmajor threat‚Äù to California‚Äôs economic well-being. In a first-of-its-kind law for any major American city, Seattle has instituted a ban on plastic straws and utensils at all food service businesses. The ordinance, which went into effect Sunday, prohibits restaurants, delis, coffee shops, food trucks, cafeterias and grocery stores from providing the plastic items to customers. Upon request only, those vendors may provide people with a compostable straw or utensil. The ban carries a $250 fine. Justice Anthony Kennedy is retiring after serving 30 years on the Supreme Court. The announcement gives President Donald Trump the opportunity to nominate the second Supreme Court justice of his presidency and sets up an epic political fight over Kennedy‚Äôs replacement. Appointed in 1988 by President Ronald Reagan, Kennedy has been the court‚Äôs least ideological conservative for a number of years, voting with the liberal justices in 5-4 decisions more often than any other conservative justice. His role as a swing voter has made him the court‚Äôs most powerful justice, with Supreme Court advocates tailoring oral arguments specifically to try to win his favor. Kennedy‚Äôs decision to retire gives Trump the opportunity to move the court farther to the right. Read more on motherjones.com #JusticeKennedy #Trumpadministration #supremecourt #conservatives #swingvotes (üì∏: Olivier Douliery/ZUMA)

In a major decision that inspired outrage from the court‚Äôs liberal justices, the Supreme Court ruled 5-4 Tuesday to uphold President Trump‚Äôs ban on allowing travel from six countries, many of which have Muslim majorities. Justice Sonia Sotomayor, joined by Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, used President Trump‚Äôs inflammatory rhetoric about Muslims to underscore the ‚Äústark parallels‚Äù between the majority opinion and one of the high court‚Äôs most shameful moments: Korematsu v. United States, the decision that upheld Japanese internment during World War II. Sotomayor flatly rejected the government‚Äôs request to ignore Trump‚Äôs multiple statements about Muslims and his earliest description of the executive order as a ‚Äútotal and complete shutdown‚Äù of Muslims entering the US. In concluding her dissent, she said, ‚ÄúOur Constitution demands, and our country deserves, a Judiciary willing to hold the coordinate branches to account when they defy our most sacred legal commitments. Because the Court‚Äôs decision today has failed in that respect, with profound regret, I dissent.‚Äù Read more on motherjones.com #dissent #JusticeSotomayor #JusticeRuthBaderGinsburg #muslimban #travelban #trumpadministration (üì∏: Elaine Thompson/AP)

In another major Supreme Court ruling, a California law regulating deceptive, anti-abortion pregnancy centers has been blocked. The 5-4 ruling on Tuesday morning in National Institute of Family and Life Advocates (NIFLA) v. Becerra is the first Supreme Court decision related to abortion since Neil Gorsuch became a justice. The majority sided with a group of 110 California crisis pregnancy centers, which are anti-abortion organizations that steer women seeking help with an unwanted pregnancy away from abortion. They blocked a 2015 state law, known as the Reproductive FACT Act, that required medical clinics to disclose if they are unlicensed, and to hang a waiting room sign about state contraception and abortion assistance programs. The centers argued they were singled out for their anti-abortion views, and that the signs violated their free speech rights. Read more about the case on motherjones.com #antiabortion #prolife #prochoice #supremecourt #NeilGorsuch #trumpadministration (üì∏: J. Scott Applewhite/AP)

Soviet treasure trove: Last year, Asya Ivashintsova-Melkumyan and her husband were renovating their house near St. Petersburg, Russia, when they stumbled upon an oversized box among her late mother‚Äôs belongings. Inside were 30,000 negatives and prints packaged in envelopes with handwritten comments and dates. The archive contained a photographic record of everyday life in the Soviet Union and post-communist Russia created by Asya‚Äôs mother, Masha Ivashintsova (1942-2000): schoolchildren playing in the snow, alcoholics guzzling beer, communist rallies, weddings, passersby posing with cigarettes in fur hats, Soviet fashions, and quotidian objects like washbasins. Check out the beautiful prints and read more about Masha Ivashintsova on motherjones.com #photography #USSR #Russia #streetart #archives #history (üì∏: Masha Ivashintsova)

Homeless people are dying at an alarming rate. Climate change might be making it worse. Last year was the third hottest on record, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Association. 2017 also marked the first time that the United States has seen an increase in homelessness in almost a decade, according to the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Extreme heat is already the leading cause of weather-related death in the United States. If the number of homeless people continues to increase alongside temperatures, it could be a recipe for serious health consequences. This article was initially published on Slate and appears on Mother jones as part of the Climate Desk collaboration. Illinois wants to launch a huge "get out the vote" campaign‚Äîin jails: An Illinois bill that passed last month would require every Illinois jail‚Äîincluding Cook County Jail, the largest in the country‚Äîto make in-person or absentee voting available to pre-trial detainees. First Lady Melania Trump made a surprise visit to Texas on Thursday to take a first-hand look at the border crisis that has detained more than 2,300 children under her husband‚Äôs zero-tolerance immigration policy. But Trump‚Äôs concern for the migrant children was likely eclipsed by her apparel.
