Do you currently work with migrant children, or have you ever worked with them? Mother Jones wants to hear from you. The Trump administration‚Äôs new ‚Äúzero tolerance‚Äù policy has led to thousands of families being separated at the border. After widespread outcry, President Donald Trump signed an executive order largely ending his administration‚Äôs practice on Wednesday. Rather than separate parents from children, agencies must now detain families together on a temporary basis. In light of these new developments, we want to hear from people who have worked with migrant families and children. Have you worked in a shelter or detention facility, or as a lawyer representing some of these kids? Have you worked with kids after they have been released? Or, has your family been affected by this new separation policy? Share your story with us on motherjones.com #immigration #familyseparation #deportation #migrantchildren #trumpadministration

While the Trump administration reboots America‚Äôs war on weed, Canada is poised to corner the legal market. Our neighbors to the north are now doing what only Uruguay has done before‚Äîlegalize recreational marijuana across the country. Canada plans to create a nationwide system in which weed is treated less like a narcotic and more like booze, taxed and sold mostly in state-run stores open to any adult. And it‚Äôs happening while legal growers in the United States navigate a patchwork of state laws and watch the hands-off approach to marijuana enforcement of the Obama years give way to Attorney General Jeff Sessions‚Äô decidedly retrograde anti-weed stance. In some respects, the situation is a throwback to Prohibition days: Liquor was banned in the United States but legal in Canada in the 1920s, and Seagram Co. of Montreal took advantage of its sidelined American competitors to become the world‚Äôs largest distiller. Read more about Canada‚Äôs plans on motherjones.com #legalizingmarijuana #medicalcannabis #weed #canada

A new FBI study shows mass shooters aren‚Äôt loners who just suddenly snap: The reality of mass shootings in America is starkly different from these familiar misconceptions. Mass shooters don‚Äôt explode out of nowhere‚Äîthey plan and prepare. Most have no diagnosable mental illness. And their attacks are almost always preceded by behaviors that stir apprehension in people close to them. Those behaviors most commonly involved mental health problems related to anger, paranoia, or depression; troubling levels of interpersonal conflict; or communicated threats of violence. The study is a significant expansion of forensic research in active shooters, information that could increase the likelihood of thwarting would-be killers before they act. Read more on motherjones.com #massshootings #mentalhealth #shooters #gunviolence

Five years ago, she fled Iraq as a refugee. Today, she‚Äôs showcasing at some of the world‚Äôs hottest restaurants: 45-year-old Muna Anaee never saw cooking as a profession until 2013, when she fled Iraq and came to the US as a refugee. Her ESL teacher noticed her skill as a chef, and encouraged her to start a business. This week, after she was selected to participate as a featured chef in the Refugee Food Festival, Muna will bring her flatbreads, hummus, and various meat dishes to a couple of high-end San Francisco restaurants. Tune in next week to Mother Jones' food podcast, @bite_podcast, to hear more about the story. Also check out her recipe for Chicken Shawarma on motherjones.com #Iraq #refugeefoodfestival #asylum #food (üì∏: Azar Hashem)

Life for Latina domestic workers in the Texas border region can be incredibly bleak. Many face severe economic hardships, often struggling to pay rent and cover basic needs, according to a new report released Tuesday by the National Domestic Workers Alliance. More than 200,000 domestic workers live in Texas, and it has roughly the third highest number of domestic workers in the country, after California and New York. One of the report‚Äôs biggest findings is that a significant portion of domestic workers in the region face economic uncertainty; more than 40 percent of them struggled to pay their rent at some point in the last year, while 37 percent reported going hungry‚Äîmore than double the rate of food insecurity in Texas as a whole. Read more from the report on motherjones.com #texas #domesticworkers #jobsecurity #latinas #racialdiscrimination (üì∏: Antonio_Diaz/Getty Images) Note: The woman pictured here is not Olivia Figueroa herself; it is in fact a photo taken from one of our wire art services.

Sea level rise driven by climate change is set to pose an existential crisis to many US coastal communities, with new research finding that as many as 311,000 homes face being flooded every two weeks within the next 30 years. The swelling oceans are forecast to soak coastal residences collectively worth $120bn by 2045 if greenhouse gas emissions are not severely curtailed, experts warn. This article was first published in The Guardian and appears on Mother Jones as a part of the Climate Desk collaboration. Read more on motherjones.com #climatechange #naturaldisasters #coastalcommunities (Image: Dale Gerhard/The Press of Atlantic City via AP)

Solar is the future, and Donald Trump has given it to China: From solar to batteries to electric vehicles, China is rapidly gaining on the West in the most important arena of all: innovation. Under President Trump, who has called climate change a Chinese ‚Äúhoax,‚Äù the United States appears content to cede its lead in solar energy. America has more than twice as many jobs in solar as in coal, and its installed solar capacity is expected to more than double over the next five years. Yet Trump‚Äôs 2019 budget proposes slashing the Energy Department‚Äôs renewable-¬≠energy and energy-efficiency funding by about 75 percent. The world‚Äôs first transgender-only body building competition launched in Atlanta in 2014, giving trans athletes the chance to stand onstage and embrace, rather than hide their bodies. "Man Made" is a film by journalist and filmmaker T. Cooper that follows a handful of trans male athletes as they prepare for the event. The Supreme Court just guaranteed that millions of Americans will vote in districts that have been ruled unconstitutional: Two cases, from Wisconsin and Maryland, had the potential to reshape political maps across the country by sanctioning or restricting states‚Äô ability to draw districts for one party‚Äôs political advantage. Now, any ruling on the constitutionality of extreme political gerrymanders will have to wait, and the while the cases are sent back to lower courts on procedural grounds. The Supreme Court has long protected racial minorities from discrimination in gerrymandering, but it has never before restricted gerrymandering on the basis of partisan affiliation or past voting behavior. Read more about the cases and their outcomes on motherjones.com #gerrymandering #supremecourt #voterdiscrimination (üì∏: Jacquelyn Martin/AP)

The election of self-described ‚Äúpro-European nationalist‚Äù to a Republican Party post in Whitman County, Washington, has sparked local outrage and raised key questions about how party officials can oust members who legitimately earned their positions. Trump‚Äôs EPA green-lighted a pesticide that harms kids‚Äô brains. And Hawaii just said, ‚ÄúHell no‚Äù: The insecticide Chlorpyrifos is on the EPA's list of chemicals deemed to be so toxic that can only be used by trained applicators on particular crops. Russia's football team is, uh... suuuuper white. As Team Russia takes the field on Thursday for the first match of the 2018 World Cup, soccer fans will see a national team that looks almost nothing like tournament favorites Brazil, France, Germany, Spain, or Belgium. Russia‚Äôs team is almost entirely made up of white players who make their living playing for the country‚Äôs domestic league. The World Cup teams expected to get close to the final game are not only ethnically diverse, but are stocked with players who ply their trade outside their home countries. The lack of diversity in the Russian football team and its fans might not be that surprising when you consider that back in 2012, Zenit St. Petersburg‚Äôs largest fan group demanded that their team only hire ethnically Slavic players. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not racist,‚Äù the fans wrote in a manifesto to club officials, ‚Äúbut we see the absence of black players at Zenit as an important tradition. It would allow Zenit to maintain the national identity of the club.‚Äù Read more on motherjones.com #Russia #Soccer #worldcup2018 #racism #xenophobia (üì∏: Matthias Schrader/AP)

A week after the high-profile suicides of Kate Spade and Anthony Bourdain renewed the national conversation over mental health, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention released numbers showing that America‚Äôs overall suicide rate has climbed by a whopping 30 percent since 2000. On Thursday, the CDC released a second report that breaks down the data on the nearly 45,000 Americans who took their own lives in 2016, making suicide the 10th leading cause of death. North Dakota saw the biggest increase from 1999 to 2016: 58 percent. If you or someone you care about may be at risk of suicide, call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline, a free, 24/7 service that offers support, information, and local resources: 1-800-273-TALK (8255). Read more on motherjones.com #suicide #anthonybourdain #katespade #mentalillness #CDC #guns (üì∏: CDC)

Black people are more likely than whites to die of heart disease: It‚Äôs not just diet and lifestyle that determine your risk for heart disease‚Äîrace matters, too. About 37 percent of white men and 32 percent of white women develop heart disease, versus 44 percent of black men and 49 percent of black women. The reasons black Americans have higher rates of cardiovascular problems are complicated‚Äîamong them, as researchers have pointed to, elevated levels of stress as a result of poverty and racism. But a study published Wednesday in the journal JAMA Cardiology sheds light on another possible explanation: African Americans are slightly less likely than Caucasians to be given drugs to control their cholesterol levels‚Äîand they‚Äôre far less likely to be prescribed the correct doses. A team of researchers from Duke University Medical Center followed the progress of 5,689 patients who were eligible for treatment with statins, a class of cholesterol drug. In the study, the researchers found, clinicians who saw the black patients were less likely to use the current guidelines in determining a statin dose. Read more on motherjones.com #racialdisparities #healthissues #Dukeuniversity #cardiovascualrdiseases

The election of San Francisco‚Äôs first black female mayor on Wednesday proves that there‚Äôs still a gap between African-American voters and the progressive movement: In a state that‚Äôs deep blue, in city of progressives, London Breed is considered a true moderate‚Äîpuzzling observers and leading to even more soul-searching on the Left about race. Her victory also makes Breed the latest in what might be a national wave of black women running for and winning‚Äîor at least progressing toward‚Äîpublic office. Read our profile of Breed, and other women like her, on motherjones.com #londonbreed #sanfrancisco #mayoralelections #progressives #race (üì∏: Lorin Eleni Gill/AP Photo)

It‚Äôs a tale of steaks, lawsuits, and foreign agents: The Zionist Organization of America and its longtime president, Mort Klein, have been known for their zealous support of Israeli right-winger and their unrestrained attacks on who they consider to be Israel‚Äôs enemies. In recent years, their targets have included Qatar. But Ahmed al-Rumaihi, a former Qatari diplomat and, until March 2017, the head of Qatar Investments, a $100 billion division of the country‚Äôs sovereign wealth fund, and Joseph Allaham, the former owner of a group of kosher restaurants, struck up an unlikely alliance. Al-Rumaihi‚Äôs presence at ZOA‚Äôs annual gala was part of an extensive effort by Qatar to improve its relations with the Trump administration and its political supporters. But in a dramatic reversal last week, Allaham broke with Qatar and declared he was ending his relationship with the state. To make matters more complicated, Al-Rumaihi is also entangled in a lawsuit with Ice Cube, that alleges Al-Rumaihi, whose company had invested in a professional basketball league that the rapper had helped launch, and other investors reneged on an agreement to put up $20.5 million in financing. Read our investigation into this alliance and its aftermath on motherjones.com #zionism #islam #qatar #diplomacy #trumpadministration #IceCube

Finishing a job application on your own is usually a prerequisite for getting hired. But US Customs and Border Protection wants to change that: The agency is having so much trouble hiring border agents that it‚Äôs now spending huge sums‚Äîpotentially hundreds of millions of dollars‚Äîto recruit people and help them complete the application process. This includes assistance with scheduling physical fitness and medical tests, as well as providing them with ‚Äúhelpful information‚Äù about their entrance exams. Last November, CBP awarded a five-year, $297 million contract to a subsidiary of the global consulting company Accenture. The math works out to nearly $40,000 for each of the 7,500 workers Accenture is supposed to help hire. Now CBP is proposing to expand the contract by up to an additional $8 million over five years so that Accenture can help replace employees CBP is losing through attrition. Read more on motherjones.com #CBP #Accenture #trumpadministration (üì∏: CBP/ZUMA)

The Democratic National Committee voted over the weekend to ban donations from fossil fuel companies. The resolution‚Äîproposed by Christine Pelosi, a party activist and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi‚Äôs daughter‚Äîbars the organization from accepting contributions from corporate political action committees tied to the oil, gas and coal industries. The executive committee voted unanimously to approve the motion. The DNC may consider a second resolution at a full board meeting in Chicago in August to ban contributions over $200 from individuals who work for the fossil fuel industry. On the flip side, the coal mining industry gave 97 percent of its donations to Republicans in 2016‚Äîa figure that has dipped to 95 percent this year. This article was initially published on HuffPost, and appears on Mother Jones as part of the Climate Desk collaboration. Read more on motherjones.com #climatedesk #nancypelosi #dnc #rnc #fossilfuels #environmentalissues

Democrats running for office in rural states‚Äîlike Janet Mills‚Äîare facing increased pressure to abandon the NRA after the Parkland shooting. A decade ago, Mills, Maine‚Äôs attorney general, and the current frontrunner for governor, received ‚ÄúA‚Äù or ‚ÄúA+‚Äù ratings from the NRA for her voting record during each of her three terms as a state legislator. Maine Democrats support some combination of ‚Äúcommon sense‚Äù gun control measures, such as banning assault weapons or expanding background checks. But in the wake of the February school shooting in Parkland, Florida, they have taken a tougher stance on the issue. While Mills now notes that her fellow Democrats have ‚Äúa lot of work to do‚Ä¶for the student so afraid that any day might bring the next shooting,‚Äù her Democratic competitors are touting their endorsements from gun safety organizations while criticizing Mills, for whom a positive NRA rating‚Äîor even a somewhat softer stance on the issue‚Äîisn't seen as an advantage anymore. Read more on motherjones.com #JanetMills #Maine #Democrats #guncontrol #NRA (üì∏: Robert F. Bukaty/AP)

Someone didn't get the "witch-hunt memo": A top Trump appointee issued a dire assessment about Russia the same day Trump declared that the country should be readmitted to the G7. Dan Coats, the director of national intelligence, warned that Moscow is currently mounting information warfare against the United States that could influence the coming midterm elections. One of the biggest questions of the #MeToo era is whether voters will reject candidates who have been accused of inappropriate or illegal sexual behavior. In California, two races show voters‚Äô split response to #MeToo scandals. Former State Sen. Tony Mendoza, who resigned in February just minutes before the Senate was to expel him after an investigation found he had engaged in sexually suggestive behavior, ran again for his seat in the 32nd Senate District. Last Tuesday, he resoundingly lost two elections‚Äîone to reclaim the seat he vacated and finish the remainder of his term and another for a new term beginning in 2019. The second race involved Assemblywoman Cristina Garcia, who was investigated by the state Assembly for alleged inappropriate behavior with male colleagues. On Tuesday, Garcia eked out a narrow primary victory in the 58th Assembly District, besting a Republican competitor by about 700 votes. Read more on motherjones.com #metoo #timesup #california #primaries (üì∏: Rich Pedroncelli/AP)

Sessions just made it vastly harder for victims of domestic abuse and gang violence to receive asylum: Using his authority over the US immigration court system, Sessions decided Monday that people fleeing gangs and domestic violence will generally not qualify for asylum. We‚Äôd like to hear from our LGBTQ readers: when did you first see yourself in fiction? Fictional characters from Kim Possible to Mulan are often perceived as LGBTQ, even if writers don‚Äôt say they are. GLAAD‚Äôs most recent ‚ÄúWhere We Are On TV‚Äù report revealed that just over 6 percent of characters on broadcast television were slated to be LGBTQ during the June 2017 to May 2018 broadcast season‚Äîhigher than ever, the report notes, but that still leaves young LGBTQ people wanting more. Carmen Esposito's brand-new special, Rape Jokes, is an hourlong set that reimagines how a rape joke is defined and where sexual violence does‚Äîand doesn‚Äôt‚Äîfit into comedy. Esposito worked on the set in pieces, all over the country, with audiences of between 50 and 100 people. The result is masterful and hilarious, weaving Esposito‚Äôs signature loud, friendly style with stories from her childhood, her relationship to the audience, and very funny jokes. The special went live online Monday morning on her website and at Vulture, as well as on motherjones.com. It‚Äôs free, but viewers can donate on a sliding scale to the Rape, Abuse, and Incest National Network, the nation‚Äôs largest anti-sexual violence organization. We spoke to Carmen about her new special and her mission to use comedy to open a larger conversation about sexual assault. Read the interview and watch the special on motherjones.com #carmenesposito #sexualassault #rapeculture #comedy #standup #timesup #metoo (üì∏: Graham Fielder)

The Supreme Court dealt a big blow to voting rights Monday in a decision that is likely to green-light aggressive purges of voter rolls across the country. The case originated in Ohio, where thousands of eligible voters were removed from the rolls, and where a Reuters analysis found that people in Democratic-leaning neighborhoods were removed at twice the rate of people in Republican areas, noting that ‚Äúneighborhoods that have a high proportion of poor, African-American residents are hit hardest.‚Äù Ohio‚Äôs system does not inform voters when they are taken off voting rolls, and citizens were often unable to re-register before an election took place, losing their ability to vote. Today marks the official end of net neutrality. Led by current Chairman Ajit Pai, the Federal Communication Commission voted 3-2 in December 2017 to repeal the Obama-era open internet rules. The decision went into effect on Monday. Advocates have warned that the repeal of the 2015 regulation would open the door for internet service providers to start charging more for preferred content, slow certain content, or fully block content. The repeal doesn‚Äôt mean, however, the fight for net neutrality is over. Last Thursday, Senate Democrats wrote a letter to House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) urging him to force a vote on the repeal. Read more about the battle over net neutrality on motherjones.com #netneutrality #ajitpai #trumpadministration (üì∏: Battle for the Net)

In April, President Donald Trump nominated Patrick Wyrick, currently a Justice on the Oklahoma Supreme Court, to an Oklahoma district court judgeship. Wyrick is also a former aide to Environmental Protection Agency Administrator Scott Pruitt. And now, he might also be appointed as a federal judge. Read more about Wyrick on motherjones.com #PatrickWyrick #Trumpadministration #federaljudge #supremecourt #prolife #antienvironment #epa (üì∏: Sue Ogrocki/AP Photo)

Anacostia is a neighborhood in DC located somewhere beyond the river that divides the city‚Äôs prosperous west from its neglected and largely African American east. According to recent transplants, it is a region marked with crime and poverty, but if you ask a realtor, they‚Äôll say it‚Äôs the next hot neighborhood. Susana Raab‚Äôs photo project ‚ÄúThe Invisible Wall‚Äù depicts the complicated truth of Anacostia and the surrounding impoverished neighborhoods of the city‚Äôs southeast corner‚Äîa mix of historic buildings and public housing, and a bastion of black cultural pride. Check out the beautifully captured moments in Anacostia at motherjones.com #anacostia #WashingtonSC #blackcommunities #racialdivide (üì∏: Susana Raab)

Reverend Rob Schenck helped build the religious right. He now believes he made a terrible mistake: The past four decades have seen an ever-tightening alliance between American evangelicals and the Republican Party, and few have played as pivotal a role in fostering that coupling as Rev. Rob Schenck. He gained national notoriety in the 1990s as a fervent anti-abortion activist who orchestrated shocking stunts to promote his cause, including one in which an aborted fetus was thrust in the face of then-presidential candidate Bill Clinton. But today, Schenck has distanced himself from many of his fellow evangelical pastors and former political allies, over the issue of gun control. Schenck explores his personal evolution in a new memoir, "Costly Grace: An Evangelical Minister‚Äôs Rediscovery of Faith, Hope and Love". We recently sat with Schenck to talk to him about Evangelicals and his reformation. Read the interview at motherjones.com #Schenck #evangelicals #conservatism #trump #guncontrol (üì∏: Lauren Victoria Burke/AP)

Without interpreters, California‚Äôs deaf prisoners are getting stuck behind bars: Under federal law, all prisons are required to provide qualified interpreters for deaf inmates to help them participate in education and self-help classes, and communicate with guards. But at the Substance Abuse Treatment Facility (SATF), where most of California‚Äôs deaf inmates are housed, prisoners with hearing impairments are regularly denied access to interpreters, according to recent court filings in a long-running disability rights case known as Armstrong v. Brown. Inmates say the facility has failed to offer interpreters for many of the programs and meetings that they are required to attend, potentially opening them up to the risk of serving longer prison sentences. California, because of its size, has more deaf inmates requiring sign language interpreters than most other states‚Äîabout 75 at SATF alone, according to the corrections department. And the fact that so many are clustered at one institution creates problems, because SATF is located in a remote part of California‚Äôs Central Valley, far from the biggest pools of interpreters in metropolitan areas like San Francisco and Los Angeles. Desperate families are locking up their opioid-addicted relatives for treatment. But what can be a lifeline can sometimes become a nightmare. Civil commitment allows states to confine people who have not been convicted‚Äîor even accused‚Äîof a crime, if a judge decides they pose an imminent danger to themselves or others. Could our gadget addiction put us on the path to a renewable energy revolution?: An international team of scientists has developed a global scenario called Low Energy Demand, arguing that humanity‚Äôs appetite for things like electric cars and cellphones can drive a revolution in efficiency that could help lower energy demand and encourage the proliferation of renewable energy. The Supreme Court ruled on Monday in favor of Jack Phillips, a Colorado baker who refused to make a cake for a same-sex wedding. The case got started in 2012, when Phillips refused on religious grounds to make a custom wedding cake for David Mullins and Charlie Craig. The couple sued and prevailed at every level in Colorado courts, which found that baking a gay wedding cake would not violate Phillips‚Äô free speech or religious freedom rights, and that refusing to make one would constitute illegal discrimination based on sexual orientation. But during oral arguments in the case, Kennedy seemed peeved at the behavior of the Colorado Civil Rights Commission. Kennedy wrote the majority opinion in Monday‚Äôs ruling. Veterans carry the weight of chronic PTSD. Raising animals could help them keep the demons at bay: Alex Sutton is a decorated US Army veteran who served three tours in Iraq. The coal industry is dying, and it‚Äôs leaving its communities to pick up the pieces: In mid-November of 2016, a few days after the election of Donald Trump, the Dayton Power & Light plants‚ÄîStuart and Killen‚Äîwere notified by Ohio state that they were intended to be closed in June  2018. Susan Solomon is best known for solving the mystery of the ozone hole, the annual thinning of the protective stratospheric ozone layer over Antarctica. Solomon‚Äôs studies and measurements in Antarctica identified both the mechanism for ozone destruction and the culprit: chemicals called chlorofluorocarbons, which were once widely used as refrigerants and aerosol propellants. Identifying the problem led to the Montreal Protocol, an international treaty that phased out ozone-destroying gases in favor of less harmful compounds. She is now receiving the prestigious 2018 Crafoord Prize in Geosciences for her efforts. Solomon was interviewed by Dawn Stover of the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, which originally published this story. Read the interview on http://motherjones.com #geosciences #ozonelayer #climatechange #environmentalstudies

Trail-by-Skype is now the norm in Immigration court. But the practice puts pressure on vulnerable asylum-seekers: Many detainees at Mesa Verde and other facilities in the Bay Area don't meet their pro bono lawyers and judges in person. Instead, they meet via video teleconference. The rise of trial-by-screen is a result of two factors: a massive spike in the number of immigrants in detention, begun under Obama and ramped up by Trump, and the increasingly remote locations of the facilities that house them. The downside to video teleconference? The detainees appearing via video give up more quickly and resign themselves to so-called self-deportation, according to a study conducted by Northwestern University Law Review. Read more about virtual trials on motherjones.com #immigration #deportation #trialbyskype #trumpadministration (Illustration: Rob Dobi)

In November 2014, Dr. Craig Spencer walked out of New York‚Äôs Bellevue Hospital cured of Ebola. He was the last American diagnosed with the disease in the US. Spencer, an emergency medicine doctor, caught Ebola while treating patients for Doctors Without Borders in Guinea. Called a "selfish man" by Trump for potentially spreading the disease in New York (it's virtually impossible for someone to spread the Ebola virus before they have symptoms) he is now the director of global health in emergency medicine at New York-Presbyterian-Columbia University Medical Center.. We spoke with him about his experience with Ebola, as a doctor and a patient. He also reflected on America‚Äôs response to the Ebola epidemic, and his concern that we are unprepared for the next outbreak. Read the interview on Motherjones.com #Ebola #virus #diseases #healthconcerns #Trump #africa (üì∏: Diana Quintela/Atlantico Press/ZUMA)

Federal agents arrested two Arizona brothers on Thursday and charged them with operating deceptive political action committees (PACs) that raised more than $50 million over the last decade. Dozens of PACs have sprung up in recent years that similar tactics to target small-dollar donors‚Äîfrequently elderly ones‚Äîwith fundraising pleas that appeal to issues the donors feel strongly about, such as protecting conservative values, supporting law enforcement, and advocating for people with autism. These PACs often do very little to support actual candidates or causes, while making large payments to their operators. Read more about these PACs on motherjones.com #PACs #conservatives #fundraising #fraud

Here‚Äôs some good news: Meteorologists can now forecast storms with such unprecedented accuracy that humanitarian organizations can fund disaster relief before disasters even hit. It‚Äôs a revolutionary change that could save countless lives. Earlier this month, the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies launched the first ‚Äúforecast-based financing‚Äù fund, which aims to use weather predictions to anticipate humanitarian crises, giving organizations like the Red Cross a chance at stopping them before they begin. White people just keep calling the cops on black people. In the month since two law-abiding black men were arrested at a Philadelphia Starbucks, white people have called police on a black Yale graduate student who‚Äôd fallen asleep on the sofa in the common room, a group of black women who were golfing too slowly, on a group of black girls goofing around outside a formal dinner, on a black real-estate investor who was inspecting a house he had under contract; the list goes on. For black people, that call to law enforcement can sometimes have dire consequences‚Äîblack men aged 15 to 34 were killed by police at four times the rate of our white counterparts in 2016. Ramadan Kareem! This week is the start of Ramadan, the most sacred month of the year in Islamic culture. During Ramadan, Muslims fast and pray to become closer to God. From dawn to dusk, Muslims are advised to refrain from consuming food, drinking liquids, smoking, engaging in sexual relations, among other things. The fast is broken at sunset, where families celebrate by engaging in a feast called Iftar. Here are some photos of scenes from around the world. #ramadan #iftar #islam #festivals #fasting (üì∏: India: Ajit Solanki/AP and Nasir Kachroo/ZUMA; Turkey: Emrah Gurel/AP; Bosnia and Herzegovina: Haris Memija/Xinhua via ZUMA; Palestine: Mahmoud Ajour/APA Images via ZUMA; Egypt: Gehad Hamdy/picture-alliance/dpa/AP Images)

Towns across northwest Indiana are finding alarming amounts of lead in their soil. Residents are not surprised: For the last century, this part of the state has been hub for oil refineries, steel mills, and lead processing plants. According to a report from the Chicago Tribune, the Environmental Protection Agency has found high levels of lead in dozens of yards in Hammond and Whiting, Indiana, from the now-shuttered Federated Metals Corporation, a lead smelter plant which operated from 1937 to 1983. According to the Chicago Tribune, nearly 10,000 people live within a mile of the company‚Äôs old site. Read more about lead contamination on motherjones.com #leadcontamination #environmentaljustice #EPA #ScottPruitt #Indiana

Ebola is back, but this time an experimental vaccine could stop the outbreak: The rVSV-ZEBOV vaccine has been decades in the making, and it is finally ready to be administered. This decision comes after WHO announced on May 8 that two Ebola cases have been confirmed in the DRC. As of Monday, a total of 39 possible cases had been reported, including 19 deaths. Rather than vaccinating the entire population, they will try to vaccinate anyone who came in contact with an infected person, and then vaccinate those individuals‚Äô contacts as well. WHO will also vaccinate health workers. Read more about this experimental vaccine on http://motherjones.com #WHO #Ebola #vaccine #medicine #healthissues

Comedian Ali Wong hasn‚Äôt found success despite her degree in ethnic studies, but maybe because of it: In Wong's 2016 Netflix special Baby Cobra, she use comedy that gets an audience to laugh at trauma. ‚ÄúSome useful advice for all of my Asian-American brothers and sisters,‚Äù she jokes. ‚ÄúNever go paint balling with a Vietnam veteran.‚Äù These jokes, and how she got her start performing, are very much informed by one of the most maligned fields of study in academia, a field that has long been derided by conservatives. With the election of Donald Trump, and with the growing popularity of comedians like Wong, the movement to implement ethnic studies in classrooms has gained momentum. Mojo's Jamliah King takes on the importance of ethnic studies and the rise of Asian-Americans in entertainment, at motherjones.com. Wong's new comedy special, Hard Knock Wife, is now out on Netflix. #asianamericans #ethnicstudies #trauma #war #minorities #standupcomedy (üì∏: Ken Woroner/Netflix)

He was dying and normal antibiotics weren't working. Then doctors tried a forgotten treatment that saved his life: American psychologist Tom Patterson was infected with a nasty superbug, a bacterium named Acinetobacter baumannii that was resistant to every antibiotic thrown at it. Then they tried phage therapy. Phages are viral cleanup crews that keep bacteria from taking over the world by killing them rapidly. But phage therapy is not approved in the U.S. How did it work? Read about the fascinating science at http://motherjones.com, or pick up the May/June 2018 issue. #phagetherapy #viruses #bacteria #healthissues #medicine (üì∏: David Walter Banks; illustration: Ery Burns)

It‚Äôs not just rural women who must travel long distances to get an abortion. Researchers mapped out 780 abortion facilities across America in a new study out Monday and found that 27 major cities are 100 miles or more from their nearest abortion provider, particularly in the South and the Midwest. residents of Kentucky, Mississippi, Missouri, North Dakota, South Dakota, and West Virginia are all limited to one in-state abortion facility. Amid a spiraling overdose epidemic, opioid prescribing is still on the rise for a small subset of physicians: those who receive funding from opioid manufacturers. Strikingly, the general trend held not just for the select few prescribers receiving big consulting and speaker fees, but for the many more who have simply eaten meals paid for by the drug companies. Meals served as a cheap way to reach a lot of doctors: Of the roughly 369,000 doctors who billed opioid prescriptions to Medicare, about 25,000 had at least one meal sponsored by opioid makers. Read more about the Opioid crisis on http://motherjones.com #opioidcrisis #bigpharma #drugs #healthissues

They disagree on guns. But after their children died in Parkland, these fathers are finding common ground. Fred Guttenberg and Ryan Petty are focussing on what they can agree on: guns are one of many factors that led to their daughters‚Äô murders. Now they're working together on school safety measures and holding law enforcement accountable for failures, while forging alliances with both political parties to make progress. Coal plant polluters probably don‚Äôt want Scott Pruitt to resign: Pruitt is moving swiftly to grant one of industry‚Äôs major policy wishes. He‚Äôs making it easier for plant operators to sidestep equipment upgrades. Last year, 145 coal plants without control technology collectively put out nearly 580,000 tons of sulfur dioxide‚Äîknown as SO2‚Äîaccording to EPA data that has gone largely unnoticed amid the Pruitt scandals. Even small amounts of SO2 can set off asthma attacks or harm the lungs. Read more on motherjones.com #sulphurdioxide #coal #scottpruitt #epa #environmentalissues

Two millennial socialists could take down a Pittsburgh political dynasty: Since it was founded in 1982, the Democratic Socialists of America has played virtually no role the country‚Äôs elections. That‚Äôs begun to change, fuelled by the organization‚Äôs 2016 endorsement of Bernie Sanders and a growth spurt led by the activists and organizers he inspired. In Pittsburgh, the local DSA chapter is 500 members strong and hosts Marxist reading groups, organizes against controversial anti-abortion pregnancy centers, and works to reduce police stops by fixing residents‚Äô brake lights. On Tuesday, the revitalized DSA could notch its biggest wins yet in a city that‚Äôs long been defined by machine politics. ‚ÄúWhat if Jesus actually meant the stuff he said?‚Äù: Say the word ‚Äúevangelical,‚Äù and images of diversity or progressive politics are not likely to come to mind. But at the E.C. Glass High School auditorium in Lynchburg, Virginia, that‚Äôs exactly what was on display in April at the first Red Letter revival. The Red Letter Christians are an organization that intends to offer evangelical Christians an alternative to the old, white, predominantly male, and politically conservative evangelicalism that they believe has led the movement to lose its way. Red Letter Christians are committed to combating racism, gun violence, and the death penalty while supporting immigrants and the LGBTQ community. A case reviewing Trump‚Äôs pardon of Joe Arpaio could have huge implications for federal separation of powers. Last year, Trump pardoned Arpaio, who became the country‚Äôs most infamous sheriff for racially profiling Latinos and arresting them on suspicion of lacking legal status. Now, in a little-noticed case, the courts are considering whether that pardon went too far by overriding the constitutional rights of Arpaio‚Äôs victims. If the court overrules Trump, it could shatter the notion that the president‚Äôs pardon power is unlimited. If it upholds his pardon, it could send two powerful messages: that law enforcement officials can violate constitutional protections against racial discrimination and still gain presidential absolution, and that people caught up in the Russia investigation can refuse to cooperate with court orders without penalty if they have the president‚Äôs backing. Read more on motherjones.com #JoeArpaio #Trump #presidentialpardon #racialprofiling (üì∏ by Mary Altaffer/AP)

The effects of climate change are already here, and they are hitting hardest in the parts of the world that have contributed the fewest greenhouse gasses. New research indicates these same regions, which are among the globe‚Äôs poorest areas, will experience the most dramatic variations in temperature over the next 80 years. Areas around the Amazon rainforest, in southern Africa, and along the Arctic coast, as well as subtropical areas of the Northern Hemisphere, including parts of India and Africa‚Äôs Sahel region, are in line for volatile weather. Meanwhile, industrialized nations, like the US and China will have relatively stable temperatures. This article was originally published by Grist and appears on Mother Jones as part of the Climate Desk collaboration. Read more on http://motherjones.com #environmentalracism #climatechange #developingcountries (üì∏ by Suvra Kanti Das/ZUMA)

‚ÄúBrothers of the Gun‚Äù by Marwan Hisham is a searing, page-turning account of life in wartime, capturing the violence and hardship of the Syrian conflict and the complexity of those who have lived through it. Hisham provides a ground-level view of the terror unleashed by the Assad regime, rebel groups‚Äô battles for territory, the rise of the Islamic State, and the bombing that has turned the country‚Äôs cities to ruins. Hisham and his friends come of age through the chaos, but it leaves them splintered. The book is illustrated with more than 80 powerful ink drawings by Molly Crabapple, an artist and journalist who has covered conflict throughout the Middle East. Mother Jones spoke with Hisham, who now lives in Turkey, and Crabapple, who lives in New York, about the Syrian civil war and how ‚ÄúBrothers of the Gun‚Äù came to be. Read the interview on motherjones.com #Syria #Civilwar #brothersofthegun #refugeecrisis #assad (üì∏ by Steve Prue; Illustrations by Molly Crabapple)

Can you believe this happened one year ago today? The booze lobby has helped kill a law that could possibly save 1,800 lives every year: The National Transportation Safety Board first called for lowering the Blood Alcohol Concentration (BAC) limit from .08 to .05 in 2013, based on substantial evidence from labs and road-track tests showing that impairment from alcohol starts with the very first drink. Only one state, Utah, passed a bill in March 2017 to lower the legal blood-alcohol limit for driving. But many alcohol lobbyists are afraid this will lower alcohol consumption, despite there being no evidence of this occurring. Read more on motherjones.com #alcoholconsumption #healthissues #boozelobbyists (üì∏: kali9/iStock/Getty Images Plus)

California leads the way in emission reduction strategies: The state just became the first to mandate solar panels on nearly all new residential homes. The mandate is part of California‚Äôs ‚ÄúEnergy Efficiency Strategic Plan,‚Äù which includes the goal that both residential and commercial construction be zero net energy by 2030‚Äîmeaning the buildings‚Äô annual energy usage is either less than or equal to the renewable energy generated onsite. The Mormons of Utah have long been determined to transform the desert and fulfill a biblical prophecy, by using astronomical amounts of water: The average American uses between 80 to 100 gallons a day. In Utah, each individual consumes approximately 248 gallons of water per day. Water in Utah is cheap and, in many municipalities, users pay flat rates for it unlike other states in the country. While water experts and those concerned about conservation talk about using less water, there is swift pushback from legislators and water suppliers. This has been been part of the deeply entwined history of Utah‚Äîwith more than 60 percent of its population being mormon‚Äîand the Church of the Latter Day Saints. The prophesy of Isaiah 35:1 states that ‚Äúthe wilderness and the solitary place shall be glad for them; and the desert shall rejoice, and blossom as the rose.‚Äù Read the full story on motherjones.com #Utah #mormons #waterconservation #environmentalissues (üì∏: bozhdb/Getty)

Lawmakers just might do something positive for pregnant women for a change: The United States has the highest maternal mortality rate of any developed nation. Attorney General Jeff Sessions announced on Monday that the government will begin referring everyone who crosses the Mexican border illegally to the Justice Department for criminal prosecution. Currently, most people who cross into the country illegally are sent back across the border without facing criminal charges. This change would cause many more immigrants to be tried in court and imprisoned for up to six months‚Äîor longer, in the case of repeat offenders. Jared Kushner prison reform's plan has some glaring flaws. Does quitting alcohol lower the risk of cancer? Last month, we reported that alcohol-related cancers are estimated to kill about 20,000 Americans every year. But unlike smokers, who see significant health benefits within five years of smoking their last cigarette, there is no comparable body of research on how ceasing to drink alcohol affects cancer risks. On the plus side, going dry can bring down the risk of some cancers. It just might take a while. Read more at motherjones.com #cancer #healthissues #MoJoinvestiagtion

The Trump Administration could send 57,000 Hondurans to one of the world‚Äôs most dangerous places: Today is the deadline for the Department of Homeland Security to decide whether to extend temporary legal residency for about 57,000 Hondurans who have lived in the United States since at least 1998. The Case for Building Public Housing That Doesn‚Äôt Suck: The ranks of Americans who can‚Äôt find affordable housing are swelling. Milk pricing policies have left small producers at their wit‚Äôs end: Farmers, fishermen, and forestry workers, who are lumped together by government statisticians, have the highest suicide rate of any occupational group: 84.5 self-inflicted deaths per 100,000 workers, according to a Center for Disease Control and Prevention analysis. Dairy farmers in the United States are paid by the hundredweight‚Äîthat‚Äôs 100 pounds of milk, about 12 gallons. Milk prices, after peaking in 2014, have plummeted to roughly $15 per hundredweight, while the cost of production is usually $22 to $25 per hundredweight. Continuing coverage of the link between alcohol and cancer: For years, alcohol companies have promoted and funded studies suggesting that moderate drinking will make us live longer and ward off heart disease, diabetes, and even dementia. There are lots of reasons to be skeptical of the industry‚Äôs health claims. But perhaps most importantly, drinkers themselves tend to underestimate what constitutes a healthy amount of alcohol. Scientists have a different measure. The US Dietary Guidelines, published by the Department of Agriculture, define moderate drinking as having no more than one drink a day for women and two for men. Check out the maps above to see which states have the highest number of alcohol consumers. #Alochol #cancer #health #substanceabuse

A large caravan of migrants, made up of men, women, and children fleeing violence and persecution in Central America, has walked, hopped trains, and taken buses for more than 2,000 miles to reach Tijuana from Chapachula, Mexico. The Trump administration has known about them for about a month now, but when 50 members of the caravan presented themselves at the port of entry on Sunday afternoon, they were turned back by Customs and Border Protection. They claimed that the port of entry was at capacity and could not process any new cases. Both federal law and international treaties require the United States to process asylum seekers. No one knows how immigration affects wages and jobs. Especially Donald Trump. In fact, Trump has tapped into a long-raging battle among economists to mislead Americans. In April of 2015, the nonpartisan Congressional Research Service produced a memo on the relationship between jobs and immigration, featuring a six-decade timeline estimating average incomes‚Äîmostly flat after 1970‚Äîand another showing a rise in the foreign-born population. Conservatives led by Jeff Sessions seized on the charts as powerful evidence of the threat posed by immigration. But, that's not how the original chart was intended. Read more about this history, and other misinterpretations about jobs and immigration at motherjones.com #immigration #Trumpadministration #conservatives #media #immigration

A white man in a truck mowed down a young Native American man. Was it a hate crime? Last May, Jimmy Smith-Kramer, 20, and another man was crushed under the wheels of a pickup truck at a local campground in Grays Harbor County, Washington. Both were members of the Quinault Indian Nation, and a white man, James Walker, was arrested and charged with having intentionally run over the two men. The leaders of the Quinault Nation quickly issued a statement alleging that Walker and or others in his truck had used anti-Native slurs during the fatal incident. But in the year since then, the case has faded from public view, and prosecutors chose not to charge Walker with a hate crime, saying there were conflicting accounts of his possible motivations. This article was originally published by ProPublica‚Äîand their new reporting suggests there is at least some evidence that racial bias played a role in the crime. Find out more about what happened on motherjones.com #Nativeamericans #racialcrimes #procecution

As the death toll from overdoses soars, a growing number of states are requiring doctors to take opioid training programs that can help them deal with real world scenarios. California hasn't been struck by a megaflood since 1861, but very soon the Golden State could fall victim to them as often as every few decades. It‚Äôs fairly normal for all of California‚Äôs yearly water to fall in just a few days. The key is to have enough storage space to absorb the rain when it comes, so it doesn‚Äôt charge unbound into populated areas. For a long time water managers have been able to rely on the mountains to help out‚Äîbut warmer temps are making those reserves less reliable. This article was originally published on Wired and appears on Mother Jones as a part of the Climate Desk collaboration. You'll probably never save as many lives as this guy who got the Philippines to stop using lead paint. Actually, you definitely won't. Ten years ago, local Filipino activist Manny Calonzo decided to test the paint in his home country‚Äîthe first person to publicly do so. Alarmingly, Calonzo found that most of the paint he tested contained lead levels above the allowable US limit. For years following the discovery, he used scientific evidence to advocate for the phase-out of lead paint in his country and organized more than 100 events to draw attention to the issue. By January of last year, 85 percent of the paint market in the Philippines was certified as safe. Mother Jones interviewed Calonzo on his work, and how he hopes to inspire a new generation of environmentalists. Read the interview on motherjones.com #environmentalissues #environmentaljustice #leadcontamination #philippines (Image: Goldman Environmental Prize)

Teacher Strikes: Republicans want to throw the book at Colorado teachers getting ready to strike. Nearly a week before Colorado teachers are expected to descend on the state capitol to rally for better pay and protest potential retirement benefit cuts, state legislatures Sen. Bob Gardner (R-Colorado) and Rep. Paul Lundeen (R-Colorado) introduced a bill that would bar school districts from paying teachers who participate during the time of the strike. The districts could also seek an injunction to stop a strike from happening. If teachers failed to comply, they could face up to $500 a day in fines and up to six months in county jail‚Äîand if found in contempt of court, they could be fired without a hearing. The bill is still under consideration, and is seen as a long-shot to make it through the state legislature. Plastic attack: Some ninety percent of sea birds have been found to have plastic in their bellies, and the problem is only getting worse. The estimated 19 billion pounds of plastic that ends up in the ocean every year is expected to double by 2025. Unfortunately, no single country can make a significant enough impact to solve it before some of the impacts become irreversible. Cleaning up the ocean will require an international agreement on par with the Paris climate accord, and soon. This article was originally published by The New Republic and appears on Mother Jones as a part of the Climate Desk collaboration. Do countries that drink less have less breast cancer? Earlier this month, MoJo's Stephanie Mencimer published a deeply personal investigation into the link between alcohol and breast cancer. Alcohol is implicated in about five percent of all cancer cases, and 15 percent of all breast cancers. Studies also show that countries with less alcohol consumption have lower rates of breast cancer. Places like the Middle East and sub-Saharan Africa, where alcohol consumption is low also have far fewer cases of cancers. Read more about this investigation on http://motherjones.com #breastcancer #alcohol #investigation #health üì∏ by Dikobraziy/Vladans/Shutterstock/Getty

She fled genocide in Rwanda‚Äîand ended up on Oprah. Now, she's ready to share her full story. In the wake of the 1994 genocide, Clemantine Wamariya escaped her hometown of Kigali, Rwanda. Louisiana has notoriously overworked and underfunded public defenders. Now, a bill aims the change that. The only problem? Public defenders hate the proposal. The bill, which is currently awaiting debate in the Louisiana House, would increase the amount of money allocated to the state‚Äôs public defender offices by the Louisiana Public Defender Board, their umbrella organization. But there's opposition from public defenders, as it would likely fund the offices by slashing the budget of legal aid organizations like the Innocence Project New Orleans, which works to overturn wrongful convictions, and the Louisiana Center for Children‚Äôs Rights, which provides public defense for juveniles. The GOP House's new farm bill would gut a key green program, the Conservation Stewardship Program: The CSP is arguably the most important program to encourage farmers to protect soil and water resources, and last week's draft of the farm bill, the once-every-five-years legislation that shapes and funds the country‚Äôs agriculture funding and policy, would gut the program. The plan is to fold the CSP into another, similar conservation initiative called the Environmental Quality Incentives Program. While that may sound innocuous, the National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition shows that the move would shave off nearly $5 billion from conservation funding over 10 years. The Trump Administration wants to gut funding for publicly funded preschools: The number of American children enrolled in publicly funded preschools is growing‚Äîbut states are spending less per child than they were 15 years ago. According to a Rutgers University Report, public preschool programs have made major progress since 2002. However, that budget growth hasn‚Äôt kept up with increased enrollment, which means per-child spending has actually declined. To make matters worse, the administration hopes to slash federal funding aimed at getting more disadvantaged kids into preschool. Earth‚Äôs powerful, climate-shaping water currents are weak and broken and it might be time to freak out. The warm Atlantic current, linked to severe and abrupt changes in the climate in the past, is now at its weakest in at least 1,600 years. Europe could suffer more extreme winters. Sea level rise on America's east coast could disrupt vital tropical rains. The new research shows the current is now 15 percent weaker than around 400 AD, and that human-caused global warming is responsible for at least a significant part of the weakening. This article was initially published on the Guardian and appears on Mother Jones as a part of the Climate Desk collaboration. Read more stories on climate change on motherjones.com #climatechange #currents #environmentalissues. (üì∏ by piola666/iStock/Getty)

Attack of the green blobs: Every summer, a massive green-algae blob colonizes western Lake Erie. According to the EPA, ‚Äúpets and livestock have died from drinking water contaminated with microcystins.‚Äù Predictably, these blobs are created by the use of fertilizers, and they‚Äôre leading to a much bigger methane problem than previously assumed. Hidden threat: Warming waters in the Antarctic have caused the base of ice near the ocean floor around the south pole to shrink by 1,463 square kilometers‚Äîan area the size of Greater London‚Äîbetween 2010 and 2016, according to the new study published in Nature Geoscience. In 1968, following the deaths of two Memphis sanitation workers, the city erupted in a campaign for dignity and higher pay. The protests drew the attention of Martin Luther King Jr., who spent his final days alongside the workers in their battle against the city‚Äôs white leadership. On the anniversary of President Donald Trump‚Äôs travel ban, Mother Jones asked readers to share their stories about how the ban has affected them. More Cambridge Analytica drama keeps unfolding at pace. The suspension comes one day after Britain‚Äôs Channel 4 News published an explosive video from a months-long undercover investigation that captured the firm‚Äôs top executives discussing various ways it offered to entrap politicians, including using sex workers. The Supreme Court this week heard arguments in a blockbuster case that could shift the law of the land on free speech and abortion rights. During oral arguments in National Institute of Family and Life Advocates (NIFLA) v. Becerra yesterday, justices wrestled with the cases's central conundrum. A ruling favoring anti-abortion plaintiffs that could lay the legal foundation for future pro-choice victories. It's the first major abortion-related case to come before the court since President Trump appointed Justice Neil Gorsuch, and it zeroes in on laws requiring medical clinics to disclose if they are unlicensed to  perform abortions. Read more about the act and the arguments at motherjones.com. #NIFLA #prochoice #prolife #abortion #supremecourt

You might want to back slowly away from that delicious Hawaiian poke bowl. Long a staple dish of Hawaiian fishing communities, poke‚Äîwhich means ‚Äúto cut into pieces‚Äù‚Äîis often composed of tuna but can be made from other species of fish, octopus, shellfish, or even pork. The number of Hawaiian restaurants on the mainland, mostly in California, doubled between 2014 and 2016, BUT there‚Äôs a dark side to this dish‚Äôs newfound popularity. Ahi, the star of most poke bowls, commonly refers to yellowfin or bigeye tuna. These fish, which help keep ocean ecosystems in balance, are considered a near-threatened species. To add to this, distributors often use carbon monoxide to preserve the pink color in their tuna, which critics warn makes the fish appear artificially fresh. To read more about the growing environmental concerns linked to tuna poke bowls, check out motherjones.com or pick up the March/April 2018 issue. #Tune #pokebowl #Hawaii #environmentalissues

The FBI is too white‚Äîand it considers that a ‚Äúhuge operational risk‚Äù, according to one senior official quoted in this ProPublica investigation. Almost 30 years ago, a group of black agents sued the FBI, alleging systemic discrimination in the quality of assignments, performance reviews, rates of promotions and overall workplace culture. Hiring problems remain, according to ProPublica. In fact, former FBI Director James Comey called the agency‚Äôs lack of diversity ‚Äúa crisis.‚Äù Read more at motherjones.com #FBI #diversity #JamesComey Picture by Lannis Waters/Zuma Press

Since the 1970s, federal officials used the Migratory Bird Treaty Act to fine companies that accidentally killed birds with oil pits, wind turbines, spills or other industrial hazards. But a legal decision issued in December by the Interior Department revoked that ability. Under the new interpretation, the law no longer applies to oil spills. After the 2010 Deepwater Horizon spill in the Gulf of Mexico, which researchers estimate killed more than a million birds, BP paid a $100 million settlement for violating the Migratory Bird Treaty Act, among other fines. But now, wildlife officials predict deadly consequences for migratory birds. This article was initially published by Reveal, and appears on Mother Jones as a Climate Desk collaboration. Read more on motherjones.com. #birds #environmentalissues #oilspills #TrumpAdmin

Attorney General Jeff Sessions' contribution to a White House plan to make schools safer post-Parkland is to put more cops in schools. But civil rights groups fear the policy will target students of color, resulting in more arrests and charges for offenses like truancy and fighting. According to Education Department civil rights data, black students are 2.2 times more likely to be either referred to law enforcement or arrested at school than white students. To read more about measures taken by the government post-Parkland, check out motherjones.com #Parkland #massshootings #JessSessions #TrumpAdmin

Washington Gov. Jay Inslee is set to sign a sweeping election reform package on Monday that will make his state one of the leaders in the country in expanding voting rights. The ‚ÄúAccess to Democracy‚Äù bills passed by lawmakers include automatic voter registration, Election Day registration, pre-registration for 16- and 17-year-olds, and a state version of the national Voting Rights Act. This is the second state after California to have all four policies in place. Read more from MoJo voting rights expert Ari Berman at motherjones.com. #voting #Washingtonstate #accesstodemocracy

Puerto Rico after Maria: Yabucoa, a town of about 35,000 on the southeastern corner of Puerto Rico, was devastated by Hurricane Maria. The winds destroyed concrete homes that had withstood prior hurricanes, leaving it the hardest hit place on an island wrecked with devastation. With the six-month anniversary of the storm approaching on Tuesday, just 35 percent of the town has been reconnected to power. Residents feel frustrated, neglected and forgotten. To read more about the residents of Yabucoa and their struggles, check out continuing coverage by @ajvicens on motherjones.com. #puertorico #hurricanemaria #trump #environmentaljustice #Yabucoa üì∏ by Eduardo Mel√©ndez. The impacts of lead exposure on children‚Äôs health and development are widely known, but new research suggests the poison could be more harmful to adults than previously thought. The research team, led by Bruce Lanphear, a professor of health science at Simon Fraser University in British Columbia, examined medical records on lead exposure in roughly 14,000 adult subjects. Their analysis concluded that lead accounted for the deaths of 18 percent of their decedents. Extrapolated to the number of annual deaths in the United States, the finding suggests lead exposure could be responsible for the deaths of some 412,000 adults each year. By comparison, according to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, guns killed about 38,000 Americans in 2016, and cigarettes killed about 480,000. Read more about the dangers of lead contamination on motherjones.com #leadcontamination #environmentaljustice #lead #science

Happy 85th birthday to Ruth Bader Ginsburg! Appointed by President Bill Clinton in 1993, she is the second female justice to be confirmed to the court (and still only one of four women appointed). She was also the first Supreme Court justice to officiate a same-sex marriage ceremony in 2013. Some of her landmark cases include United States vs. Virginia, 1996, where the Supreme Court struck down the long-standing male-only admission policy of the Virginia Military Institue, and Olmstead v. LC, 1999, a case regarding discrimination against people with mental disabilities. Fondly referred to as the ‚ÄúNotorious RBG,‚Äù she is considered to be a champion for gender equality and civil rights. #RBG #birthday #supremecourtjustice #genderequality #civilrights Picture by Doug Mills/AP

The Southwest United States is wrapping up an abnormally dry winter. Nearly all of Utah, New Mexico, Colorado, Arizona, and California have been afflicted by drought conditions so far this year. The region is naturally dry, of course, but over the last 100 years, developers have turned sprawling deserts into communities with thirsty lawns and golf courses, and climate change is set to make droughts worse as less rain falls in the future. Read more environmental news on motherjones.com #climatechange #environment #draught #SouthwestUS

The World Health Organization defines an underweight newborn as weighing less than 5 pounds, 8 ounces. In 2016, according to new joint report from the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation and the University of Wisconsin Population Health Institute‚Äôs annual county health rankings, 8.2 percent of new babies failed to exceed the threshold. That‚Äôs a 2 percent increase in underweight births since 2014, particularly seen among the African-American population. To show just how dire the disparity is for African Americans, the researchers compared the underweight birth rate for black babies in each state with the overall rates for that state‚Äôs lowest performing counties. In every case, the statewide rate for black babies was worse than the rates for those counties. Check out motherjones.com for the complete study. #WHO #underweightbirths #racism #babies source: countyhealthrankings.org

The National Rifle Association, which spends millions of dollars lobbying Congress, dominates the debate and considers any restriction a threat to the right to own a gun. Ticks carried by migratory birds have appeared in Canada for decades. But it‚Äôs only been within the last 10 to 15 years, amid a changing climate and the creation of new habitats in the north, that populations of deer ticks have exploded. According to Canada‚Äôs Lyme surveillance efforts, the number of reported Lyme cases increased more than six-fold from 2009 (144 reported cases) to 2016 (987 reported cases). And while public awareness of the disease has expanded in Canada as caseloads surge, many patients still struggle to get appropriately diagnosed and treated‚Äîenough so that many of them have been driven to seek help beyond the country‚Äôs borders. Read more about climate change and other environmental issues on motherjones.com #lymedisease #canada #climatechange

In the weeks after Donald Trump was elected president, Americans flocked to the internet with pressing questions. Few sources were as widely consulted as ‚ÄúDo You Understand the Electoral College?‚Äù a five-minute video hosted by retired lawyer and television pundit Tara Ross. The Electoral College video had about 850,000 views before the election, says Allen Estrin, Prager‚Äôs producer and consigliere. ‚ÄúTwo weeks later, it had 50 million.‚Äù Since 2012, PragerU has posted nearly 300 similarly accessible videos, most covering core conservative doctrines including that police are not biased against black men, and man-made climate change is debatable. You‚Äôll find takes on animal rights (against), the $15 minimum wage (against), the gender wage gap (doesn‚Äôt exist), and why the South turned Republican (nothing to do with race). To read more about these viral right-wing videos and the groups responsible for making them, check out motherjones.com #rightwingpolitics #YouTube #conservatives

MoJo photo essay: Wawarsing, New York, was once a proud manufacturing hub known for producing high-quality knives in the Hudson Valley. But its 150-year-old industry withered as companies were bought and sold, then squeezed for maximum profit until they packed up and moved overseas. Some 500 workers were left without jobs. The largest employers in the county are now Wal-Mart and Eastern Correctional Facility. Photographer Jason Koxvold moved to the area in 2014, and set about documenting the town, its knives, and the workers who have been left behind. The result is KNIVES, a book that explores capitalism, the rise of Donald Trump, and white men. Read our interview and check out more of Koxvold‚Äôs awesome photos at motherjones.com #Knives #Wawarsing #Capitalism #manufacturing #Trump

One weird western bird is again at the center of a battle between conservationists and the federal government. The greater sage-grouse‚Äîonce a candidate for the endangered species list‚Äîfaces an uncertain future. In 2015, as a result of increased drilling and mining in its 167-million-acre sagebrush habitat, the sage-grouse population had declined by up to 90 percent from historic levels. A $45 million plan to protect the species implemented by western states, the Department of the Interior, and the USDA was largely a compromise between industry-minded conservatives and environmentalists. It required cooperation among more than 1,100 ranchers in 11 states to protect nearly 70 million acres of sage-grouse habitat from commercial activity. Now, organizations like the National Wildlife Federation, the Audubon Society, and the Natural Resources Defense Council are saying Trump‚Äôs Interior Secretary, Ryan Zinke, is refusing to honor this plan to protect this bird. Read more on motherjones.com #GreaterSageGrouse #endangered #conservation #environment #conservatives #trump üì∏ by Bob Wick/Zuma Press

In not-so-surprising news, Republicans on the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence officially announced Monday night that they have concluded their investigation of Russian interference in the 2016 election. Mike Conaway (R-Texas) on Monday agreed with US intelligence agencies that Russia meddled in the election, but, strikingly, noted that the Republicans on the panel rejected the intelligence community‚Äôs unanimous conclusion that Russia wanted Trump in the White House. We now have a new assessment of the United States‚Äô military spending compared to the rest of the world. The Stockholm International Peace Research Institute estimates that the US devoted $611 billion to its military machine in 2016. That was more than the defense expenditures of the next nine countries combined, almost three times what runner-up China put out, and 36 percent of total global military spending. Yet reading the Trump Administration‚Äôs Nuclear Posture Review‚Äî recommending the president have more ‚Äúflexible‚Äù nuclear options at his disposal‚Äîyou might be led to believe America is the most vulnerable country on Earth. This article first appeared in TomDispatch.com and was republished on motherjones.com. #nuclearweapons #Trump #military

The census is our best source of information about the nation, and the only way to draw fair legislative boundaries. But today it is in danger. President Donald Trump is threatening the 2020 census from every direction: Cutting its budget, scaring immigrants away from answering its questions, and prohibiting the Census Bureau from hiring the best people for the job. While the census has always revealed our deepest insecurities about race and inequality, read motherjones.com to understand how it is being further threatened. #census #Trump #immigrants #demographics

California Dreamin': The California Freedom Coalition is one of a handful of organizations that have emerged in the wake of Donald Trump‚Äôs election to promote the idea that California should peacefully split off and form an independent country. Californians often feel like they‚Äôre a breed apart, but that sense has intensified lately. Hillary Clinton swept the state with more that 61 percent of the vote. Democrats have controlled the governor‚Äôs mansion and both houses of the legislature since 2011. Gov. Jerry Brown and the state‚Äôs Democratic leadership have presented the state as a liberal counterweight to the Trump administration‚Äôs immigration, drug, and environmental policies. Read more about how and why Californians want to do this on motherjones.com #California #Liberalism #Trump #Democrats

A new letter to the Drug Enforcement Agency from the American Civil Liberties Union of Nebraska is calling on the DEA to investigate Nebraska State Penitentiary officials for allegedly illegally obtaining drugs to use in lethal injections. Nebraska‚Äôs proposed lethal cocktail calls for diazepam, a sedative, and fentanyl to render the prisoner unconscious, cisatracurium to paralyze the inmate, and finally potassium chloride to stop the heart. But medical experts say that if the first two drugs aren‚Äôt administered properly, the paralytic would leave the inmate unable to scream or move to indicate pain. This isn‚Äôt the first time Nebraska has come under fire for allegedly trying to obtain lethal injection drugs. Read more on motherjones.com #fentanyl #deathpenalty #drugs #Nebraska üì∏ by Nate Jenkins/AP

In the winter of 1996, a flood hit Isleton, California. As residents returned to their homes and went through their kitchens, they found that the paper labels on their canned foods had disintegrated. The only identifiable product, thanks to its printed aluminum can, was Spam. For the past 20 years, the town of roughly 800 people on the Sacramento River has commemorated this postdiluvian miracle with an annual Spam Festival. This year, nearly 20 contestants vied for a chance to get their names inscribed on the Spamley Cup, serving up creations such as Spam tacos, Spam pasta, Spam gumbo, Spam tamales, deep-fried jalape√±o Spam on a stick, Spam meat pies, Spamaroni and chesse, Spam jerky (‚ÄúSperky‚Äù), and Spam cheesecake. Read more about this festival that celebrates America‚Äôs favorite canned meat on motherjones.com #Spam #California #festival

In the first year of Trump‚Äôs presidency, he nominated 69 federal judges, more than any president since Reagan. A record-breaking 12 were appeals court judges. Since the start of the new year, Trump has nominated nearly two dozen more judges. In total, 71 percent of Trump‚Äôs nominees have been white men. Federal judges serve for life and are rarely impeached. The numbers Mother Jones compiled show a president who is working hard to cement a judiciary, and a legacy, that will last long beyond his term. Check out the charts on motherjones.com #trumpadmin #judiciary #diversity

After a mass shooting in a high school in Parkland, Florida left 14 students and three teachers dead last month, the Giffords Law Center for Preventing Gun Violence gathered studies, media reports, and government data to analyze the toll gun violence has taken on children since 1998. In the last two decades, more than 150,000 kids at more than 170 elementary, middle, and high schools have experienced a shooting on campus. A new report from the Giffords Law Center to Prevent Gun Violence suggests those kids, as well as those who encounter gun violence in their daily lives, continue to suffer the consequences for decades. For the highlights of the resulting paper, ‚ÄúProtecting the Parkland Generation,‚Äù check out motherjones.com. #Parkland #massshootings #guncontrol

In 2014, Charles Stricker III learned that his ballot was not counted. He was one of 35,000 voters in Kansas who had their registrations blocked by the state for failing to provide documentary proof of citizenship, such as a birth certificate, passport, or naturalization papers, when they registered. Stricker, who‚Äôd recently moved back to Wichita from Chicago, had brought his Illinois driver‚Äôs license, Social Security card, and utility bill to confirm his identity and residence. The proof-of-citizenship measure prevented 1 in 7 new voters from registering between 2013 and 2016, nearly half of whom were under 30. In 2016, Stricker joined a lawsuit filed by the ACLU against Kansas Secretary of State Kris Kobach. Ari Berman details the case against Kobach on motherjones.com #votersupression #Kansas #KrisKobach #voting

On Tuesday, Mother Jones published a lengthy investigation about a mysterious Russian-linked firm that hired a former Trump campaign aide named Nick Muzin to work in the United States‚Ä¶ to help the right-wing Democratic Party of Albania during the country‚Äôs 2017 parliamentary elections. Got all that? We tried to track down these Russian-linked companies and their representatives by examining Russian corporate records, sending a reporter to several addresses in Moscow, and calling and emailing entities and individuals in Russia, Ukraine, Canada, and the United States. We never obtained a complete answer. But our question hit a nerve. Over the last two days, several media outlets in Albania reprinted pieces of our story, as Albanian politicians and the Russian embassy in Tirana denounced the article‚Äîand Mother Jones. To read the piece that has led the Russian embassy in Albania to call us a ‚Äúdirty news campaign,‚Äù check out motherjones.com #russia #albania #trump #putin #rightwing

In 1998, the state of Rhode Island‚Äîwhich had a disproportionate number of children with elevated blood lead levels‚Äîwanted Fidelma Fitzpatrick‚Äôs help suing the paint industry. After an unsuccessful campaign for Senate in 2016, Ann Kirkpatrick is a leading contender to win the Democratic nomination in the smaller and less rural second congressional district, and she‚Äôs singing a different tune than she was a decade ago. Kirkpatrick, once the model of a rural, pro-gun Democrat, is emblematic of the broader shift within the party. As we bid farewell to the Oscars for another year, a little tidbit from the archives we found: Did you know the Hollywood Sign used to be the Hollywoodland sign? According to the Hollywood Sign Trust, the ownership of the sign passed to the city in the mid-1940s. The L.A. Recreation and Parks Commission apparently wanted it demolished. But the Hollywood Chamber of Commerce stepped in, and in 1949 it removed the last four letters and restored the rest. Today, this neighborhood stands as the historic birthplace of the U.S. film industry, with its biggest awards ceremony, the Oscars, concluding its 90th chapter yesterday. For our coverage of the Oscars, check out Motherjones.com #Oscars2018 #hollywood #archives Source: NYPL Digital Collections

Women‚Äôs rights groups think now is the moment to finally get the Equal Rights Amendment passed. The ERA, which says simply ‚Äúequality of rights under the law shall not be denied or abridged‚Ä¶on account of sex,‚Äù was passed by Congress in 1972, at the height of the women‚Äôs movement. The proposal‚Äôs passage was a joint effort by feminists and labor groups like the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations. But conservatives and anti-feminist activists fought fiercely against it. By the time the 1982 deadline rolled around, only 35 states had ratified‚Äîthree short of what was needed. The amendment was dead. But with movements like #Metoo and #TimesUp, the advocates of the Amendment think it might be time for it to see the light of day. Read more on motherjones.com #Metoo #Timesup #Womensrights #Feminism

In 2016, we found that one of the city‚Äôs lead pipes had been replaced for the benefit of the press, but more than 8,000 additional service lines were likely corroded and still leaching toxic lead. And that‚Äôs not all. An outbreak of Legionnaires‚Äô disease killed at least 9 people and infected 87 others over the last two years. The state knew. The city knew. The county knew. The federal government knew. But the public was never told. Photographer and filmmaker Zackary Canepari, along with co-directors Jessica Dimmock and Drea Cooper, now have an eight-part documentary on Netflix, which follows the Flint police department over a two-year period. The series, Flint Town, digs into issues the city faces beyond the water crisis. Read the Flint investigation from the May/June 2016 issue on Motherjones.com. #flint #watercontamination #environmentaljustice #netflix #documentary
