A new study finds that ‚Äújunk news‚Äù is a staple of the #MAGA crowd. Denise Clifton reports that Trump supporters are among the most prolific social media users spreading fake news and conspiracy content, according to new research from Oxford University‚Äôs Computational Propaganda Research Project, which has been studying disinformation campaigns globally since 2014. 
The group‚Äôs new findings are based on study of more than 13,000 Twitter accounts representing politically diverse viewpoints, including just under 2,000 pro-Trump accounts‚Äîwhich were identified by terms like #MAGA included on their Twitter profiles and explicitly pro-Trump content they have shared.

The researchers also studied content from more than 47,000 public Facebook pages during the same 90-day period; they determined that about 60 percent of the total ‚Äújunk news‚Äù links were posted by users that appeared to be aligned with the political far right. (The research doesn‚Äôt address whether any of these Twitter and Facebook accounts may be controlled by bots or other deceptive online operators.) #tinfoilhat #maga #junknews #deniseclifton #disinformation

ECOT was created by a washed-up lobbyist scribbling plans on Waffle House napkins. It was backed and/or funded by Jeb Bush, John Kasich, Betsy Devos and numerous other GOP donors. After skimming a BILLION dollars from Ohio public schools, it was forced to close today, leaving thousands of kids in the lurch.

Sick. Uninsured. And begging the internet for a lifeline-by crowdfunding for healthcare. Stephen Marche reports on America's dystopian health care system that forces people into a lethal popularity contest. 
After receiving a diagnosis of stage 4 breast cancer, Marissa Rahdar had to figure out how to beg for her life. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt want to do it at all,‚Äù she recalls. Rahdar is a 32-year-old bartender from Detroit, and she has insurance. Her brother, Dante, the one in the family who‚Äôs good with numbers, worked out the amount she‚Äôd need to cover her out-of-pocket medical expenses and take a break from serving beer so she could rest up after chemotherapy. The number he came up with was $25,000. Read what happened to Rahdar and how crowdfunding has impacted healthcare in America at motherjones.com or in the January/February issue. (Illo by Brian Stauffer @staufferstudio; Photo of Marissa Rahdar by Laura McDermott @lauramcdermottphoto) #gofundyourself #healthcare

Sometime in the next 40 years, robots are going to take your job. As Kevin Drum explains in his newest piece, it doesn't matter what your job is, if you dig ditches, a robot will dig them better. In January, 2016 Border Angels opened their water drops to public volunteers. The signups peaked in November, 2016 with 400 people signing up to leave water for migrants attempting to cross the U.S.-Mexico border. Today, to keep the program sustainable, they limit signups to 20-60 per month. The exact locations of water drops are not publicized ‚Äì the group has found their water bottles slashed with knives. Stay tuned to #mojodayattheborder for the rest of our Instagram mini-series. #borderwall #immigration #borderangels #documentary

A non-profit based in California, Border Angels focuses on undocumented immigrant issues. The group‚Äôs first trips to distribute water in the desert for migrants crossing the U.S.-Mexico border began in 1998. Today, Border Angels uses their water drops as an opportunity to galvanize public volunteers around their cause as well as to build empathy for migrants. Mother Jones joined the group for a day in September. Follow our Instagram mini-series #mojodayattheborder to get a glimpse of what the crossing journey is like. #borderwall #immigration #borderangels #documentary

1 in 5 election-related tweets weren‚Äôt from real people, research shows. Denise Clifton looks into how Twitter Bots distorted the 2016 election‚Äìincluding a number of bot accounts likely from Russia. Russian-pushed content and fake news on Twitter peaked in the swing state of Michigan‚Äîwhich Trump won narrowly‚Äîthe day before the election. "The day Donald Trump was elected president, nearly 2,000 Twitter accounts that had pumped out pro-Trump messages in the run-up to the vote suddenly went dark. Then, in spring 2017, these bot-controlled accounts reemerged to campaign en fran√ßais for Marine Le Pen in the French election, and then once again this fall, to tweet auf Deutsch on behalf of the far-right party in Germany‚Äôs election. The bots were part of a larger group tracked over a month-long period before the US election by University of Southern California researchers, who discovered that bots were deeply entwined in political conversation on Twitter‚Äîaccounting for 1 in 5 election-related tweets." Read the full story and all of our Russia-related investigation at motherjones.com. (photo: Larry Marano/Rex Shutterstock/ZUMA) #whoknewwhatwhen #election2016 #twitterbots #russianinvestigation

David Corn isn't mincing words in his latest piece, "Why You Really Should Be Scared Shitless About Trump and Nuclear Weapons"

The revelation that Trump wanted nearly ten times the number of nukes is just the start. "On Wednesday morning, NBC News provided sane people with more reason to be scared: at a private July 20 meeting with his top national security officials, President Donald Trump said he wanted a nearly tenfold increase in the US nuclear arsenal. He made this remark after being shown a chart that illustrated a steady decrease in the number of US nuclear weapons over the past 50 years. Trump responded by telling his most senior advisers, which included Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and the Joint Chiefs of Staff, that he wanted the bigger number shown at the start of the downward slope, not the smaller amount at the end. Officials had to explain to Trump that the current level was lower due to years of successful arms treaties and that the nation‚Äôs overall military posture was now much stronger than in the days of a larger and bloated nuclear arsenal. It was at the end of this meeting‚Äîwhere other national security matters were discussed‚Äîthat Tillerson apparently was overheard referring to Trump as a 'moron.'" Read Corn's full take on the latest cause for alarm at motherjones.com (image: iStockphoto/Getty) #davidcorn #nuclearwar #fuckingmoron

Margareta Dumitrescu (1903-1986) was a Romanian speleologist and cave biologist who studied bats, collected all manner of cave critters, many of which are named after her, and contributed to mapping many caves in Romania and beyond. She was the first chief of the Biospeleology Department of the Institute of Speleology in Bucharest, which she was instrumental in reorganizing after the death of its founder. Here's to women being both fearless explorers in the depths of the earth and fearless leaders in roles traditionally exclusive of women. Repost from @cas_arachnerds #IWD2017
#speleology #caves #biology #womeninscience #californiaacademyofscience

Thousands of girls are locked up simply for talking back or staying out late. Read Hannah Levintova's piece on motherjones.com, accompanied by Richard Ross' photos from his Girls In Justice project. @juvenileinjustice In this image: F.E., age 17 Cuyahoga County Juvenile Detention Center, Ohio.

This is F.E.'s sixth incarceration since she was 13 years old. She has violated probation a number of times, most recently for fighting with her mother, who called the police. Her parents are separated. When F.E. was 12, her mother sent her to Alabama to live with her father, who she says beat her and only gave her $20 a week for food. "I told my mom how bad it was," she says. "But she thought I was just saying that." She began acting out, so her father kicked her out. She went to live with a friend, but her father found her, broke the door down, and beat her. She had a black eye and bruises, and her father sent her back home to Ohio, where she took Molly and Xanax. She is now in a drug program while in detention. "I am going to go to Lakewood College and then to Kent State and do a degree in psychology," she says. "If I ever get on track." #juvenileinjustice #girlsinjustice #mojophoto #prison #richardross @everydayincarceration

The heat index hit 109 in Philadelphia, according to a radio report I hear yesterday. Logistics for the DNC have been much less organized than the RNC. Here, outside the Philadelphia Convention Center (about 3 miles north of the Wells Fargo Center, where the DNC is) delegates waited in the heat for buses to take them to the convention. The weather and general confusion around this convention has made emotions raw among attendees and journalists everywhere I've been around Philadelphia; there were pockets of arguments between delegates waiting in the heat. 
Photo by @mscottbrauer #demsinphilly

Yesterday, the Democratic National Convention officially started in Philadelphia. There've been far more protests and demonstrations here than at the RNC. Here, a group of organizations, including Veterans for Peace and the World Can't Wait handed out information about what they feel are crimes perpetrated around the world by the American government. They were set up outside the United Methodist Church on Arch Street near City Hall. The church is a sort of "activist oasis," offering air conditioning, water, food, quietude, and other support to protesters. 
Photo by @mscottbrauer for @motherjonesmag #demsinphilly  I'll be posting more pictures throughout the day and the rest of the week on @motherjonesmag

The area where the DNC is being held in Philadelphia seems much larger and further away from things than the RNC venue in Cleveland. It took me about an hour and a half of walking in the heat to find the correct entrance yesterday, after being told conflicting information by DNC volunteers, local police, secret service, and everyone else. I wasn't the only one who had trouble finding the media entrance or who was frustrated by the size of the venue. 
Here, an activist named Annette Elbaz was walking along the eastern perimeter of the larger DNC area. She was trying to find the protest (about which I posted earlier today). The protest ended at FDR park on the western edge of the DNC area, which was about another mile or so from where she was due to fences and barriers put up for the convention. Elbaz said she came down to Philadelphia after attending a Rainbow Gathering in Vermont. She said she "slept in the rough" on the way down to Philadelphia and did some day labor jobs to help fund the trip. On the way, a 24 karat gold necklace was stolen from her; she had hoped to sell it as a way to fund her trip. The necklace came from Egypt, where she lived for a few years recently. She said she witnessed the revolution there first hand and it reinvigorated her activism. She is a Bernie Sanders supporter and said she's not sure if Hillary is right for the country right now.

Now it's time for the Democratic National Convention. This is @mscottbrauer again posting for @motherjonesmag all week. One of the central themes of my project, This is the worst party I've ever been to, about the current election, is that regardless of party or candidate, the campaign process is virtually identical. The stages, posters, buttons, food, music, etc., are almost interchangeable between the political parties. Here, you can see the stage of the Democratic National Convention at the Wells Fargo Center in Philadelphia yesterday, and it looks pretty similar, though with maybe a bit more blue than red. Two notable differences between this and the RNC stage: the delegate floor is much smaller, with only a handful of states on ground level in front of the stage; and there are no slogans or banners on display around the arena. #demsinphilly

Last night, as people were leaving, balloons managed to get just about everywhere. That's all I'll share for now. Stay tuned to @motherjonesmag for my coverage from the DNC next week.

Last night, Donald Trump was officially nominated as the 2016 presidential candidate by the Republican party. There were so many photographers near the New York delegation that I decided I'd try to photograph something from the stands. This may look familiar to those of you following along with my coverage. I posted a similar picture with Nikki Haley on the screen. Covering an event like this is a challenge, because it involves photographing the same thing over and over for 4 days. In a final edit, I won't include both images, but I'll continue working this scene to find an image that really works.

I've spent most of today outside the convention. There've been small demonstrations all around downtown Cleveland, but mostly around Public Square; mostly there are more people with cameras than there are demonstrators. Here, Stevedore Crawford of Columbus, OH, is one of those demonstrators in Public Square, surrounded a couple members of his family and friends and a lot of media. He said that in 1984, he was shot by a police officer and he shot the police officer back. He spent 12 years in prison. He spoke about racism, Tamir Rice, and police conduct.

This is @mscottbrauer taking over the instagram feed for @motherjonesmag. I've just arrived in Cleveland to cover the Republican National Convention. Media were allowed in to the Quicken Loans Arena today to set up equipment and preview the scene. I'll be posting photos from the convention throughout the week. My coverage this week is an extension of my project on the New Hampshire primary, "This is the worst party I've ever been to." The images are meant to be a critical examination of the overall process of the modern American political campaign, rather than a critique of one particular candidate or party. I'll be covering the DNC next week from Philadelphia, too. #rncincle

Reframe from @visura.co: Two protestors outside the Dreamstar Northland Family Planning Clinic in Detroit, 2015. Shot for Mother Jones by @donnaferrato. The man has never been married nor had children. The woman is also unmarried and raised her own two children. Both protestors identify as Christians. They pray from the sidewalk because they will be arrested if they walk into the facility's parking lot or get too close to the clients. So they circle the premises shouting, "Your child is your future! Don't kill it!" They've been protesting at the clinic two or three days a week for fifteen years.
#donnaferrato #womensrights #humanrights #documentary #photojournalism #prochoice #prolife #protesters #abortion #detroit #motherjones

Regramm from @visura.co: Norma McCorvey, also known as Jane Roe, controversial face of Roe vs. Wade, holding hands with cardboard President ‚ÄúPoppy‚Äù Bush in Washington, D.C., 1992. In 1992 another major Supreme Court decision was made in the case of Planned Parenthood of Southeastern Pennsylvania v. Casey. In a 5-4 decision, Roe was upheld, but many new obstacles for women seeking abortion were deemed acceptable, as it was decided they did not place an ‚Äúundue burden‚Äù on the woman. Among them were a 24-hour waiting period and parental consent for minors. These provisions were the beginning of the pro-lifers‚Äô war to furtively introduce new legislation targeted at pro-choice women and abortion providers.

Repost from @cas_arachnerds: Happy Darwin Day! Darwin received a package of orchids from Madagascar in 1862. He remarked to Joseph Hooker, "I have just received such a Box full from Mr Bateman with the astounding Agraecum sesquipedalia with a nectary a foot long--Good Heavens what insect can suck it?" He surmised, correctly, that there must be a moth with a proboscis long enough to reach the nectar at the end of the spur. Wallace correctly surmised it was a hawkmoth. In 1903 the insect was discovered. We have both at CAS! #darwinday #february12 #darwin #evolution #science #scienceeducation #casarachnology #casentomology #hawkmoth #sphingidae #xanthopanmorganii #angraecumsesquipedale #orchid #madagascar #charlesdarwin #josephhooker #alfredrusselwallace #Regrann

Bernie Sanders' election night rally in Concord, New Hampshire, turned into a dance party quickly. The networks declared the Vermont senator the winner as soon as the polls closed at 8 pm.

Hailea Fiona voted for Hillary. "I really admire her as a person and I like Bernie Sanders but I feel like I'm a little bit too old for his message in a way. He's very idealistic--almost like he's running for school president...I feel like she had more of a plan, because she just kept talking about, 'I have a plan, I have a plan'."
Amelia Campbell voted for Bernie Sanders. "I think we need a revolution. I think the system's broken...People are just buried in [student] debt and I think that's wrong."

Rob Albert of Manchester voted for Jeb Bush. "Because he's got a bunch of Medal of Honor recipients that think he's the man, and a bunch of generals that are former military who think he would be the best commander in chief...I didn't like [Rubio] repeating himself and he did it again last night and it's like 'ahhhh'.
...which I guess raises the question, "who is Kelso?"
Bleu, a Scottish Highlander cow, from @milessmithfarm in Loudon, N.H., showed up in Manchester on primary day to show his support for Bernie Sanders and locally sourced food.

Walked into Chez Vachon in Manchester for some emergency poutine, and Carly Fiorina walked in, making a last-minute push for voters. Bill and Hillary were here on Monday . Donald Trump on Saturday. New Hampshire is what they say it is.

In 2013, Miguel Angel Jimenez left his life as a cosmetics salesman to help organize community efforts to identify graves, register disappeared persons, and get government support for victims' families. Horgo≈°, Serbia: Refugees make a break into Hungary through the border fence being constructed between Hungary and Serbia. Most were trying to avoid going to camps in Hungary, fearful that if they are registered and fingerprinted there they will eventually be forced to settle there, as opposed to in a Western European nation.

Photojournalist David Maurice Smith has been on the front lines of the refugee crisis for a year and a half. "A lot of those people are there because of the same conflicts that are forcing others to Europe," Smith says. To see that situation firsthand, Smith recently traveled to, among other places, the Hungarian-Serbian border, where he was awed by the immensity of the crisis. "When you see imagery of flash-point events, and people talking about 'swarms' of people, it can dehumanize the situation," he says. "It's easy to forget that we're talking about individual people with individual stories and individual lives. It's personal, and it's no different than if your son or mother or nephew or daughter was in that situation.‚Äù See more of David‚Äôs work on motherjones.com and follow him on Instagram for his continuation of this story. (photo by David Maurice Smith/Oculi) @davidmauricesmith #refugees #horgos #crisis #Europe #hungary #oculicollective #motherjonesphoto

As seven-year-Olds, Helene Nakamoto Mihara and Mary Ann Yahoo (right) were photographed by Dorothea Lange as they recited the Pledge of Allegiance outside their elementary school in San Francisco in 1942. Both were sent to the Topaz Internment Camp in Utah. Yahiro was separated from her mother, who died in another camp. "I don't have bitterness like a lot of people might," she told photographer Paul Kitagaki Jr. 
In 1945, the federal government began opening internment camps where it held 120,000 Japanese Americans for much of World War II. Seven decades later, Kitagaki has been tracking down internees pictured in wartime images by photographers like Lange. See more at motherjones.com #motherjones #mjphoto #wwii #japaneseinternment #dorothealange #1945 #SquareInstaPic

Seven-year-olds Helene Nakamoto Mihara (left) and Mary Ann Yahiro (center) were photographed by Lange as they recited the Pledge of Allegiance outside their elementary school in San Francisco in 1942. Both were sent to the Topaz Internment Camp in Utah. Yahiro was separated from her mother, who died in another camp. "I don't have bitterness like a lot of people might," she told Kitagaki.

As part of our ongoing investigation into the cost of gun violence, we
documented the stories of eight survivors. This is the last of those eight: Caheri Gutierrez of Oakland, CA photographed by @prestongannaway

On November 20, 2008, 18-year-old Caheri Gutierrez sat at a stoplight in Oakland, on her way to work. A bullet hissed through the window and struck Gutierrez through the jaw. It may have been from a nearby gang incident. When the police came, Gutierrez scribbled down that she had no idea who had pulled the trigger, or why. The case wasn't solved.

She spent the next month in the hospital undergoing multiple procedures, including surgeries to reconstruct her facial bones and install dentures. Medicaid covered most of the $120,000 in costs. Her hospital stay was followed by many months of physical therapy and counseling.

Gutierrez worked in retail before the shooting, but struggled to find a customer service job after the shooting. "I felt like employers didn't want to hire me because the scars were so prevalent," she says. Her caseworker from Youth Alive, a local nonprofit that aids victims of violent crime, helped her relocate to a safer neighborhood and continue with counseling. Today, she works for the organization herself. She also attends nursing school. November 20th is now a special occasion. "I like to celebrate that I'm still here, " Gutierrez says. 
#motherjones #gunviolence #gunviolencesurvivors #oakland #youthalive #guns

As part of our ongoing investigation into the cost of gun violence, we documented the stories of eight survivors. This is one of those eight: Antonius Wiriadjaja of Brooklyn, NY, photographed by @simchiyin / @VIIPhoto

On the afternoon of July 5, 2013, Antonius Wiriadjaja was walking in his neighborhood when a man stalking an ex-lover began shooting at her in broad daylight. A stray bullet pierced Wiriadjaja's chest and lodged in his stomach. At the hospital, Wiriadjaja was put into a coma, beginning what would be a two-week stay. Then, "it took me seven months of physical therapy to regain most of my day-to-day functions, and about 18 months of psychiatric treatment to stave off PTSD," he says.

Part of Wiriadjaja's response was to blog about his recovery, including a series of photos displaying his scars. His medical and mental-health treatments have totaled about $169,000, most of which have been covered by his health insurance. His deductibles and other out-of-pocket expenses cost more than $20,000 eating up his savings. He was told that he was eligible for reimbursements from the state's office of victim services, but the process was so daunting on top of his recovery and return to work that he decided to move on.

Today, Wiriadjaja is an assistant arts professor at New York University in Shanghai. "I'm lucky, because I had savings, health insurance, and an incredible support network," he says. "Many other gunshot survivors are not. I count my blessings every day." The man who helped save his life on the street was shot and killed in South Carolina last year.

#gunviolence #gunviolencesurvivors #motherjones #antoniuswiriadjaja #guns #mjphoto #viiphoto

As part of our ongoing investigation into the cost of gun violence, we¬†
documented the stories of eight survivors. This is one of those eight:¬† Philip Russo of Alturas, CA, photographed by @peterearlmccollough

On February 20, 2014, during a tribal council meeting in Alturas,¬† California, a woman named Cherie Rhoades, angry about an eviction¬† proceeding, walked in with two 9 mm handguns and opened fire. One gun¬† jammed and the other ran out of bullets. She pulled out a butcher's¬†knife and began stabbing people. Two people were critically injured and¬†four died. Shelia Lynn Russo was among those killed.

Philip Russo, her husband, was a part-time correctional officer at the¬†local county jail. After Rhoades was taken there on the day of the¬† shooting, Russo was told he could no longer guard the building‚Äîfor¬† Rhoades' safety.

Not long after, Russo was laid off. Shelia had earned the majority of¬†their household income, about $60,000 annually. Russo lived off savings¬†while he looked for a new job; he now works as a security guard at a¬†medical center in Redding. He has become an advocate for tighter firearm regulations and for survivors of gun violence.

#motherjones #gunviolence #gunviolencesurvivors #guns

As part of our ongoing investigation into the cost of gun violence, we documented the stories of eight survivors. This is one of those eight:  Kamari Ridgle of Richmond, CA, photographed by @prestongannaway

On May 27, 2010, Kamari Ridgle had just left a liquor store in Richmond,¬†California, when a car pulled up behind him and shots rang out. He was¬†hit 22 times before the perpetrators sped off. Ridgle was 15 years old. "When I was shot, I was that kid in and out of juvenile hall," he says, describing his time as a drug dealer. "You develop a name, and people don't like you." He was transported by helicopter to a nearby hospital.

He would have a dozen surgeries, including some later to remove bullets. It was nearly a year before he rolled out of the hospital with his wheelchair and a colostomy bag. Medicaid covered most of his costs.

Today, Ridgle is a full-time accounting and criminal-justice student at Sacramento City College. He was quick to grasp the financial curriculum: It's not that the streets don't have good businessmen, he says, "it's that they all get killed." #gunviolence #gunviolencesurvivor #motherjones #guns #richmond

As part of our ongoing investigation into the cost of gun violence, we documented the stories of eight survivors. This is one of those eight: Paris Brown of Oakland, CA, photographed by @peterearlmccollough

On December 11, 2010, Paris Brown was at a bingo hall when one of her sons called to tell her that someone had just shot Dominic, the fourth of her seven children. Earlier that evening, Dominic, 19, had handed her a gift for her birthday and told her he loved her. The next time she saw him, he was sprawled on the pavement at an intersection in East Oakland, surrounded by police cars.

After the funeral, Brown says she felt deeply alone, despite her large family. She began a year of grief counseling through Catholic Charities of the East Bay. State and local government funds covered the costs, about $10,000. "I could be anywhere and I could just cry," Brown says. "It's an ongoing thing that you feel. I guess I'm going to feel it for the rest of my life." Brown called the Oakland Police Department every few months to check on the status of the case. In 2013, detectives told her that they'd identified a suspect in Dominic's murder, but that there wasn't enough evidence to prosecute without a witness stepping forward. No one has done so, and Brown no longer wants to focus on it.

#motherjones #gunviolence #gunviolencesurvivors #guns #oakland

As part of our ongoing investigation into the cost of gun violence, we documented the stories of eight survivors. This is one of those eight: Pamela Bosley of Chicago, IL, photographed by @jonlowenstein / @noorimages.

On April 4, 2006, on Chicago's South Side, Pamela Bosley's 18-year-old son, Terrell, was unloading a drum set for a church choir rehearsal when a man walked up and opened fire. Terrell died a few hours later. He was one of Chicago's 384 gun homicide victims that year. Bosley describes Terrell, a college freshman and the oldest of three siblings, as "my outgoing son." The few hours Terrell clung to life in the hospital cost about $10,000, mostly covered by insurance.

Bosley spent thousands of dollars on therapy and antidepressants for herself and another family member. Bosley lost several thousand dollars in earnings during a six-month leave of absence from her job. She twice attempted suicide. "I could be okay one hour, then the next minute I could look at something and be broken down," she says. In 2007, Bosley and her husband started a service to help gun violence survivors join support groups. Justice has been elusive: In 2008, a man was charged in connection with Terrell's murder, but prosecutors lacked sufficient evidence, and no one has been convicted.

#motherjones #gunviolence #gunviolencesurvivors #guns #noorimages #chicago

As part of our ongoing investigation into the cost of gun violence, we documented the stories of eight survivors. This is one of those eight: Jennifer Longdon from Phoenix, AZ, photographed by @brandonthibodeaux with @wearemjr

On November 15, 2004, Jennifer Longdon and her fiance pulled into a parking lot in Phoenix when a truck sideswiped theirs. A man got out and began shooting. Her fiance took a bullet through the brain that left him profoundly impaired. Longdon was shot in the spine and left paralyzed from the chest down. The physical devastation was followed by financial ruin. Longdon lost her health insurance shortly after the shooting and has been hospitalized at least 20 times over the past decade. 
Longdon spent $40,000 to modify to her home, just so she could wheel through the front door, make dinner, or take a shower. And she paid $35,000 for a custom lift-equipped van. "I don't think people understand the way nickels and dimes add up to hundreds of thousands of dollars‚Äîmillions of dollars‚Äîover the lifetime of an injury," she says. The Phoenix police investigated, but the crime was never solved. 
#motherjones #gunviolence #phoenix #gunviolencesurvivor #guns

Arthur Burgess, 19, was shot and killed on a cold winter night in Englewood, Chicago, 2009. He was one of the 33,000 people killed by guns each year. His two friends who also got shot but lived are among the 80,000 people injured by guns. Gun violence costs the U.S. $229 billion annually. Read more in our new in-between investigation on the economic impact of gun violence in the May/June issue or online, via the link in our bio.

While the air is cleaner today, they say, there aren't enough jobs, and many have returned to farming.
